When someone is afraid, they feel fear.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've always been afraid of flying.

Vocabulary.mean: To agree is to say “yes” or to think the same way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I agree that he should be invited.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is angry, they may want to speak loudly or fight.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's really angry with me for upsetting Sophie.

Vocabulary.mean: To arrive is to get to or reach some place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. What time will your train arrive?

Vocabulary.mean: To attack is to try to fight or to hurt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Most wild animals won't attack unless they are provoked.

Vocabulary.mean: The bottom is the lowest part.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Extra information will be found at the bottom of the page.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is clever, they can solve a hard puzzle or problem.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Judy has never been very clever, but she tries hard.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is cruel, they do bad things to hurt others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Children can be very cruel to each other.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens finally, it happens after a longtime or at the end.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We finally got home at midnight.

Vocabulary.mean: To hide is to try not to let others see you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She used to hide her diary under her pillow.

Vocabulary.mean: To hunt is to look for or search for an animal to kill.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Wolves hunt in groups known as packs.

Vocabulary.mean: A lot means a large number or amount of people, animals, things, etc.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She eats lots of fruit.

Vocabulary.mean: The middle of something is the center or halfway point.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was standing in the middle of the road.

Vocabulary.mean: A moment is a second or a very short time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'll be ready in just a moment.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is pleased, they are happy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We're so pleased that you're able to come to the wedding.

Vocabulary.mean: To promise is to say you will do something for sure.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He promised faithfully to call me every week.

Vocabulary.mean: To reply is to give an answer or say back to someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I try to reply to letters the day I receive them.

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is safe, they are not in danger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In some cities you don't feel safe going out alone at night.

Vocabulary.mean: A trick is something you do to fool another person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She played a really nasty trick on me - she put syrup in my shampoo bottle!

Vocabulary.mean: You use well to say that something was done in a good way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The documentary presented both sides of the problem very well.

Vocabulary.mean: An adventure is a fun or exciting thing that you do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She had some exciting adventures in Egypt.

Vocabulary.mean: To approach something means to move close to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We could just see the train approaching in the distance.

Vocabulary.mean: Carefully means with great attention, especially to detail or safety.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Drive carefully on those icy roads.

Vocabulary.mean: A chemical is something that scientists use in chemistry.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They use special chemicals to accelerate the growth of crops.

Vocabulary.mean: To create means to make something new.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Bible says that God created the world.

Vocabulary.mean: Evil describes something or someone bad or cruel, not good.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The film was about an evil genius who wanted to control the world.

Vocabulary.mean: An experiment is a test that you do to see what will happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In the second experiment they obtained a very clear result.

Vocabulary.mean: To kill someone or something is to make them die.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bomb killed four soldiers and three civilians.

Vocabulary.mean: A laboratory is a room where a scientist works.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was taken on as a laboratory assistant.

Vocabulary.mean: Laugh is the sound made when someone is happy or a funny thing occurs
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's got a really annoying laugh.

Vocabulary.mean: If a sound is loud, it is strong and very easy to hear.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The music just gets distorted when you play it so loud.

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is nervous, they think something bad will happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's always been nervous around dogs.

Vocabulary.mean: A noise is an unpleasant sound.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The noise out in the street was deafening.

Vocabulary.mean: A project is a type of work that you do for school or a job.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Has she had any experience of managing large projects?

Vocabulary.mean: To scare someone is to make them feel afraid.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sudden noises scare her.

Vocabulary.mean: A secret is something that you do not tell other people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A close couple should have no secrets from each other.

Vocabulary.mean: To shout is to say something loudly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's no need to shout, I can hear you.

Vocabulary.mean: To smell something means to use your nose to sense it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Can you smell something burning?

Vocabulary.mean: If something is terrible, it is very bad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The weather was terrible.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is worse, it is of poorer quality than another thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The conditions they're living in are worse than we thought.

Vocabulary.mean: An alien is a creature from a different world.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The alien came in peace.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are among certain things, they are all around you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I saw a few familiar faces among the crowd.

Vocabulary.mean: A chart is a list of information.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sales chart shows a distinct decline in the past few months.

Vocabulary.mean: A cloud is a group of water drops in the sky.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Dark clouds massed on the horizon.

Vocabulary.mean: To comprehend something is to understand it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I fail to comprehend their attitude.

Vocabulary.mean: To describe is to say or write what someone or something is like.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He described the painting in detail.

Vocabulary.mean: Ever means at any time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Have you ever been to London?

Vocabulary.mean: To fail means you do not succeed in what you try to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If you fail these exams, you can resit them next year.

Vocabulary.mean: Friendly is behaving in a pleasant, kind way toward someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm on friendly terms with my daughter's teacher.

Vocabulary.mean: A grade is a score or mark given to someone’s work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Steve never studies, but he always gets good grades.

Vocabulary.mean: Instead means in place of.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm going to drop yoga and do aerobics instead.

Vocabulary.mean: A library is a place where you go to read books.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The library at school is full of books.

Vocabulary.mean: A planet is a large round thing in space.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They launched a rocket to the planet Venus.

Vocabulary.mean: A report is something students write for school.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. John had trouble writing his report.

Vocabulary.mean: Several is more than two but not many.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I’ve seen
several times.

Vocabulary.mean: To solve something is to find an answer to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've been trying to solve this problem all week, but I still haven't cracked it.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens suddenly, it happens quickly and unexpectedly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I suddenly realized what I'd said, but it was too late.

Vocabulary.mean: To suppose is to guess.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We all supposed him to be German, but in fact he was Swiss.

Vocabulary.mean: The universe is the known or supposed objects in space.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Is there intelligent life elsewhere in the universe?

Vocabulary.mean: To view is to look at something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You can view the sharks from outside the glass tank.

Vocabulary.mean: When a thing is appropriate, it is right or normal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Is this film appropriate for small children?

Vocabulary.mean: To avoid something is to stay away from it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He took a different route which avoids the city centre.

Vocabulary.mean: To behave is to act in a particular way, especially to be good.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They behaved as if nothing had happened.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is calm, they do not get excited or upset.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Now keep calm everyone, the police are on their way.

Vocabulary.mean: Concern is a feeling of worry.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Continued fighting in the city is causing great concern.

Vocabulary.mean: To be content is to be happy and not want more.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He seems fairly content with his life.

Vocabulary.mean: If you expect something to happen, you believe it will happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I expect he'd have left anyway.

Vocabulary.mean: When something happens frequently, it happens often.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They frequently hold conferences at that hotel.

Vocabulary.mean: A habit is a thing that you do often.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's so hard to stop smoking when it's been a lifelong habit.

Vocabulary.mean: To instruct is to teach.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I need someone to instruct me on how to use the computer.

Vocabulary.mean: An issue is an important topic.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We met on several occasions to discuss the issue.

Vocabulary.mean: None means not any of someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We've got five accounts of what happened and none of them agree.

Vocabulary.mean: If a person is patient, they don’t become angry or upset easily.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's very patient with small children.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is positive, it is good.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These measures should have positive effects on exports and employment.

Vocabulary.mean: To punish means to make someone suffer for breaking the rules or laws.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He punished the class by giving them extra work.

Vocabulary.mean: To represent is to speak or act for a person or group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I sent my husband to represent me at the funeral.

Vocabulary.mean: To shake is to move back and forth or up and down quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Turn the bottle upside down and shake it.

Vocabulary.mean: To spread is to move quickly to more places.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fire spread very rapidly because of the strong wind.

Vocabulary.mean: To stroll means to walk slowly and calmly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We could stroll along the beach after dinner.

Vocabulary.mean: A village is a very small town.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's a little fishing village with very narrow streets.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are aware of something, you know about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm very much aware of the problem.

Vocabulary.mean: Badly means in a severe or harmful way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was badly affected by the events in her childhood.

Vocabulary.mean: If something belongs to you, you own it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The red hat belongs to Paul.

Vocabulary.mean: To continue something is to keep doing it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Football's popularity continues to grow.

Vocabulary.mean: An error is something you do wrong.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Your essay is full of spelling errors.

Vocabulary.mean: An experience is something you have seen or done.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The new job will provide you with invaluable experience.

Vocabulary.mean: A field is a big area of land.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The field was planted with citrus trees.

Vocabulary.mean: To hurt is to do something that makes you feel pain.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Emilio hurt his back when he fell off a ladder.

Vocabulary.mean: Judgment is the ability to form opinions or decisions.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have absolute faith in her judgment.

Vocabulary.mean: If something likely happens, it will probably happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Do remind me because I'm likely to forget.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is normal, it is not strange nor surprising to you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Lively behaviour is normal for a four-year-old child.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is rare, you do not see it very often.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The museum is full of rare and precious treasures.

Vocabulary.mean: To relax is to rest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This exercise will help you to relax your neck muscles.

Vocabulary.mean: To request something is to ask for it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her request for time off work was denied.

Vocabulary.mean: To reside means to live somewhere permanently or for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The family resides in Arkansas.

Vocabulary.mean: A result is something that happens because of something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The road has been widened, but the result is just more traffic.

Vocabulary.mean: To roll is to move by turning over and over.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I rolled the wheel along the side of the road back to the car.

Vocabulary.mean: Since is used to talk about a past event still happening now.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Emma went to work in New York a year ago, and we haven't seen her since.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is visible, it can be seen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The farthest landmark visible is about 30 km away.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is wild, it is found in nature.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These herbs grow wild in the area.

Vocabulary.mean: An advantage is something that helps you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The advantage of the plan is its simplicity.

Vocabulary.mean: To cause is to make something happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Smoking can cause respiratory diseases.

Vocabulary.mean: A choice is the act or possibility of picking something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'd prefer not to work but I don't have much choice

Vocabulary.mean: A community is a group of people who live together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's well known in the local community.

Vocabulary.mean: To be dead is to not be alive.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In the autumn I rake up the dead leaves.

Vocabulary.mean: The distance between two things is how far it is between them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The house is only a very short distance from the sea.

Vocabulary.mean: To escape is to run away from something bad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A lion has escaped from its cage.

Vocabulary.mean: If you face a problem, you deal with it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Passengers could face long delays.

Vocabulary.mean: To follow means to go behind someone and go where they go.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A dog followed us home.

Vocabulary.mean: Fright is the feeling of being scared.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I lay in bed shaking with fright.

Vocabulary.mean: A ghost is the spirit of a dead person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A headless ghost walks the castle at night - or so the story goes.

Vocabulary.mean: An individual is one person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Every individual has rights which must never be taken away.

Vocabulary.mean: A pet is an animal that lives with people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Doctors have discovered that keeping a pet can do wonders for your health.

Vocabulary.mean: To reach means to arrive at a place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We won't reach Miami until five or six o'clock.

Vocabulary.mean: To return is to go back to a place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She left South Africa at the age of 15 and has never returned.

Vocabulary.mean: To survive is to stay alive.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These plants cannot survive in very cold conditions.

Vocabulary.mean: To be upset is to be unhappy about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I didn't mean to upset her - it was just a bit of fun.

Vocabulary.mean: A voice is the sound a person makes when they talk or sing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She lowered her voice to a whisper.

Vocabulary.mean: The weather is the condition of the air: hot, rainy, windy, etc.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The weather was good at the start of the week.

Vocabulary.mean: To be wise is to use experience and intelligence to make good choices.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You'd be wise to keep quiet.

Vocabulary.mean: To allow something to happen means to let it happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He took a step backwards to allow her to pass.

Vocabulary.mean: To announce something is to make it known.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company announced a pre-tax loss of three million pounds.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something is beside you, they are next to you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our school was built right beside a river.

Vocabulary.mean: A challenge is something difficult to complete.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. An awesome challenge lies ahead of them.

Vocabulary.mean: To claim means to say that something is true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They claim to have met the president, but I don't believe them.

Vocabulary.mean: The condition of someone or something is the state that they are in.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Thick fog has made driving conditions dangerous.

Vocabulary.mean: To contribute to something means to do something to make it successful
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her family decided to contribute $50,000 to the fund.

Vocabulary.mean: A difference is a way that something is not like other things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's not much difference between the two products.

Vocabulary.mean: To divide something is to make it into smaller parts.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Knead the dough well, then divide it into four pieces.

Vocabulary.mean: An expert is someone who is very good at doing something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's an expert on 15th-century Italian art.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is famous, they are known to many people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Beatles will always be the world's most famous pop group.

Vocabulary.mean: Force is a person’s strength or power.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She slapped his face with unexpected force.

Vocabulary.mean: Harm is hurt or problems caused to someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Modernizing historic buildings can often do more harm than good.

Vocabulary.mean: To lay means to put or place in a horizontal or flat position.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Just lay the suitcase on the bed, would you?

Vocabulary.mean: Peace is a time without war.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The war was followed by a long period of peace and prosperity.

Vocabulary.mean: A prince is the son of a king.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The witch cast a spell on the prince and he turned into a frog.

Vocabulary.mean: To protect someone is to stop them from getting hurt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Surely the function of the law is to protect everyone's rights.

Vocabulary.mean: To sense something is to know about it without being told.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I could just sense that something was wrong.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is sudden, it happens very quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A sudden snowstorm paralysed the city.

Vocabulary.mean: Therefore means for this reason.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are a moral, ethical people and therefore we do not approve of their activities.

Vocabulary.mean: To accept something that is offered is to take it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Do you accept credit cards?

Vocabulary.mean: To arrange things is to put them in the right place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We arranged the chairs in a semicircle.

Vocabulary.mean: To attend something is to go to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. All pupils are expected to attend school assembly.

Vocabulary.mean: To balance something is to keep it from falling.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The flamingos balanced gracefully on one leg.

Vocabulary.mean: A contrast is the sharp difference between two things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I like the contrast of the white trousers with the black jacket.

Vocabulary.mean: To encourage someone is to make them want to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We encourage the victims to talk freely about their experiences.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is familiar to you, you know them well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her name is familiar, but I can't quite call to mind where I've heard it.

Vocabulary.mean: To grab is to take a hold of someone or something suddenly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I just managed to grab hold of Lucy before she fell in the pool.

Vocabulary.mean: To hang something is to keep it above the ground.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We could hang this picture on the wall next to the door.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is huge, it is very big.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A huge cloud of dense smoke stretched across the horizon.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is necessary, you must do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We can always go back to the original plan if necessary.

Vocabulary.mean: A pattern is a way in which something is done or organized.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The pattern of family life has been changing over recent years.

Vocabulary.mean: To propose something is to say that it should be done.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I propose an exchange of contracts at two o'clock.

Vocabulary.mean: A purpose is the reason that you do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I came to Brighton for the express purpose of seeing you.

Vocabulary.mean: To release something is to stop holding it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Highly toxic dioxins were released into the air.

Vocabulary.mean: To require something is to say that it is necessary.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Students at this level require a lot of help.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is single, then there is only one.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He knocked his opponent down with a single blow.

Vocabulary.mean: Success is doing something well that you choose to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The success of our campaign has exceeded our wildest expectations.

Vocabulary.mean: To tear something means to pull it apart.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You need to tear off the top of the packet.

Vocabulary.mean: A theory is an idea about how something works.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has four theories to explain organizational change and development.

Vocabulary.mean: To be against something is to be touching it or opposed to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The rain beat against her face as she struggled through the wind.

Vocabulary.mean: The beach is a sandy or rocky place by the ocean.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The campsite is in a beautiful location next to the beach.

Vocabulary.mean: To damage something is to break it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Smoking is likely to damage your health permanently.

Vocabulary.mean: To discover something is to find it for the first time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Who discovered America?

Vocabulary.mean: An emotion is how you feel.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My mother was overcome with emotion and burst into tears.

Vocabulary.mean: To fix something is to make it work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We must get someone to fix that wheel.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are frank, you are being very honest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There followed a frank exchange of views.

Vocabulary.mean: To identify something is to be able to name it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Even the smallest baby can identify its mother by her voice.

Vocabulary.mean: An island is land in the middle of water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I dream of living on a tropical island.

Vocabulary.mean: The ocean is all of the salt water that surrounds land.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The ship sank slowly to the depths of the ocean.

Vocabulary.mean: Perhaps is used when you say that something could happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We have fruit juice but perhaps you'd like something a little stronger?

Vocabulary.mean: If something is pleasant, you enjoy it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He spent a pleasant afternoon reading a book.

Vocabulary.mean: To prevent something is to stop it from happening.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police seem to be powerless to prevent these attacks.

Vocabulary.mean: A rock is a hard thing in the dirt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There were some large rocks sticking up out of the water.

Vocabulary.mean: To save something is to keep it from being hurt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Many brave men fell in the fight to save the city.

Vocabulary.mean: To step is to walk.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Be careful not to step in the mud.

Vocabulary.mean: Still is used when you say that a situation keeps going on.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm still hungry.

Vocabulary.mean: A taste is the flavor something makes in your mouth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I love the taste of garlic.

Vocabulary.mean: To throw something is to use your hand to make it go through the air.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My friend threw the ball back over the fence.

Vocabulary.mean: A wave is a line of water that moves higher than the rest of the water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A large wave swept away half the sandcastle.

Vocabulary.mean: A benefit is a good thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She studied every evening and reaped the benefit at exam time.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are certain about something, you know it is true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's not certain whether to invest in the property market.

Vocabulary.mean: A chance is an opportunity to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's no chance of us getting there by eight.

Vocabulary.mean: An effect is a change made by something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I worry about the effect that violent movies may have on children.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is essential, it is very important and necessary.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Water is essential for living things.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is far, it is not close.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I could just see Joan on the far side of the room.

Vocabulary.mean: To focus on something is to think about it and pay attention to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Tonight’s programs focus on homelessness.

Vocabulary.mean: The function of something is what it does.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The function of the veins is to carry blood to the heart.

Vocabulary.mean: Grass is the green leaves that cover the ground.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He sat on the grass, strumming his guitar.

Vocabulary.mean: To guard something is to take care of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Soldiers guard the main doors of the embassy.

Vocabulary.mean: The image of something is a picture of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Can you improve the sharpness of the image at all?

Vocabulary.mean: If something is immediate, it happens quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We must make an immediate response.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is primary, it is the most important thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Ozone is the earth's primary filter for ultraviolet radiation.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone feels proud, they are happy about what they have done.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was justifiably proud of his achievements.

Vocabulary.mean: To remain somewhere is to stay there.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The doctor ordered him to remain in bed for a few days.

Vocabulary.mean: To rest is to stop being active while the body gets back its strength.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was told to stay in bed to rest her injured back.

Vocabulary.mean: If two things are separate, they are not together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The art department and the music department are in two separate buildings.

Vocabulary.mean: A site is a place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company hasn't yet chosen the site for the new hospital.

Vocabulary.mean: A tail is a part of an animal’s body, sticking out from its rear or back.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The cat's tail was peeping out from under the bed.

Vocabulary.mean: Trouble is a problem or a difficulty.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She got through her exams without too much trouble.

Vocabulary.mean: Anymore means any longer.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The old hospital isn't used anymore.

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is asleep, they are not awake.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The film was so boring I fell asleep.

Vocabulary.mean: A berry is a small round fruit that grows on certain plants and trees.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Gin is made from juniper berries, isn't it?

Vocabulary.mean: To collect things is to group them together all in one place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She collected stamps when she was younger.

Vocabulary.mean: To compete is to try to be better than someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company has to be able to compete globally.

Vocabulary.mean: A conversation is a talk between people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She fell into a conversation with a man at the bar.

Vocabulary.mean: A creature is any living thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Rainforests are filled with amazing creatures.

Vocabulary.mean: A decision is a choice.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has had to make some very difficult decisions.

Vocabulary.mean: Either is used with “or” to say there are two or more possibilities.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's either a hero or a villain, depending on your point of view.

Vocabulary.mean: A forest is a place with lots of trees and animals.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The campsite is set in the middle of a pine forest.

Vocabulary.mean: The ground is the top part of the Earth that we walk on.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Cracks had appeared in the dry ground.

Vocabulary.mean: To introduce someone or something is to say who they are.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'd like to introduce my son, Mark.

Vocabulary.mean: To marry is to legally become husband and wife.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Men tend to marry later than women.

Vocabulary.mean: To prepare is to get ready for something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She'll prepare the food ahead of time and freeze it.

Vocabulary.mean: To sail is to move a boat on the water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He sailed the dinghy up the river.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is serious, it is bad or unsafe.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Drugs have become a serious problem in a lot of schools.

Vocabulary.mean: To spend is to use time doing something or being somewhere.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I think we need to spend more time together.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is strange, it is not normal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has some very strange ideas about women!

Vocabulary.mean: The truth is a fact or something that is right.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The judge was satisfied that she was telling the truth.

Vocabulary.mean: To wake is to not be sleeping anymore.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Please wake me early tomorrow.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is alone, they are not with another person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He likes being alone in the house.

Vocabulary.mean: An apartment is a set of rooms in a building where people live.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'll give you the keys to my apartment.

Vocabulary.mean: An article is a story in a newspaper or magazine.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The article appeared on the front page of the Guardian.

Vocabulary.mean: An artist is a person who paints, draws, or makes sculptures.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The artist painted this picture using tiny brushstrokes.

Vocabulary.mean: Someone’s attitude is the way they feel and think.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's often very difficult to change people's attitudes.

Vocabulary.mean: To compare means to say how two things are the same and different.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. That seems expensive - have you compared prices in other shops?

Vocabulary.mean: To judge something is to say if it is good or bad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You shouldn't judge people by their external appearances .

Vocabulary.mean: A magazine is a regular publication with news, stories, and articles.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She buys all the latest fashion magazines.

Vocabulary.mean: A material is what is used to make something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Uranium is a radioactive material.

Vocabulary.mean: A meal is a time when food is eaten like breakfast, lunch, or dinner.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. That was the worst meal I've ever eaten.

Vocabulary.mean: A method is the way to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This method of growing tomatoes never fails.

Vocabulary.mean: A neighbor is a person who lives near you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Elie is my next-door neighbor.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is professional, it deals with work that uses special skills.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We're engaging the services of a professional administrator.

Vocabulary.mean: A profit is the extra money you make when you sell something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She makes a big profit from selling waste material to textile companies.

Vocabulary.mean: The quality of something is how good it is.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Their products are of very high quality.

Vocabulary.mean: A shape is a simple form like a square or circle.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our table is oval in shape.

Vocabulary.mean: A space is an empty area.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Is there any space for my clothes in that cupboard?

Vocabulary.mean: Stairs are the things that are used to go up in a building.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Go up the stairs and her office is on the right.

Vocabulary.mean: A symbol is a thing that stands for something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A heart shape is the symbol of love.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is thin, they are not fat.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's so thin yet she eats like a horse.

Vocabulary.mean: Blood is the red liquid in your body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He lost a lot of blood in the accident.

Vocabulary.mean: To burn something is to set it on fire.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This fabric burns very easily, so keep it well away from heat.

Vocabulary.mean: A cell is a small room where a person is locked in.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Brody was locked in a padded cell and forced to wear a straitjacket.

Vocabulary.mean: To contain something is to have it inside.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Try to avoid foods which contain a lot of fat.

Vocabulary.mean: To be correct is to be right.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Your information is correct but you left out one thing.

Vocabulary.mean: A crop is food that a farmer grows.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Wheat is a staple crop for millions of people across the world.

Vocabulary.mean: To demand something is to say strongly that you want it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I demand to see the manager.

Vocabulary.mean: To be equal is to be the same.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He believes that all children are born with equal intelligence.

Vocabulary.mean: To feed is to give food.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Don't forget to feed the catts while I'm away.

Vocabulary.mean: A hole is an opening in something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We dug a hole and planted the tree.

Vocabulary.mean: To increase something is to make it larger or more.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We need to increase public awareness of the disease.

Vocabulary.mean: Long ago, a lord was a man in charge of a town.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is the younger son of a lord.

Vocabulary.mean: To owe is to have to pay or give back something received from another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I owe you a drink for helping me move.

Vocabulary.mean: A position is the way something is placed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The house is in a very exposed position.

Vocabulary.mean: To raise something is to lift it up.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She raised her gun, took aim and fired.

Vocabulary.mean: If a person is responsible, they do the right things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Nurseries are responsible for the children in their care.

Vocabulary.mean: A sight is something interesting to see.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We spent a week in Rome looking at all the sights.

Vocabulary.mean: A spot is a place where something happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This looks like a nice spot for a picnic.

Vocabulary.mean: A structure is a building.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The proposed new office tower is a steel and glass structure 43 storeys high.

Vocabulary.mean: Whole means all of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I spent the whole day cleaning.

Vocabulary.mean: A coach is a person who teaches sports.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our football coach has worked hard to inculcate a team spirit into the players.

Vocabulary.mean: To control something is to make it do what you want.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government is trying to control spending.

Vocabulary.mean: A description of someone or something says what they are like.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Write a description of your favourite beach.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is direct, it goes straight between two places.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Is there a direct train to Edinburgh?

Vocabulary.mean: An exam is a test.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She got very high marks in her biology exam.

Vocabulary.mean: An example of something is a thing that is typical of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This church is a perfect example of medieval architecture.

Vocabulary.mean: A limit is the largest or smallest amount of something that you allow.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We set a time limit of 30 minutes for the test.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is local, it is nearby.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She works on the checkout at the local supermarket.

Vocabulary.mean: Magical describes a quality that makes someone or something special.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We walked home arm-in-arm in the magical moonlight.

Vocabulary.mean: Mail is letters and other things sent to people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She spent the morning reading and answering her mail.

Vocabulary.mean: A novel is a book that tells a story.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She churns out a new bestselling novel every year.

Vocabulary.mean: An outline is the plan for a story or essay.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some novelists start by writing an outline.

Vocabulary.mean: A poet is a person who writes poems.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Robert Burns is Scotland's most venerated poet.

Vocabulary.mean: To print something is to put it onto paper.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Please print your name clearly below your signature.

Vocabulary.mean: A scene is one part of a book or movie.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In the first scene, the camera moves slowly across the room.

Vocabulary.mean: A sheet is a thin flat piece of paper.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I only needed a single sheet of paper to do my homework.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is silly, they show a lack of thought.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It was silly of you to go out in the sun without a hat.

Vocabulary.mean: A store is a place where you can buy things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The store is open for late night shopping on Wednesdays.

Vocabulary.mean: To suffer is to feel pain.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's some comfort to know that he died instantly and didn't suffer.

Vocabulary.mean: Technology is new things made by using science.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Modern technology is amazing, isn't it?

Vocabulary.mean: To go across something is to go to the other side of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We walked across the bridge.

Vocabulary.mean: To breathe means to let air go in and out of your body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. When you breathe out, you expel air from your lungs.

Vocabulary.mean: A characteristic is something that shows what a person or a thing is like
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The male bird displays several characteristics which distinguish him from the female.

Vocabulary.mean: To consume something means to eat or drink it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He consumes huge amounts of bread with every meal.

Vocabulary.mean: To excite someone means to make them happy and interested.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Nothing about my life excites me at present.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is extreme, it is in a large amount or degree.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. People here are living in conditions of extreme poverty.

Vocabulary.mean: Fear is the feeling of being afraid.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I finally mastered my fear of flying.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are fortunate, you are lucky.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You're very fortunate to have found such a nice house.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone happens to do something, they do it by chance.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Did she happen to mention whether she would be coming?

Vocabulary.mean: The length of something is how long it is from one end to the other.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The boat is ten metres in length.

Vocabulary.mean: A mistake is something you do wrong.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She admitted that she had made a mistake.

Vocabulary.mean: To observe something is to watch it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Children learn by observing adults.

Vocabulary.mean: An opportunity is a chance to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Everyone will have an opportunity to comment.

Vocabulary.mean: A prize is something of value that is given to the winner.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's a prize for the fastest three runners in each category.

Vocabulary.mean: A race is a contest to see who is the fastest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If an athlete makes a false start, the race must be restarted.

Vocabulary.mean: To realize is to suddenly understand.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They didn't realize the danger they were in.

Vocabulary.mean: To respond is to give an answer to what someone else said.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. To every question, he responded

Vocabulary.mean: A risk is a chance of something bad happening.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In this business, the risks and the rewards are high.

Vocabulary.mean: To wonder is to ask yourself questions or have a need to know.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. When did he last brush his teeth, she wondered.

Vocabulary.mean: Yet is used to say something has not happened up to now.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We haven't discussed the matter in detail yet.

Vocabulary.mean: An academy is a special type of school.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are many courses taught at the academy that I go to.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ancient, it is very old.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Mr Graham was amazed to find 46 ancient gold coins inside the pot.

Vocabulary.mean: A board is a flat piece of wood.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He advertises his services on the company notice board.

Vocabulary.mean: A century is one hundred years.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Life in the 19th century was very different from what it is now.

Vocabulary.mean: A clue is a fact or object that helps solve a mystery or crime.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Police are still looking for clues in their search for the missing girl.

Vocabulary.mean: A concert is an event where you listen to people play music.

Vocabulary.mean: A county is the largest political division of a state in the US.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Texas is divided into 254 counties.

Vocabulary.mean: A dictionary is a book that tells you what words mean.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. One great advantage of an online dictionary is that it can be constantly expanded.

Vocabulary.mean: To exist is to be real.

Vocabulary.mean: Flat describes something that is level and smooth with no curved parts
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The road ahead was flat and smooth.

Vocabulary.mean: A gentleman is a nice man.

Vocabulary.mean: Hidden means to be not easily noticed or too hard to find.

Vocabulary.mean: Maybe is used to show that something is possible or may be true.

Vocabulary.mean: An officer is a leader in the army.

Vocabulary.mean: A theater is a building where you watch plays, shows, and movies.

Vocabulary.mean: Wealth is a large amount of money.

Vocabulary.mean: To beat someone means to do better than they do.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is bright, it shows a lot of light.

Vocabulary.mean: To celebrate is to do something to show that an event is special.

Vocabulary.mean: To determine means to choose or make a decision.

Vocabulary.mean: To disappear means to go away or not be seen.

Vocabulary.mean: If you talk about something else, you talk about something different.

Vocabulary.mean: To flow is to move easily and continuously in one direction.

Vocabulary.mean: A hill is a round area of land. It is higher than the land around it.

Vocabulary.mean: A level is a point on a scale that measures something.

Vocabulary.mean: A puddle is a pool of liquid on the ground.

Vocabulary.mean: A season is a time of the year: spring, summer, fall or winter.

Vocabulary.mean: To waste means to carelessly use something all up.

Vocabulary.mean: You use whether when you must choose between two things.

Vocabulary.mean: To argue is to angrily speak to someone because you do not agree.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. When two of your best friends argue it puts you in a very awkward position.

Vocabulary.mean: To communicate is to give information by talking, writing, etc.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We can now communicate instantly with people on the other side of the world.

Vocabulary.mean: A crowd is a large group of people.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is fresh, it is new.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We need to take a fresh look at the problem.

Vocabulary.mean: To gather is to collect several things usually from different places.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I went to several libraries to gather information about the plans.

Vocabulary.mean: To indicate means to show, point or make something clear.

Vocabulary.mean: An item is a thing that you buy or sell.

Vocabulary.mean: The price of something is how much it costs.

Vocabulary.mean: A product is something that is made.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company is concentrating on developing new products.

Vocabulary.mean: Property is something that someone owns.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fire resulted in damage to their property.

Vocabulary.mean: To purchase something is to buy it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Tickets must be purchased two weeks in advance.

Vocabulary.mean: To recommend something is to say that someone should do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We recommend changing your internet provider.

Vocabulary.mean: To select something is to choose it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I selected the best staff available.

Vocabulary.mean: A tool is something that helps you do a task.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A hammer is a simple tool.

Vocabulary.mean: To treat is to act in a certain way toward someone.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is alive, they are not dead.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He must be 90 if he's still alive.

Vocabulary.mean: A bone is a hard part of the body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's broken a bone in his wrist.

Vocabulary.mean: The conclusion of something is the final part of it.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. You have to sit the exams, however much you don't feel like doing them.

Vocabulary.mean: To achieve something is to successfully do it after trying hard.
