Vocabulary.mean: To advise someone is to tell them what to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His doctor advised him against smoking.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens already, it happens before a certain time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The concert had already begun by the time we arrived.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is basic, it is very simple or easy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I really need to get some basic financial advice.

Vocabulary.mean: A bit is a small amount of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There were bits of paper all over the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: To consider something means to think about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Don't make any decisions before you've considered the situation.

Vocabulary.mean: To destroy means to damage something so badly that it cannot be used.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A bomb fell on the church and destroyed it.

Vocabulary.mean: To entertain someone is to do something that they enjoy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We hired a magician to entertain the children.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is extra, it is more than what is needed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She waited on tables to earn some extra money.

Vocabulary.mean: A goal is something you work toward.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our goal is for the country to be fully independent within two years.

Vocabulary.mean: To lie is to say or write something untrue to deceive someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I suspect he lies about his age.

Vocabulary.mean: Meat is food made of animals.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The meat produced from a pig is called pork, bacon, or ham.

Vocabulary.mean: An opinion is a thought about a person or a thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. What's your opinion about the matter?

Vocabulary.mean: If something is real, it actually exists.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Was King Arthur a real or a legendary character?

Vocabulary.mean: To reflect is when a surface sends back light, heat, sound or an image.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He saw himself reflected in the water.

Vocabulary.mean: To regard someone or something is to think of them in a certain way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her parents always regarded her as the smartest of their children.

Vocabulary.mean: To serve someone is to give them food or drinks.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They serve pretty decent food in the cafeteria.

Vocabulary.mean: A vegetable is a plant used as food.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We don't have any fresh vegetables, only frozen peas.

Vocabulary.mean: A war is a big fight between two groups of people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The war has claimed thousands of lives.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is worth an amount of money, it costs that amount.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Any painting by Van Gogh is worth a fortune.

Vocabulary.mean: To appear is to seem.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The most important rule in life is always to appear confident.

Vocabulary.mean: The base is the bottom of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The base of the bed was made of slats.

Vocabulary.mean: The brain is the organ in your head that lets you think.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The virus attacks specific cells in the brain.

Vocabulary.mean: A career is a job that you do for a large part of your life.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's hoping for a career in the police force.

Vocabulary.mean: A clerk is a type of worker. Clerks in a store help customers.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Take your purchases to the clerk, and he will wrap them for you.

Vocabulary.mean: Effort is hard work or an attempt to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Ensuring the product is launched on time will be a team effort.

Vocabulary.mean: To enter a place is to go into it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her eyes brightened when she saw him enter the room.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is excellent, it is very good.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The food was excellent.

Vocabulary.mean: A hero is a brave person who does things to help others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. James Bond was a hero of mine when I was a boy.

Vocabulary.mean: To hurry is to do something quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Come on - we're going to be late if you don't hurry!

Vocabulary.mean: To inform someone is to tell them about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She informed her tenants that she was raising the rent.

Vocabulary.mean: Later means after the present, expected, or usual time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She said she would speak to me later.

Vocabulary.mean: To leave means to go away from someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bus leaves (the station) in five minutes.

Vocabulary.mean: To locate something is to find it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Police are still trying to locate the suspect.

Vocabulary.mean: A nurse is a person who helps sick people in the hospital.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The nurse will take your blood pressure in a moment.

Vocabulary.mean: An operation is when a doctor replaces or removes something in the body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. After the operation the wound became infected.

Vocabulary.mean: Pain is the feeling that you have when you are hurt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Aspirin reduces pain and inflammation.

Vocabulary.mean: To refuse something is to say “no” to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He asked me to give him another loan, but I refused.

Vocabulary.mean: Though is used when the second idea makes the first seem surprising.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I enjoyed her new book though it's not quite as good as her last one.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is various, there are many types of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We had various problems on our journey, including a flat tyre.

Vocabulary.mean: Actual means that something is real or true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We expected 50 people, but the actual number was a lot higher.

Vocabulary.mean: To amaze someone is to surprise them very much.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The prices they’re getting for vegetables just amaze me.

Vocabulary.mean: A charge is the price to pay for something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They fixed my watch free of charge.

Vocabulary.mean: To comfort someone means to make them feel better.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The girl's mother was at home today, being comforted by relatives.

Vocabulary.mean: To contact someone is to speak or write to them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She finally made contact with him in Italy.

Vocabulary.mean: A customer is a person who buys something at a store.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The shop is giving away a sample pack to every customer.

Vocabulary.mean: To deliver something is to take it from one place to another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Shops which will deliver goods are thin on the ground these days.

Vocabulary.mean: To earn means to get money for the work you do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. As a personal trainer to the rich and famous, he earns over a million dollars a year.

Vocabulary.mean: A gate is a type of door. Gates are usually made of metal or wood.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. An angry crowd surged through the gates of the president's palace.

Vocabulary.mean: To include something means to have it as part of a group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bill includes tax and service.

Vocabulary.mean: To manage something means to control or be in charge of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There must be a better way to manage our household finances than this!

Vocabulary.mean: A mystery is something that is difficult to understand or explain.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The book tries to explain some of the mysteries of life.

Vocabulary.mean: To occur means to happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Evolution occurs as a result of adaptation to new environments.

Vocabulary.mean: If A is the opposite of B, A is completely different from B.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The two politicians have diametrically opposite points of view.

Vocabulary.mean: A plate is a flat round thing that you put food on.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I gave her a plate of food but she pushed it aside.

Vocabulary.mean: To receive something is to get it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Did you receive my letter?

Vocabulary.mean: A reward is something given in exchange for good behavior or work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's a reward for whoever finishes first.

Vocabulary.mean: To set something is to put it somewhere.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He set a vase of flowers on the table.

Vocabulary.mean: To steal is to take something that is not yours.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Employees who steal are dismissed automatically.

Vocabulary.mean: A thief is someone who quietly takes things that do not belong to them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police believe he is the thief, but all the evidence suggests otherwise .

Vocabulary.mean: To advance is to go forward.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fire advanced steadily through the forest.

Vocabulary.mean: An athlete is a person who plays sports.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is currently considered to be the best British athlete.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is average, it is at a normal level.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The average age of the 'Times' reader is fairly low at 42.

Vocabulary.mean: Your behavior is the way you act.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This approach can help identify common behaviors and their causes.

Vocabulary.mean: Behind means to be at the back of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The guard dog was snarling and snapping behind the fence.

Vocabulary.mean: A course is a class in school.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I did a course in creative writing.

Vocabulary.mean: To lower something is to make it go down.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We lowered the wall to let in more light.

Vocabulary.mean: To match is to be the same or similar.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Does this shirt match these trousers?

Vocabulary.mean: A member is a person who is part of a group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've just become a member of the company's sports and social club.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is mental, it has to do with your mind.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Stress can affect both your physical and mental health.

Vocabulary.mean: A passenger is a person who rides in a car, train, or airplane.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Taxis are allowed to carry no more than four passengers.

Vocabulary.mean: Your personality is what you are like and how you behave.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has a very warm personality.

Vocabulary.mean: A poem is a short kind of writing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He composed this poem for his wife.

Vocabulary.mean: A pole is a long thin stick made of wood or metal that supports things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The vine twines round the pole.

Vocabulary.mean: To remove something is to take it away.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The men came to remove the rubbish from the backyard.

Vocabulary.mean: Safety means to be the condition of being safe and free from danger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The airline is taking steps to ensure safety on its aircraft.

Vocabulary.mean: To shoot is to fire something like a bullet at someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has a licence to shoot pheasants on the farmer's land.

Vocabulary.mean: To sound means to make a noise.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If the alarm sounds, leave the building immediately.

Vocabulary.mean: To swim is to move through water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I used to swim twice a week, but I seem to have got out of the habit recently.

Vocabulary.mean: A web is a home made by a spider.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We watched a spider spin a web between three tall grass stems.

Vocabulary.mean: A block is a solid piece of wood, stone or ice.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The blocks of stone had to be lifted into position with a system of pulleys.

Vocabulary.mean: To cheer is to give a loud shout of approval or encouragement.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The crowd cheered as the goalkeeper deflected the shot.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is complex, it has many small parts. It is hard to understand
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The structure of this protein is particularly complex.

Vocabulary.mean: A critic is someone who give their opinions about movies, books, plays
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The play has been well received by the critics.

Vocabulary.mean: An event is something that happens, especially something important.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This year's Olympic Games will be the biggest ever sporting event.

Vocabulary.mean: To exercise is to run or play sports so that you can be healthy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This exercise is designed to develop the shoulder and back muscles.

Vocabulary.mean: If something fits, it is small enough orthe right size to go there.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. That jacket fits you perfectly.

Vocabulary.mean: Friendship is the relationship between people who are friends.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In every friendship there has to be some give-and-take.

Vocabulary.mean: A guide is someone who shows you where to go.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We had to ask our guide to interpret for us.

Vocabulary.mean: If there is a lack of something, there is not enough of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Hospitals are being forced to close departments because of lack of money.

Vocabulary.mean: A passage is a long area with walls that goes from one place to another
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A narrow passage led directly through the house into the garden.

Vocabulary.mean: To perform is to do something in front of people who watch.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The orchestra is to perform its last ever concert tomorrow night at the Albert Hall.

Vocabulary.mean: Pressure is what you apply to make someone do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Teachers are under increasing pressure to work longer hours.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is probable, it is likely to happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The probable cause of death was heart failure.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is public, it is meant for everyone to use.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His ideas have very little public support.

Vocabulary.mean: To strike someone or something is to hit them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My golf was terrible today - I just didn't strike the ball well.

Vocabulary.mean: To support something is to like it and help it be successful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Many companies support public television very generously.

Vocabulary.mean: A task is work that someone has to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They face the daunting task of rebuilding their economy.

Vocabulary.mean: A term is a word for something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The terms
and
are often interchangeable.

Vocabulary.mean: To unite is to get together to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The thirteen American colonies united to form a new nation.

Vocabulary.mean: To associate means to connect something with a person or thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Most people associate this brand with good quality.

Vocabulary.mean: The environment is the place where people work or live.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It would be better for the environment if more people used bikes rather than cars.

Vocabulary.mean: A factory is a building where things are made or put together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The factory supplies electrical components for cars.

Vocabulary.mean: A feature is an important part of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A unique feature of these rock shelters was that they were dry.

Vocabulary.mean: An instance is an example of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There have been several instances of violence at the school.

Vocabulary.mean: To involve means to be actively taking part in something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I prefer teaching methods that actively involve students in learning.

Vocabulary.mean: Medicine is something you take to feel better or treat an illness.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This medicine is for external use only and should not be taken internally.

Vocabulary.mean: A mix is different things put together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Mash the potatoes and then mix in the butter and herbs.

Vocabulary.mean: To organize is to plan or get ready for an event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They organized a meeting between the students and teachers.

Vocabulary.mean: A period is an amount of time when something happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her time at university was the most eventful period of her life.

Vocabulary.mean: If people populate an area, they live there.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The settlers began to move inland and populate the river valleys.

Vocabulary.mean: To produce something is to make or grow it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Plutonium is a fuel used to produce nuclear energy.

Vocabulary.mean: A range is a number or a set of similar things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This range of clothing is specially designed for shorter women.

Vocabulary.mean: To recognize something is to know it because you have seen it before.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I hadn't seen her for 20 years, but I recognized her immediately.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is regular, it happens often and in equal amounts of time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She goes to her doctor for regular check-ups.

Vocabulary.mean: A sign is a notice giving information, directions, a warning, etc.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sign by the roadworks said 'Slow - heavy plant crossing'.

Vocabulary.mean: A tip is a pointed end of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has a house on the western tip of the island.

Vocabulary.mean: A tradition is something people have been doing for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Fireworks have long been an American tradition on the Fourth of July.

Vocabulary.mean: Trash is waste material or unwanted or worthless things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He threw a valuable drawing out, thinking it was trash.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is wide, it is large from side to side.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bed is too wide - we'll never get it through the door.

Vocabulary.mean: Advice is an opinion about what to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Steven gave me some good advice.

Vocabulary.mean: Along means to move from one part of a road, river, etc. to another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We walked along the beach collecting small crabs in a bucket.

Vocabulary.mean: Attention is the notice, thought, or consideration of someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Pay attention to what she's saying because she won't explain it a second time.

Vocabulary.mean: To attract means to make a person or thing come closer or be intereste
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The tennis championship will attract a lot of tourists to the city.

Vocabulary.mean: To climb means to use your hands and feet to go up on something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We climbed to the top of the hill, where we had a great view.

Vocabulary.mean: To drop is to fall or allow something to fall.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She dropped her cup and it smashed to pieces on the stone floor.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is final, it is the last part.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The recommendation will be sent to the City Council for final approval.

Vocabulary.mean: Further is used to say something is from a distance or time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The wind was pushing the boat further and further out to sea.

Vocabulary.mean: To imply something is to suggest it without saying it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He implied that the error was mine.

Vocabulary.mean: To maintain means to make something stay the same.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You have to maintain a minimum balance in your checking account.

Vocabulary.mean: You use neither to connect two negative statements.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They have two TVs but neither one works.

Vocabulary.mean: Otherwise means different or in another way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Dennis White scored the only goal in an otherwise forgettable match.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is physical, it is related to your body and not your mind.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In his quest for physical perfection, he spends hours in the gym.

Vocabulary.mean: To prove something is to show that it is true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It will be very difficult to prove that they are guilty.

Vocabulary.mean: To react is to act in a certain way because of something that happened.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. How do you think she’ll react when she hears the news?

Vocabulary.mean: To ride something is to travel on it. You can ride an animal, a bike, etc.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I learned to ride a bike when I was six.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is situated somewhere, it is in that place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The school is situated near the park.

Vocabulary.mean: Society is people and the way that they live.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We live in a multicultural society.

Vocabulary.mean: A standard is what people consider normal or good.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This essay is not of an acceptable standard - do it again.

Vocabulary.mean: To suggest something means to give an idea or plan about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I suggested that we should meet, and they agreed .

Vocabulary.mean: Actually means in fact or really.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I didn't actually want any more dessert, but Julia forced it on me .

Vocabulary.mean: Bite is the act of using your teeth to cut and tear into something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. When he bit into his apple, his tooth came out.

Vocabulary.mean: The coast is the land by an ocean.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The boat sailed down the coast.

Vocabulary.mean: A deal is an agreement that you have with another person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our firm could lose a lot of money if the deal is unsuccessful.

Vocabulary.mean: The desert is an area of land without many plants or water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They were lost in the desert for nine days.

Vocabulary.mean: An earthquake is a shaking movement of the ground.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In 1906 an earthquake destroyed much of San Francisco.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is effective, it works well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Yoga is a very effective technique for combating stress.

Vocabulary.mean: To examine something is to look at it carefully.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Don't sign any contract before examining its conditions carefully.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is false, it is not correct.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The news report about the explosion turned out to be false.

Vocabulary.mean: A gift is something you give someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have to get my sister a gift for her birthday.

Vocabulary.mean: Hunger is the feeling that you get when you need to eat.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Hundreds of refugees collapsed from hunger and thirst.

Vocabulary.mean: To imagine something is to think of it in your mind.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Can you imagine how it feels to be blind?

Vocabulary.mean: A journey is a long trip.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was planning a six-week journey to China.

Vocabulary.mean: A puzzle is something that is hard to understand.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Scientists have been trying to solve this puzzle for years.

Vocabulary.mean: Quite is used to say that something is complete or very much.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The two situations are quite different.

Vocabulary.mean: Rather is used when you want to do one thing but not the other.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She wants us to meet her here rather than go to her apartment.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is specific, it is precise or exact.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The report makes specific recommendations.

Vocabulary.mean: A tour is a short trip in which you see many sights.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A bus took us on a sightseeing tour of the city.

Vocabulary.mean: A trip is a journey to a certain place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We're going on a trip to Norway this summer.

Vocabulary.mean: If something has value, it is worth a lot of money.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The value of the painting has been put at £1 million.

Vocabulary.mean: A band is a group of people who play music.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The band played a familiar tune which had everyone clapping along.

Vocabulary.mean: Barely means by the smallest amount, almost not.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The dark line of the mountains was barely visible against the night sky.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is boring, it is not fun.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's boring to sit on the plane with nothing to read.

Vocabulary.mean: To cancel means to decide that an event or a request will not happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They had to cancel tomorrow's game because of the bad weather.

Vocabulary.mean: A driveway is a short private road that leads to a person’s home.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There was a driveway from this court into the street beyond.

Vocabulary.mean: Garbage is waste material like unwanted or spoiled food, bottles, paper, etc.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Don't forget to take out the garbage.

Vocabulary.mean: An instrument is something designed to do a certain task like music.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The trumpet and trombone are brass instruments.

Vocabulary.mean: A list is a record of information printed with an item on each line.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He checked off their names on the list as they got on the coach.

Vocabulary.mean: Magic is the power to do impossible things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She used magic to cure illnesses.

Vocabulary.mean: A message is a set of words that you send to someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She wasn't in so I left a message on her answerphone.

Vocabulary.mean: To notice something is to see it for the first time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I noticed a crack in the ceiling.

Vocabulary.mean: To own something means to have it. That thing belongs to you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They own 20% of the company's stock.

Vocabulary.mean: To predict something is to say that it will happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Astronomers can predict the exact time of an eclipse.

Vocabulary.mean: A professor is a person who teaches in college/university.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's a professor of nutrition at Columbia University.

Vocabulary.mean: To rush is to go somewhere or do something very quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We shouldn't rush to blame them.

Vocabulary.mean: A schedule is a plan that tells you when to do things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The work schedule for this month is posted on the staff bulletin board.

Vocabulary.mean: To share something is to give some of it to another person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I share a house with four other people.

Vocabulary.mean: A stage is a place where actors or musicians act or sing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The show climaxed with all the performers singing on stage together.

Vocabulary.mean: A storm is very bad weather. There is a lot of rain or snow.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A lot of trees came down in the storm.

Vocabulary.mean: You use within to say that something is inside another thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The tickets should reach you within a week.

Vocabulary.mean: To advertise is to tell people about something on TV, radio, etc.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He advertises his business on the Internet.

Vocabulary.mean: To assign something to someone is to tell them to do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We assigned Alberto the task of watching the children.

Vocabulary.mean: An audience is a group of people who watch something together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The audience clapped and cheered when she stood up to speak.

Vocabulary.mean: Breakfast is the first meal of the day.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have toast and marmalade for breakfast.

Vocabulary.mean: A competition is a contest to see who is the best at something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The two companies are in competition with each other.

Vocabulary.mean: If the weather is cool, it is a little bit cold.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. As she dived into the pool, the water felt deliciously cool on her skin.

Vocabulary.mean: If you gain something, you get more of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The rock gains speed as it rolls down the slope.

Vocabulary.mean: Importance means the quality or condition of being needed or valued.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The health report stresses the importance of fresh food in a diet.

Vocabulary.mean: Knowledge is information that you have about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has a limited knowledge of French.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is major, it is big or important.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sugar is a major cause of tooth decay.

Vocabulary.mean: Mean describes someone who is unkind or cruel.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Stop being so mean to your brother!

Vocabulary.mean: If you prefer something, you want it more than something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He prefers watching baseball to playing it.

Vocabulary.mean: A president is the leader of a country.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Boris Yeltsin was Russia's first democratically elected president.

Vocabulary.mean: Progress is the act of getting closer to doing or finishing something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The construction work is already in progress.

Vocabulary.mean: Respect is a good opinion of someone because they are good.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You should show more respect to your parents.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are rich, you have a lot of money.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is determined to get rich quickly.

Vocabulary.mean: A skill is the knowledge and ability that allows you to do something well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This job demands a high degree of skill.

Vocabulary.mean: Somehow means in a way or by some means which is not known.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It won't be easy, but we'll get across the river somehow.

Vocabulary.mean: Strength is the physical power that you have.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Making baskets requires skill more than physical strength.

Vocabulary.mean: To vote is to officially choose between two or more things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Only 40 percent of people bothered to vote in the election.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is above, it is at a higher level than something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's a mirror above the sink.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ahead of something else, it is in front of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The road ahead is very busy.

Vocabulary.mean: An amount is how much there is of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He liked to carry a large amount of money around with him.

Vocabulary.mean: A belief is a strong feeling that something is correct or true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His belief in God gave him hope during difficult times.

Vocabulary.mean: The center of something is the middle of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She stood in the center of the stage.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is common, it happens often or there is much of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. One common cause of homelessness is separation or divorce.

Vocabulary.mean: To cost is to require expenditure or payment.
Vocabulary.example: e.g.

Vocabulary.mean: To demonstrate something is to show how it is done.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He demonstrated how to use the new software.

Vocabulary.mean: Different describes someone or something that is not the same as others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She seems to wear something different every day.

Vocabulary.mean: Evidence is a fact or thing that you use to prove something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The FBI has found no evidence of a crime.

Vocabulary.mean: Honesty means the quality of being truthful or honest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He should be praised for his honesty.

Vocabulary.mean: An idiom is a phrase with a meaning different from its words.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. ‘Let the cat out of the bag’ is an idiom meaning to tell a secret by mistake.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is independent, it is not controlled by something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Now that Jean’s got a job, she’s financially independent

Vocabulary.mean: Inside means the inner part, space or side of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Did you clean the inside of the car?

Vocabulary.mean: A master is a person who is very good at something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Everyone knew he was a master of compromise.

Vocabulary.mean: A memory is something you remember.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Loss of memory is a natural part of old age.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is proper, it is right.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You have to ensure your child receives a proper education.

Vocabulary.mean: To scan something is to look at it very carefully.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She anxiously scanned the faces of the men leaving the train.

Vocabulary.mean: A section is a part of something larger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Most news magazines have a section devoted to external affairs .

Vocabulary.mean: The surface of something is the top part or outside of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The marble has a smooth, shiny surface.

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is anxious, they worry that something bad will happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My mother always gets a bit anxious if we don't arrive when we say we will.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is awful, it is very bad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The weather was awful the whole time – cold and wet.

Vocabulary.mean: To consist of is to be made of parts or things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The crowd consisted mostly of college kids and office workers.

Vocabulary.mean: To desire is to want something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The hotel had everything you could possibly desire.

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is eager about something, they are excited about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sam was eager to get home and play with his new toy.

Vocabulary.mean: A household is all the people who live in one house.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She became part of his household.

Vocabulary.mean: An intent is a plan to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It was not his intent to hurt anyone.

Vocabulary.mean: A landscape is how an area of land looks.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The landscape was sheathed in ice.

Vocabulary.mean: To lift something is to move it higher.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I can’t lift you up – you’re a big boy now!

Vocabulary.mean: To load is to put objects into something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. How long will it take to load this sand onto the lorry?

Vocabulary.mean: A lung is the organ in the body that fills with air when breathing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's a high correlation between smoking and lung cancer.

Vocabulary.mean: A motion is a movement that someone makes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She moved her finger in a circular motion.

Vocabulary.mean: The pace of something is the speed at which it happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He set off running at a furious pace.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is polite, they are acting in a thoughtful way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm afraid I wasn't very polite to her.

Vocabulary.mean: To possess something is to have it or own it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Those states are the countries that possess nuclear weapons.

Vocabulary.mean: When something happens rapidly, it happens very fast.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The wind power industry is expanding rapidly.

Vocabulary.mean: To remark is to say something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She remarked that the award was more than she was expecting.

Vocabulary.mean: To seek is to look for something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I was expelled from school and forced to seek work.

Vocabulary.mean: To shine is to make a bright light.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sun shone directly in my eyes.

Vocabulary.mean: To spill is to have something fall out of its container.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I just spilled gravy on my shirt.

Vocabulary.mean: To bring means to take someone or something to a person or place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Is it okay if I bring a friend to the party?

Vocabulary.mean: A castle is a building with strong walls where royalty usually lives.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We visited an ancient ruined castle overlooking the sea.

Vocabulary.mean: To command someone is to tell them to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The queen commands that you should go to her at once.

Vocabulary.mean: To counsel someone is to listen and give advice about a problem.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police have provided experts to counsel local people affected by the tragedy.

Vocabulary.mean: To ensure is to make certain that something happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The airline is taking steps to ensure safety on its aircraft.

Vocabulary.mean: An explosion is a violent burst, usually with a loud sound.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fire was thought to have been caused by a gas explosion.

Vocabulary.mean: Jewelry is something that people wear like earrings or necklaces.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The nurse asked her to remove all her jewellery.

Vocabulary.mean: To land means to come to the ground usually from a ship or aircraft.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You can land a plane on water in an emergency.

Vocabulary.mean: A meteor is a rock from outer space that falls to Earth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We saw a meteor in the sky last night.

Vocabulary.mean: A monster is any imaginary frightening creature that looks strange.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The movie was about a huge green monster.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is northern, it is in the direction of north.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are reports of widespread flooding in northern France.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is remote, it is very far away and difficult to get to.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Ben grew up in a remote part of Montana.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is southern, it is in the direction of south.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sunbelt stretches from Florida to southern California.

Vocabulary.mean: A statue is an image of a person or animal made of stone or metal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The statue of the dictator was toppled over by the crowds.

Vocabulary.mean: Steam is water that has become hot and has turned into a misty gas.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The steam from the kettle misted up her glasses.

Vocabulary.mean: To submit to someone is to agree to do what they tell you to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She submitted to her mother’s wishes and did her homework.

Vocabulary.mean: A temple is a building that is used for religious purposes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This temple is a place of great holiness for the religion's followers.

Vocabulary.mean: Upper means higher in position or place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our company occupied the three upper floors of the building.

Vocabulary.mean: A weed is a plant, especially one that is not useful or wanted.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The yard was overgrown with weeds.

Vocabulary.mean: A wing is the part of an animal that lets it fly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The poor bird couldn't fly because it had a broken wing.

Vocabulary.mean: An arrow is a thin, straight stick shot from a bow.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Robin Hood asked to be buried where his arrow landed.

Vocabulary.mean: A battle is a fight between two armies during a war.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. During the war, he saw many of his comrades fall in battle.

Vocabulary.mean: A bow is a weapon made of curved wood and string that shoots arrows.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He went hunting with a bow and arrow.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are brave, they are not afraid to face pain or danger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Nelson Mandela is revered for his brave fight against apartheid.

Vocabulary.mean: A chief is the leader of a group of people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A new chief of the security forces has just been appointed.

Vocabulary.mean: A disadvantage is a situation where someone is likely to lose.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's at a disadvantage being so shy.

Vocabulary.mean: An enemy is a country that is fighting another country during a war.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The commandos made a daring raid on the enemy.

Vocabulary.mean: An entrance is a place where someone can enter an area.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are two entrances – one at the front and one at the back of the building.

Vocabulary.mean: If something hardly happens, it almost does not happen at all.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The instructions are printed so small I can hardly read them.

Vocabulary.mean: To intend to do something means to plan to do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've heard that she intends to leave the company.

Vocabulary.mean: Laughter is the sound produced by laughing about something funny.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Raucous laughter came from the next room.

Vocabulary.mean: A log is a thick piece of wood that is cut from a tree.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Stack the logs near the fireplace.

Vocabulary.mean: The military is the armed forces of a country.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The president relied on the coercive powers of the military.

Vocabulary.mean: To obey means to follow what a law or a person says you must do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He hated being in the army because he had to obey commands.

Vocabulary.mean: To secure something means to get it after a lot of effort.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The directors have managed to secure a good deal for the company.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something is steady, they are under control.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You need steady nerves to drive in city traffic.

Vocabulary.mean: To trust is to believe that someone is honest and will do what is right.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My sister warned me not to trust him.

Vocabulary.mean: To twist something is to wrap it around itself or another thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Vines twisted around the trunk of the old tree.

Vocabulary.mean: Unless means if not or except when.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I can't let you in unless you give the password.

Vocabulary.mean: A weapon is an object that can be used to hurt people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was carrying a concealed weapon.

Vocabulary.mean: The chest is the front part of a person’s body under the neck.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's tiny, he doesn't even come up to my chest!

Vocabulary.mean: If you have confidence about something, you are sure of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Consumers’ confidence in the economy is strong.

Vocabulary.mean: A consequence is a result of a choice or action.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This decision could have serious consequences for the industry.

Vocabulary.mean: A disaster is a really bad thing that happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The destruction of the rain forests is an ecological disaster.

Vocabulary.mean: To disturb someone means to upset them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Please don't disturb your sister - she's trying to do her homework.

Vocabulary.mean: To estimate something means to make a guess about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Red Cross officials estimate that 20 000 refugees streamed into the city last week.

Vocabulary.mean: When you honor people or things, you show respect for them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The dinner is in honor of a colleague who is leaving.

Vocabulary.mean: To impress someone means to make that person proud.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He tried to impress his teachers by using big words in all his essays.

Vocabulary.mean: A marathon is a very long foot race just over 42 kilometers.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Running a marathon is a test of human endurance.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is narrow, it is very thin.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The boats all have to pass through this narrow channel.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is pale, it does not have a bright color.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You're looking pale - are you feeling well?

Vocabulary.mean: When something is rough, it is not even or smooth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It was a rough mountain road, full of stones and huge holes.

Vocabulary.mean: To satisfy someone means to make them happy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They have 31 flavours of ice cream - enough to satisfy everyone!

Vocabulary.mean: To scream means to make a loud noise with your mouth.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something is sensitive, they are easily hurt.

Vocabulary.mean: The shade is a dark area that something makes when it blocks the sun.

Vocabulary.mean: To supplement something is to add something else to it in a good way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He supplements his income by working in a bar at night.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone feels terror, they are scared.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was screaming in terror as the flames got closer.

Vocabulary.mean: A threat is something bad that might happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Nuclear weapons pose a threat to everyone.

Vocabulary.mean: A victim is a person that had something bad happen to them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The murderer had lured his victim to a deserted house.

Vocabulary.mean: An ancestor is a family member from the past.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She claims that Mary Queen of Scots is one of her distant ancestors.

Vocabulary.mean: An angle is the direction from which you look at something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The photographer kept moving around to find the best angle for the picture.

Vocabulary.mean: A boot is a heavy shoe that goes over your ankle.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There were big clumps of soil on his boots.

Vocabulary.mean: A border is the edge of an area.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The card has a pretty design around the border.

Vocabulary.mean: To congratulate someone is to tell them that you are happy for them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I must congratulate you - this is a very impressive piece of work.

Vocabulary.mean: A frame is a border for a picture or mirror.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The painting was presented in a gilt picture frame.

Vocabulary.mean: Heaven is the place that some people believe people go when they die.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Beethoven's dying words are said to have been

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is incredible, it is hard to believe they are true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Johnson scored an incredible goal in the match.

Vocabulary.mean: A legend is a story from the past.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The opera is based on an Icelandic legend.

Vocabulary.mean: To praise is to show that you like someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He should be praised for his honesty.

Vocabulary.mean: To proceed is to go in a certain direction.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Passengers for Madrid should proceed to gate 26 for boarding.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is pure, it is very clear and beautiful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was wearing a suit made from pure silk.

Vocabulary.mean: A relative is a family member.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The children are being cared for by a relative.

Vocabulary.mean: If one is senior, they are the oldest or have been there the longest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This is the common room for senior pupils at the school.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is silent, they make no sound.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The empty house was completely silent.

Vocabulary.mean: To sink into something is to slowly fall into it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The boat filled with water and began to sink.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is superior, they are better than another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This is clearly the work of a superior artist.

Vocabulary.mean: To surround something is to close in on it from all sides.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Snow-capped mountains surround the city.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is thick, it is wide and solid.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The roof of the temple was held up by a row of thick stone columns.

Vocabulary.mean: To wrap is to cover something on all sides.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If you wrap yourself in this blanket, you will stay warm.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone goes or travels abroad, they go to another country.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We always go abroad in the summer.

Vocabulary.mean: To anger someone is to make them mad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It always angers me to see so much waste.

Vocabulary.mean: A bride is a woman who is getting married or has just gotten married.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bride and groom posed for pictures outside the church.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is brief, it only lasts for a short time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Rory had a brief career as an actor.

Vocabulary.mean: To chase someone or something is to follow them in order to catch them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It was plucky of you to chase after the burglar.

Vocabulary.mean: To disappoint is to make one feel sad or unsatisfied.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We don't want to disappoint the fans.

Vocabulary.mean: A favor is something you do for someone to help them.

Vocabulary.mean: A fee is an amount of money that a person or company asks for a service.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We couldn't pay the lawyer's fee.

Vocabulary.mean: If something lasts forever, it means it lasts for all time.
