Vocabulary.mean: A guy is an informal way to call a man.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's a really nice guy.

Vocabulary.mean: If people or things are lovely, they are good or beautiful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You look lovely in that dress.

Vocabulary.mean: A mood is the way someone is feeling.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her mood seemed to change during the course of the conversation.

Vocabulary.mean: A palace is a very large building. It is often the home of a royal family.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This magnificent palace took over 20 years to complete.

Vocabulary.mean: To permit something is to let someone do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Smoking is not permitted anywhere in this theatre.

Vocabulary.mean: To protest something is to argue about it with someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We protested about the changes for a long time, but in the end we had to submit.

Vocabulary.mean: A sculpture is a piece of art that is made from wood, clay, or stone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This sculpture must be centuries old.

Vocabulary.mean: A tribe is a group of people who live in the same culture.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They met a tribe of Somalian desert nomads.

Vocabulary.mean: Youth is a time in people’s lives when they are young.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I was a fairly good football player in my youth.

Vocabulary.mean: To do something on time’s basis is how often you do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Mostly people work on a part-time basis.

Vocabulary.mean: Biology is the study of living things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She studied biology at university.

Vocabulary.mean: A cage is something that holds an animal so it cannot leave.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The monkeys bunched together in their cage.

Vocabulary.mean: A colleague is somebody you work with.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her work is highly esteemed by all her colleagues.

Vocabulary.mean: A colony is a country controlled by another country.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. India was a British colony.

Vocabulary.mean: To debate is to seriously discuss something with someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Education is the current focus of public debate.

Vocabulary.mean: To depart is to leave some place so you can go to another place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The last flight to Cleveland departs at 8 p.m.

Vocabulary.mean: To depress someone is to make them sad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This weather depresses me.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is factual, it is true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The essay contains a number of factual errors.

Vocabulary.mean: To fascinate someone is to make them really like something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The children were fascinated by the story.

Vocabulary.mean: A mission is an important job that is sometimes far away.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They were sent on a secret political mission to the Middle East.

Vocabulary.mean: You use nevertheless to show that something goes against a fact.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I knew a lot about the subject already, but her talk was interesting nevertheless.

Vocabulary.mean: An occupation is a person’s job.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He listed his occupation on the form as

Vocabulary.mean: If you go overseas, you go to a country on the other side of an ocean.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are a lot of overseas students studying at our college.

Vocabulary.mean: To persuade someone is to make them agree to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She used her womanly charms to persuade him to change his mind.

Vocabulary.mean: A route is the way you go from one place to another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The route we had planned took us right across Greece.

Vocabulary.mean: Ruins are old buildings that are not used anymore.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I visited the ruins of the ancient city of Carthage

Vocabulary.mean: A scholar is a person who studies something and knows much about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The theory has been widely discredited by scholars.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something is significant, they are important.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Is there any significant difference in quality between these two items?

Vocabulary.mean: A volcano is a mountain with a hole on top where hot liquid comes out.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Lava from the volcano was flowing down the hillside.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is broad, it is wide.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We walked down a broad avenue lined with trees.

Vocabulary.mean: A bush is a plant with many thin branches. It is smallerthan a tree.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She saw him coming and crouched down behind a bush.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is capable of something, they can do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These new bullets are capable of inflicting massive injuries.

Vocabulary.mean: To cheat is to be dishonest so that you can win or do well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She cheated in the test by copying from the boy in front.

Vocabulary.mean: To concentrate on someone or something is to give your full attention.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Just try to concentrate on hitting the ball.

Vocabulary.mean: To conclude is to arrive at a logical end by looking at evidence.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I saw crumbs on my dog’s face, so I concluded that he ate my cookie.

Vocabulary.mean: Confident means that one believes they can do something without failing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His confident leadership inspired his followers.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is considerable, it is large in size, amount or extent.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He exhibited considerable skill in driving through the snowstorm.

Vocabulary.mean: To convey is to communicate or make ideas known.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. What the book does convey very successfully is the horror of war.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is definite, it is certain or sure to be true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We need a definite answer by tomorrow.

Vocabulary.mean: Delight is a feeling of being very happy with something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His music teacher expressed delight with his performance.

Vocabulary.mean: A destination is the place where someone or something is going to.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's the good weather that makes Spain such a popular tourist destination.

Vocabulary.mean: To dictate something is to read it aloud so it can be written down.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He dictated a letter to his assistant.

Vocabulary.mean: The edge of something is the part of it that is farthest from the center.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He put pink icing around the edge of the cake.

Vocabulary.mean: A path is a way from one place to another that people can walk along.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. When you reach a fork in the road take the right-hand path.

Vocabulary.mean: To resort to something is to depend on it in order to solve a problem.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I hope they don’t resort to violence to end the argument.

Vocabulary.mean: A shadow is the dark area that is made when something blocks light.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sun shone through the leaves, casting shadows on the lawn.

Vocabulary.mean: To succeed is to complete something that you planned or tried to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has the drive to succeed.

Vocabulary.mean: To suspect something is to believe that it is true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I suspect he cheats the taxman.

Vocabulary.mean: A valley is a low area of land between two mountains or hills.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. People have lived in this valley since ancient times.

Vocabulary.mean: To admire someone is to like them for what they do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I admire her forthright way of dealing with people.

Vocabulary.mean: To aid someone is to help them when they need something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Doctors hoped that moving to a warmer climate would aid his recovery.

Vocabulary.mean: To attempt something is to try to do that thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He attempted to escape through a window.

Vocabulary.mean: Authority is the power that someone has because of their position.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police have no legal authority in these disputes.

Vocabulary.mean: A capital is an important city where a country’s leaders live and work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Australia's capital city is Canberra.

Vocabulary.mean: To cooperate is to work together to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Local residents refused to cooperate with the police.

Vocabulary.mean: To defend someone or something is to protect them from attack.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. White blood cells help defend the body against infection.

Vocabulary.mean: Destruction is damage to something so bad that it can’t be fixed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The destruction of the rain forests is an ecological disaster.

Vocabulary.mean: Disorder is a lack of order, or a complete mess.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The room was in such disorder that she couldn’t find anything.

Vocabulary.mean: A division is the act of making smaller groups out of a larger one.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The electronics division was split off into a freestanding company.

Vocabulary.mean: To enable a person is to make it possible for them to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Only good team work will enable us to get the job done on time.

Vocabulary.mean: To frustrate is to prevent someone from fulfilling their desire.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He tried to frustrate his political opponents by denying them access to the media.

Vocabulary.mean: To govern is to control the public business of a country, state, or city.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was chosen to govern the colony by the British government.

Vocabulary.mean: To have plenty of something is to have more than you need.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If you have a fever you should drink plenty of fluids.

Vocabulary.mean: To relieve someone is to make them feel less pain.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was given a shot of morphine to relieve the pain.

Vocabulary.mean: Reputation is the opinion that people have about someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company has a worldwide reputation for quality.

Vocabulary.mean: Royal describes something that belongs to a king or queen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Few of the Western democracies still have a royal family.

Vocabulary.mean: A slave is a person who is not free and must work for someone else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Slaves were treated with sickening cruelty.

Vocabulary.mean: To struggle is to fight against someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He struggled with his attacker who then ran away.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is stupid, they lack intelligence.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was really stupid to quit her job like that.

Vocabulary.mean: A citizen is someone who lives in a certain town or city.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He applied to become an American citizen.

Vocabulary.mean: A council is a group of people who run a city or town.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The local council has decreed that the hospital should close.

Vocabulary.mean: To declare is to say something officially.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I declare that is the best chocolate cake I’ve ever eaten!

Vocabulary.mean: When people or things are enormous, they are very large.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They cut enormous blocks of stone out of the hillside.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something are extraordinary, they are amazing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He told the extraordinary story of his escape.

Vocabulary.mean: Fog is a thick cloud that is near the ground or water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fog is expected to have cleared away by midday.

Vocabulary.mean: A funeral is a ceremony that takes place after a person dies.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The funeral will be held next Friday.

Vocabulary.mean: When people or things are giant, they are very big.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The volcano spewed a giant cloud of ash, dust, and gases into the air.

Vocabulary.mean: An impression is the way of thinking about someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My general impression of the place was good.

Vocabulary.mean: Income is how much money a person or business makes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Average incomes have risen by 4.5 percent over the past year.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is mad, they are angry.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's always complaining and it makes me so mad.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone ought to do something, then it is the right thing to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He ought to be home by seven o’clock.

Vocabulary.mean: To resist something is to fight against it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. General Rattigan summoned reinforcements to help resist the attack.

Vocabulary.mean: To reveal is to show something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The journalist refused to reveal her sources.

Vocabulary.mean: To rid is to make a place free from something or someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In the city, it is hard to rid a building permanently of pests.

Vocabulary.mean: A sword is a long sharp weapon.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They used to use swords in battles in ancient times.

Vocabulary.mean: A tale is a story.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He told some fascinating tales about his life in India.

Vocabulary.mean: To trap people or animals is to capture them so they cannot get away.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She went to the aid of a man trapped in his car.

Vocabulary.mean: A trial is the way a court discovers if a person is guilty or innocent.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The terrorists were put on trial six years after the bombing.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are violent, they want to hurt someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some scenes are violent and may disturb younger viewers.

Vocabulary.mean: Admission is the act of allowing to enter a place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The club refuses admission to those under 18.

Vocabulary.mean: Astronomy is the study of the stars and planets.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've always had an interest in astronomy.

Vocabulary.mean: To blame someone for something bad is to say they did it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's tempting to blame the internet for the increase in crime.

Vocabulary.mean: Chemistry is the study of and reaction to substances.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Marie Curie was the woman behind enormous changes in the science of chemistry.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens despite what you do, it happens anyway.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The game continued despite the rain.

Vocabulary.mean: A dinosaur is a very big animal that lived millions of years ago.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. here were many types of dinosaurs, some of which were very large.

Vocabulary.mean: An exhibit is a display of interesting things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Let's go see the new dinosaur exhibit.

Vocabulary.mean: Fame is reputation one has gained among the public.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has spent her life running after fame and fortune.

Vocabulary.mean: A forecast is an idea about what the weather will be like in the future.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The forecast said it was going to be hot and sunny tomorrow.

Vocabulary.mean: A genius is a very smart person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Steve can solve anything - the man's a genius.

Vocabulary.mean: Someone who is gentle is kind and calm.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's very gentle with his kids.

Vocabulary.mean: Geography is the study of where things are.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My favourite subjects at school were history and geography.

Vocabulary.mean: To interfere is to cause problems and keep something from happening.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was resentful of anybody's attempts to interfere in her work.

Vocabulary.mean: To do something lightly is to not push very hard.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She patted him lightly on the shoulder.

Vocabulary.mean: A principal is a person in charge of a school.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My school’s principal can be very strict with the rules.

Vocabulary.mean: A row is a line of things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The roof of the temple was held up by a row of thick stone columns.

Vocabulary.mean: A shelf is a place on a wall where you put things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've put the cake on a high shelf where he can't get at it.

Vocabulary.mean: If you do something out of spite, you want to be mean.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He let the air out of your tires just for spite.

Vocabulary.mean: Super means really good.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Natural History Museum is a super place for kids.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is wet, it has water on it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The wood was wet and would not burn.

Vocabulary.mean: To abuse someone or something means to hurt them on purpose.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She claimed to have been a victim of child abuse .

Vocabulary.mean: To afford something means you have enough money to pay for it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I don't know how he can afford a new car on his salary.

Vocabulary.mean: To bake means to cook food with heat.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Kelly's mom always used to bake the best cookies.

Vocabulary.mean: A bean is a plant seed that is good to eat.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The villagers cultivate mostly maize and beans.

Vocabulary.mean: A candle is a stick of wax that is lit on fire for light or heat.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She watched the wax as it dripped down the side of the candle.

Vocabulary.mean: To convert something means to change it into something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Could we convert the small bedroom into a second bathroom?

Vocabulary.mean: A debt is an amount of money that a person owes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The national debt stands at 55 billion dollars.

Vocabulary.mean: To decrease something is to make it less than it was before.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Car sales decreased sharply this year.

Vocabulary.mean: A fault is a mistake.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's not my fault she didn't come!

Vocabulary.mean: A fund is an amount of money that people have.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her family have contributed £50, 000 to the fund.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is generous, they like to give things to people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. John Herschel was an urbane, kindly and generous man.

Vocabulary.mean: An ingredient is something that is part of a food dish.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You mix all the dry ingredients together before you add the milk.

Vocabulary.mean: To insist means to be firm in telling people what to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The men at City Hall insist that big spending cuts are just not practical.

Vocabulary.mean: A mess is a condition that is not clean or neat.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He makes a terrible mess when he's cooking.

Vocabulary.mean: Metal is a strong material people use to build things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Silver, gold, and platinum are precious metals.

Vocabulary.mean: To monitor people or things is to watch them closely.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They hired an accountant to help monitor cash flow.

Vocabulary.mean: To oppose something means to dislike it or act against it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Most of the local residents opposed the closing of the school.

Vocabulary.mean: If a person is passive, they do not take action to solve problems.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's very passive in the relationship.

Vocabulary.mean: A quantity is a certain amount of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She served each of us a vast quantity of spaghetti.

Vocabulary.mean: To sue someone is to take them to court for something wrong they did.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She threatened to sue the magazine for libel.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone has anxiety, they have a lot of worries and fear.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Children normally feel a lot of anxiety about their first day at school.

Vocabulary.mean: An army is a large group of people who fight in wars.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He served in the army in India for 20 years.

Vocabulary.mean: A billion is a very large number: 1,000,000,000.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The population of China is over one billion.

Vocabulary.mean: To carve means to cut into something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There were three large figures carved out of the rock.

Vocabulary.mean: To consult someone means to ask them for help.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'll have to consult my colleagues about the proposed changes.

Vocabulary.mean: An emergency is a time when someone needs help right away.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In an emergency, dial 911 for an ambulance.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone has good fortune, it means they have luck.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have had the good fortune to work with some brilliant directors.

Vocabulary.mean: To guarantee means to know something will happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I can guarantee that you will enjoy the film.

Vocabulary.mean: To hike means to walk in the mountains or forest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We plan to hike from lake to lake.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is initial, it is the first thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She failed her driving test on the initial try, but passed the next time.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is intense, it is very strong.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The President is under intense pressure to resign.

Vocabulary.mean: To lend something is to give it to someone for a short time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. All right, I'll lend you the money.

Vocabulary.mean: The peak is the very top of a mountain.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Ben Nevis is Scotland's highest peak.

Vocabulary.mean: Potential means capable of being but not yet in existence.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A number of potential buyers have expressed interest in the company.

Vocabulary.mean: When you have pride, you are happy with yourself.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We take pride in the high quality of our food.

Vocabulary.mean: Proof is a fact that shows something is real.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police have no definitive proof of her guilt.

Vocabulary.mean: To quit something means to stop doing it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I don't know why she quit her job.

Vocabulary.mean: To spin is to turn around in circles.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The earth spins on its axis.

Vocabulary.mean: When people or things are tiny, they are very small.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The glass shattered into a thousand tiny pieces.

Vocabulary.mean: A tutor is someone who gives lessons in a certain subject.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His parents got him a tutor to help with his maths.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is apparent, it is easy to see.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her unhappiness was apparent to everyone.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are blind, they cannot see.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Labradors are used as guide dogs for blind people.

Vocabulary.mean: To calculate is to find an answer using math.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We tried to calculate how fast he was moving when the car crashed.

Vocabulary.mean: To chat is to talk with someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We stopped to chat with the neighbors.

Vocabulary.mean: To commit to something is to promise to do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Can you commit to a firm date for the building work?

Vocabulary.mean: To compose something is to make it from smaller parts.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Ten men compose the committee.

Vocabulary.mean: A dormitory is a school building where students live.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I will move into the dormitory at the beginning of the school year.

Vocabulary.mean: To exhaust someone is to make them tired.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The long journey exhausted the children.

Vocabulary.mean: A greenhouse is a small glass building that is used to grow plants.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Gladys grows a lot of tomatoes in her greenhouse.

Vocabulary.mean: To ignore something is to act like you do not see or hear it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She can be really irritating but I try to ignore her.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is obvious, it is clear and easily seen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They have a small child so for obvious reasons they need money.

Vocabulary.mean: Physics is a science that deals with energy and how it affects things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Newton's discoveries revolutionized physics.

Vocabulary.mean: A portion of something is a part of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She donated a sizeable portion of her riches to children's charities.

Vocabulary.mean: To remind someone is to tell them to remember to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Remind me to take this into work for Tony tomorrow.

Vocabulary.mean: A secretary is a person who works in an office.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My secretary will phone you to arrange a meeting.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is severe, it is very bad or serious.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In parts of Africa there is a severe food shortage.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone has a talent, they are naturally able to do it well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her talent for music showed at an early age.

Vocabulary.mean: A thesis is an idea that needs to be proved.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His thesis was that World War I could have been avoided.

Vocabulary.mean: A uniform is a piece of clothing worn by people of the same group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I never wear grey because it reminds me of my school uniform.

Vocabulary.mean: Vision is the act of seeing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has very little vision in her left eye.

Vocabulary.mean: To absorb a liquid means to take it inside.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Plants absorb carbon dioxide.

Vocabulary.mean: A boss is a person in charge of other people at work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was the boss of a large international company.

Vocabulary.mean: A committee is a group of people who meet together to make decisions.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The finance committee controls the school's budget.

Vocabulary.mean: A contract is a written agreement between two people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The contract between the two companies will expire at the end of the year.

Vocabulary.mean: A crew is a group of workers.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Jack worked on a road-repair crew.

Vocabulary.mean: To devote time to something means to spend a lot of time doing it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He devoted his life to serving his family, friends, and neighbors.

Vocabulary.mean: To dig is to make a hole in the ground.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The ground was frozen hard and was impossible to dig.

Vocabulary.mean: To dine means to eat dinner.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We dined by candlelight.

Vocabulary.mean: To donate is to give something to a charity or organization.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some businesses have agreed to donate computers to schools.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is double, it is twice as much, or twice as many.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The cost of going to the movies is almost double what it was a few years ago.

Vocabulary.mean: To elevate something is to put it at a higher level.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They hoped to elevate the position of women in society.

Vocabulary.mean: A flavor is the taste of food or drinks.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We sell many different flavors of ice cream.

Vocabulary.mean: A foundation is a group that provides money for research.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He applied for a grant from the Rowntree Foundation.

Vocabulary.mean: A generation is a group of people who live at the same time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The younger generation smokes less than their parents did.

Vocabulary.mean: A handle is the part of an object people hold while using it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The handle on this door is rather stiff.

Vocabulary.mean: A layer covers over something or is between two things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A thick layer of dust had accumulated in the room.

Vocabulary.mean: Mud is soft, wet dirt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The car got stuck in the mud.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is smooth, it has no bumps.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The chocolate mousse was smooth and creamy.

Vocabulary.mean: Soil is the top layer of land on the Earth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The soil in this area is very chalky.

Vocabulary.mean: If people or things are unique, they are not like the others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Fingerprints are unique to every individual.

Vocabulary.mean: A chamber is an old word for a bedroom.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Lady Eleanor was found dead in her chamber.

Vocabulary.mean: To deny something is to say it is not true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Neil denies that he broke the window, but I'm sure he did.

Vocabulary.mean: A document is an official piece of writing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've lost a file containing a lot of important documents.

Vocabulary.mean: To emphasize is to give importance or attention to something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He emphasized how important diet was to health.

Vocabulary.mean: A fever is a high body temperature that people get when they are sick.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Both viruses cause fever and loss of appetite.

Vocabulary.mean: The flu is a type of sickness that makes you feel weak or your body hurt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's very hot and shivery, so I think she must have flu.

Vocabulary.mean: To freeze is to become very cold.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Water freezes to ice at a temperature of 0°C.

Vocabulary.mean: A gesture is a movement of the hands or body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She made a rude gesture at the other driver.

Vocabulary.mean: To interrupt is to briefly stop someone when they are doing something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Please don’t interrupt until I’m finished.

Vocabulary.mean: To last is to continue or go on for an amount of time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They say the snow will last until the end of next week.

Vocabulary.mean: Likeness means the state of being like, or resemblance.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sandy bears a much stronger likeness to her mother than to her father.

Vocabulary.mean: Moreover means besides or in addition to something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It was a good car and, moreover, the price was quite reasonable.

Vocabulary.mean: A perspective is the way you think about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He brings a new perspective to the job.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is rational, it is normal or practical.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has a very rational way of looking at things.

Vocabulary.mean: To recover is to go back to normal after something bad happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It took a long time for the economy to recover after the slump.

Vocabulary.mean: To rely on something or someone is to trust or depend on them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The system relies too heavily on one person.

Vocabulary.mean: To shock people is to surprise them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her painting might shock viewers.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are shy, they are nervous around people strange to them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was too shy to ask her to dance with him.

Vocabulary.mean: To stare at something is to look at it for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Don't stare at people like that, it's rude.

Vocabulary.mean: Thus means as a result or for that reason.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This plan will reduce waste, and thus cut costs.

Vocabulary.mean: An aim is a goal someone wants to make happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My main aim in life is to be a good husband and father.

Vocabulary.mean: To attach is to put two things together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I attached a photo to my application form.

Vocabulary.mean: To bet is to risk money on the result of a game or a business.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I bet you can't guess how old he is.

Vocabulary.mean: A carriage is a vehicle pulled by a horse.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Queen's carriage headed the procession.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is classic, it is typical.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's a classic example of a kid who's clever but lazy.

Vocabulary.mean: To commute is to travel a long distance to get to work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She commutes to the city by car every day.

Vocabulary.mean: To confirm is to make sure something is correct.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Please confirm your reservation in writing by Friday.

Vocabulary.mean: To criticize is to say you do not like someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It’s a lot easier to criticize a plan than to offer useful suggestions.

Vocabulary.mean: To differ is to not be the same as another person or thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His views differ considerably from those of his parents.

Vocabulary.mean: An expense is the money that people spend on something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The house was redecorated at great expense.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is formal, it is done in an official way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They wanted to make a formal complaint about their doctor.

Vocabulary.mean: Height is how tall someone or something is.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My little brother is only half my height.

Vocabulary.mean: To invent something is to create something that never existed before.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I wish someone would invent an everlasting light bulb.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is junior in their job, they do not have a lot of power.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The matter is being dealt with by a junior member of staff.

Vocabulary.mean: Labor is the act of doing or making something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The price will include the labor and materials.

Vocabulary.mean: A mechanic is someone who fixes vehicles or machines.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I applied for a job as a mechanic in a local garage, but I was rejected .

Vocabulary.mean: If something is prime, it is the most important one.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her prime objective now is simply to stay in power.

Vocabulary.mean: To shift to something is to move into a new place or direction.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The wind is expected to shift to the east tomorrow.

Vocabulary.mean: A signal is a sound or action that tells someone to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fireworks were a signal that the festival had started.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are sincere, they tell the truth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He seemed sincere enough when he said he wanted to help.

Vocabulary.mean: Ability is the quality of a person being able to do something well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Everyone has the right to good medical care regardless of their ability to pay.

Vocabulary.mean: Agriculture is the growing of food and animals.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Tourism has replaced agriculture as the nation's main industry.

Vocabulary.mean: A cartoon is a funny drawing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's the creator of a successful cartoon series.

Vocabulary.mean: The ceiling is the top of a room.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The ceiling was embellished with flowers and leaves.

Vocabulary.mean: To convince someone means to make them sure of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We tried to convince my grandfather to live with us.

Vocabulary.mean: When you are curious about something, you want to know more about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I was curious to know what would happen next.

Vocabulary.mean: To delay means to wait to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He wants to delay the meeting until Wednesday.

Vocabulary.mean: A diary is a book in which people write their personal experiences.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The following is an extract from her diary.

Vocabulary.mean: An element of something is a particular part of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Of course, advertising on the internet is an important element of the campaign.

Vocabulary.mean: When people have faith in something, they believe in it and trust it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have faith that she will do the right thing.

Vocabulary.mean: Grain is food crops such as wheat, corn, rice or oats.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Grain is one of the main exports of the American Midwest.

Vocabulary.mean: To greet someone means to meet and welcome them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She ran excitedly down the hall to greet her cousins.

Vocabulary.mean: To investigate means to search for something or learn about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Scotland Yard have been called in to investigate the murder.

Vocabulary.mean: Joy is a feeling you get when you are really happy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They were filled with joy when their first child was born.

Vocabulary.mean: A label is a tag that tells about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Washing instructions should be on the label.

Vocabulary.mean: A monk is a religious person who lives a simple life.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The monks knew a lot about religion.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is odd, it is unusual.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I had a very odd dream about you last night.

Vocabulary.mean: To pause means to stop doing something for a while.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He paused for a moment to listen and then continued eating.

Vocabulary.mean: A priest is a person trained to perform religious duties.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Father O'Dooley was ordained a priest in 1949.

Vocabulary.mean: A profession is a person’s job.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He left the teaching profession in 1965 to start his own business.

Vocabulary.mean: To adopt someone is to make them as a part of one’s own family.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They've adopted a baby girl.

Vocabulary.mean: To beg is to ask for something one really wants.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He went down on his knees and begged for forgiveness.

Vocabulary.mean: If A is beyond B, A is farther away.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Beyond the river was a small town.

Vocabulary.mean: A costume is a set of clothes people wear for a particular occasion.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The children were wearing traditional national costume.

Vocabulary.mean: To exclaim is to say something loudly, usually due to being excited.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She exclaimed with delight when she saw the lion.

Vocabulary.mean: To extend is to stretch out or reach.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The meeting extended into the late hours of the night.

Vocabulary.mean: A fool is someone who makes unwise choices.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I felt like a fool when I realized my mistake.

Vocabulary.mean: To forbid is to tell someone they cannot do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You can’t forbid me to go home.

Vocabulary.mean: To illustrate is to show something by drawing a picture.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The exhibition will illustrate how life evolved from water.

Vocabulary.mean: Indeed means truly or really.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If he has indeed quit his job, why is he still here?

Vocabulary.mean: To interpret is to explain what something means.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. How do you interpret this passage of the poem?

Vocabulary.mean: If people do something kindly, they do it in a nice way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Stella has very kindly offered to help out with the food for the party.

Vocabulary.mean: A motive is the reason someone does something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Does he have a motive for lying about where he was?

Vocabulary.mean: A nest is a place where a bird lays its eggs.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The cuckoo lays her egg in another bird's nest.

Vocabulary.mean: The origin of someone or something is where they come from.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He studied the origin and development of the nervous system.

Vocabulary.mean: A reception is a party to welcome a person or celebrate an event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The president gave a reception for the visiting heads of state.

Vocabulary.mean: To reject is to refuse something because you do not want it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The school rejects a third of all applicants.

Vocabulary.mean: Silence is complete quiet.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In the silence of the night, a lone wolf howled.

Vocabulary.mean: A stream is a small river.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The stream was quite shallow so we were able to walk across it.

Vocabulary.mean: Tone is the sound of someone’s voice. It shows how they feel.
Vocabulary.example: e.g.
he said in a respectful tone of voice.

Vocabulary.mean: To accomplish something means to finish it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He believes you can accomplish a lot in a relatively short space of time.

Vocabulary.mean: To approve of something means you like it or are happy about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You may not approve of what he did, but he's still your brother.

Vocabulary.mean: Approximate means to be close to an exact amount, number or time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The approximate cost of this product will be about $1600.

Vocabulary.mean: A barrier is something that prevents someone from doing something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Despite the language barrier , they soon became good friends.

Vocabulary.mean: To detect something means to notice or find something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Radar equipment is used to detect enemy aircraft.

Vocabulary.mean: A duty is something that a person has to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The duty of the agency is to act in the best interests of the child.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is elementary, it is the first or most simple thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have an elementary knowledge of physics.

Vocabulary.mean: A failure happens when you do not do something right.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Another crop failure could result in widespread famine.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is gradual, it happens slowly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has suffered a gradual decline in health over the past year.

Vocabulary.mean: An immigrant is a person who moves to a different country.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My grandfather arrived here as immigrant from Canada in 1920.

Vocabulary.mean: To insert something means to put it in something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Insert your ATM card in the slot to begin your transaction.

Vocabulary.mean: An instant is a very short amount of time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. At that instant, someone knocked on the door.

Vocabulary.mean: Poverty is the state of being poor.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The problem of poverty is particularly acute in rural areas.

Vocabulary.mean: To pretend means to make believe something is real.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We pretended that nothing had happened.

Vocabulary.mean: A person’s rank is their place in an order of people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You get more privileges if you have a higher rank.

Vocabulary.mean: Recognition is getting praise from other people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Ella complained that the company never gave her any recognition for her work.

Vocabulary.mean: To refrigerate something means to make it cold.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Refrigerate the mayonnaise after opening the jar.

Vocabulary.mean: Rent is the money people pay to someone to live in a certain place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The rent is due at the end of the month.

Vocabulary.mean: To retire is to leave a job, usually because of old age.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He will retire next year.

Vocabulary.mean: A statistic is a number that tells a fact about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The statistics reflect a change in people's spending habits.

Vocabulary.mean: An astronaut is a person that goes into outer space.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The astronaut was walking on the moon

Vocabulary.mean: When you are awake, you are not asleep.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The noise from their party kept me awake half the night.

Vocabulary.mean: When you have courage, you are not afraid.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It took me several months to get up the courage to ask her to lunch.

Vocabulary.mean: To float is to move on top of water without sinking.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. An empty bottle will float on water.

Vocabulary.mean: To grant something is to allow someone to have it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They granted her an entry visa.

Vocabulary.mean: Gravity is the force that makes things fall to Earth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Isaac Newton discovered the law of gravity.

Vocabulary.mean: A jewel is a beautiful stone that is worth a lot of money.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The ring is set with one large jewel.

Vocabulary.mean: A miner is a person who works in a mine.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Ten miners were trapped underground when the roof of the tunnel fell in.

Vocabulary.mean: A mineral is a type of substance found in the Earth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Rocks are made up of different kinds of minerals.

Vocabulary.mean: To participate is to take part in something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The teacher tries to get everyone to participate in the classroom discussion.

Vocabulary.mean: Permission means the act of allowing the doing of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You will need permission from your parents to go on the trip.

Vocabulary.mean: To pour a liquid means to make it come out of a container.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Let's see if I can pour the juice into the glass without spilling it.

Vocabulary.mean: Someone or something’s presence is the fact they are there.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's usually quite polite in my presence.

Vocabulary.mean: If a material is raw, it is natural and has not been processed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our chief expenditure is on raw materials.

Vocabulary.mean: A satellite is something that is sent into space to get information.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The World Cup was transmitted around the world by satellite.

Vocabulary.mean: The scale of something is its size, especially when it is very large.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We don't yet know the scale of the problem.

Vocabulary.mean: To skip something is to not do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She decided to skip the afternoon class.

Vocabulary.mean: To stretch is to make your arms or legs reach out.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I get up and walk around every half hour just to stretch my legs.

Vocabulary.mean: A telescope is a tool people use to look at the stars.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. With a good telescope, you can see craters on the moon.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is underground, it is below the surface of the Earth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Electrical power is supplied by underground cables.

Vocabulary.mean: An alarm is something that warns people of danger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If the alarm sounds, leave the building immediately.

Vocabulary.mean: When people or things are apart, they are not close together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Stand with your feet wide apart and bend from the waist.

Vocabulary.mean: To arrest someone means to catch them for doing something bad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Police arrested several of the demonstrators.

Vocabulary.mean: An award is a prize someone gets for doing something well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was in London to accept an award for her latest novel.

Vocabulary.mean: A breed is a group of animals within a species.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There is now a huge variety of dog breeds.

Vocabulary.mean: A bucket is a round container to put things in.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He scooped the sand into a bucket with his hands.

Vocabulary.mean: A contest is a game or a race.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's won a lot of beauty contests.

Vocabulary.mean: To convict someone means to prove that they did a bad thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There might not have been enough evidence to convict him.

Vocabulary.mean: A garage is the part of a house where people put their cars.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The wind has packed the snow against the garage door.

Vocabulary.mean: A journalist is a person who writes news stories.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The journalist took notes throughout the interview.

Vocabulary.mean: A pup is a young dog.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. All the girl wanted for her birthday was a pup.

Vocabulary.mean: To qualify is to get, or to be declared, adequate or good enough.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This training course will qualify you for a better job.

Vocabulary.mean: To repair something is to fix it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The human body has an amazing capacity to repair itself.

Vocabulary.mean: To resume something means to start it again after taking a break.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The meeting will resume after lunch.

Vocabulary.mean: To rob a person or place is to take their property by using force.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Two men robbed the bank last night.

Vocabulary.mean: To slip means to slide and fall down.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The blanket began to slip off my shoulders.

Vocabulary.mean: Somewhat means to some degree, but not to a large degree.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The resort has changed somewhat over the last few years.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is stable, it will not fall over.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Don’t climb the ladder until you’re sure it’s stable.

Vocabulary.mean: A tissue is a soft piece of paper people use to wipe their noses.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She handed me a tissue just before I sneezed.

Vocabulary.mean: A yard is the ground just outside of a person’s house.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The children played in the school yard.

Vocabulary.mean: If two things or people are alike, they are similar in some way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The children all look very alike.

Vocabulary.mean: To annoy someone means to bother them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I know you’re doing this only to annoy me.

Vocabulary.mean: Architecture is the style or way a building is made.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This is a prime example of 1930s architecture.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is artificial, it is made to look like something natural.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The match will be played on an artificial surface.

Vocabulary.mean: A chain is a series of connected loops often used to keep things in place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She looped the chain around her bike and locked it to the fence.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is distinct, it is easily noticed or different from other things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sales chart shows a distinct decline in the past few months.

Vocabulary.mean: To distinguish is to recognize differences between things.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. Polar bears live in the Arctic.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Panama Canal connects the Atlantic Ocean and the Pacific Ocean.

Vocabulary.mean: A chemist is a scientist who works with chemicals.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Chemists have found a new compound.

Vocabulary.mean: A chill is a feeling of cold.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've put the beer in the fridge to chill.

Vocabulary.mean: Congress is a group of leaders in a government.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Congress will vote on the proposals tomorrow.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is dairy, it is made from milk.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The shop doesn't stock much dairy produce, only fresh milk, actually.

Vocabulary.mean: To descend is to go downward.
Vocabulary.example: e.g.  She descended the stairs slowly.

Vocabulary.mean: A grocer is a person who sells food.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She is a grocer in a small town.

Vocabulary.mean: To hesitate is to wait for a short time before doing something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I didn't hesitate for a moment about taking the job.

Vocabulary.mean: An institution is an organization that works to help a city or group of people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Harvard University is an internationally respected institution.

Vocabulary.mean: To jog is to run slowly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I go jogging every morning at the park.

Vocabulary.mean: A merchant is a person who sells things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Venice was once a city of rich merchants.

Vocabulary.mean: To poke something is to push it with your finger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You will poke at others with that umbrella if you are not careful!

Vocabulary.mean: To postpone something is to make it happen later than planned.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We'll have to postpone the meeting until next week.

Vocabulary.mean: When a liquid splashes, it bursts and hits something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Water splashed onto the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: If people are stubborn, they don’t change their minds easily.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was too stubborn to admit that he was wrong.

Vocabulary.mean: A suburb is a small part of a large city.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Box Hill is a suburb of Melbourne.

Vocabulary.mean: The tide is the level of the water in the sea.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The boat was swept out to sea by the tide.

Vocabulary.mean: A tragedy is a very sad event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are deeply saddened by this devastating tragedy.

Vocabulary.mean: A bomb is an object that explodes and destroys large areas.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Hundreds of bombs were dropped on the city.

Vocabulary.mean: A certificate is a document that says that something is true or happened.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has a certificate in Drama Education.

Vocabulary.mean: A circumstance is an event that makes a situation what it is.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company reserves the right to cancel this agreement in certain circumstances.

Vocabulary.mean: A coffin is a box used to bury dead people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. People put a wreath on the coffin before burying him.

Vocabulary.mean: To cope with a difficult or stressful situation means to deal with it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He wasn't able to cope with the stresses of the job.

Vocabulary.mean: Criticism is the act of saying that you don’t like or approve of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government is currently facing severe criticism.

Vocabulary.mean: To devastate something means to completely destroy it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bomb devastated most of the city.

Vocabulary.mean: To frown is to make an unhappy look with your face.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Don't frown so, it spoils your pretty face.

Vocabulary.mean: To gaze at something means to look at it for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He spends hours gazing out of the window when he should be working.

Vocabulary.mean: To glance at something means to look at it quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She glanced around the room to see who was there.

Vocabulary.mean: Grief is the feeling of deep sadness, usually when a person dies.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was overcome with grief when her husband died.

Vocabulary.mean: A groom is a man who is going to be married.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bride and groom were posing for pictures.

Vocabulary.mean: A license is an official document that gives one permission to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You need a license to fish in this river.

Vocabulary.mean: A microscope is a device that makes small objects look bigger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They looked at the blood samples under the microscope.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is nuclear, it relates to the division or joining of atoms.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government is having difficulty finding a safe depository for nuclear waste.

Vocabulary.mean: To portray something means to describe it or show it in a picture.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The painting portrays a beautiful young woman in a blue dress.

Vocabulary.mean: To rotate something means to turn it around in a circle.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The wheel rotates around an axle.

Vocabulary.mean: A souvenir is something you buy to remind you of a place or event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I bought the ring as a souvenir of Greece.

Vocabulary.mean: A submarine is a boat that can go underwater for long periods of time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The submarine dives deep below the surface of the sea.

Vocabulary.mean: To trace something means to follow over it with the eyes or a finger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He traced the route on the map.

Vocabulary.mean: An appliance is a piece of equipment used for jobs in the home.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They sell a wide range of home appliances: fridges, freezers and dishwashers.

Vocabulary.mean: A basin is large bowl for washing things. A sink is sometimes called a basin.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Run some water into the basin and wash your hands and face properly.

Vocabulary.mean: A broom is a brush with a long handle used for cleaning floors.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I use that broom to sweep the kitchen floor.

Vocabulary.mean: A caterpillar is a small insect that looks like a worm and eats plants.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We found some caterpillars in vegetables.

Vocabulary.mean: A cupboard is a piece of furniture that is used to store food or household items.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I found my tennis racket at the back of the cupboard.

Vocabulary.mean: If something or someone is delicate, they are easy to break or harm.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Delicate plants need to be kept in a greenhouse during the winter.

Vocabulary.mean: To emerge from something means to come out of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He emerged from the pool.

Vocabulary.mean: A handicap is a condition that limits someone’s mental or physical abilities.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His loss of hearing was a severe handicap.

Vocabulary.mean: A hook is a sharp curved piece of metal used for catching or holding things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Could you put some hooks in the garden shed, for us to hang the tools on?

Vocabulary.mean: To hop means to jump a short distance.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A bird hopped across the lawn.

Vocabulary.mean: Laundry is clothes that have been or need to be washed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The hotel has a laundry service.

Vocabulary.mean: To pursue someone or something is to chase or follow them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She wishes to pursue an educational career.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is reluctant, they do not want to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was reluctant to admit she was wrong.

Vocabulary.mean: Sleeves are the part of a shirt where your arms go.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Dan rolled up his sleeves and washed his hands.

Vocabulary.mean: The spine is the bone that runs up and down the middle of the back.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She injured her spine in an accident.

Vocabulary.mean: A stain is a dirty mark that is difficult to clean.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I hope it doesn't stain the carpet.

Vocabulary.mean: A strip is a long, narrow piece of material or land.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He didn't have a bandage, so he ripped up his shirt into thin strips.

Vocabulary.mean: To swear means to promise to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Soldiers must swear allegiance to the king.

Vocabulary.mean: To swing something means to move it back and forth or from side to side.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He sat on the chair, swinging his legs.

Vocabulary.mean: To utilize something means to use it for a specific purpose.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The library’s great collection allowed me to utilize many rare sources.

Vocabulary.mean: An aroma is a scent or smell.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A delicious aroma was coming from the kitchen.

Vocabulary.mean: A beverage is a drink.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Hot beverages include tea, coffee, and hot chocolate.

Vocabulary.mean: A cluster of things is a small group of them placed close together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Have a look at the cluster of stars in this photograph.

Vocabulary.mean: To combine is to join together to make a single thing or group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water.

Vocabulary.mean: When a liquid is condensed, it is made thicker.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We used sweetened condensed milk in place of cream.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is contemporary, it is related to the present time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She is performing a contemporary dance.

Vocabulary.mean: To cultivate plants is to care for them and help them grow.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The people cultivate mainly rice and beans.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is divine, it is related to gods.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some fans seem to regard the players as divine beings.

Vocabulary.mean: When it is humid, there is a lot of water in the air.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. New York is very hot and humid in the summer.

Vocabulary.mean: An odor is a very distinct smell.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. the stale odor of cigarette smoke make me sick.

Vocabulary.mean: The palate is the top part of the mouth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You can touch your palate with your tongue.

Vocabulary.mean: Paradise is the place or condition of happiness where things are perfect.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His idea of paradise is to spend the day fishing.

Vocabulary.mean: A plantation is a big farm that only grows certain kinds of crops.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He works at a banana plantation.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is rapid, it moves or changes very quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The disease is spreading at a rapid rate.

Vocabulary.mean: A rate is the speed at which something happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. At the rate you work, you'll never finish!

Vocabulary.mean: When something is soothing, it makes you calm or relaxed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I put on some nice soothing music.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is subtle, it is not easy to see or notice.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fragrance is a subtle blend of jasmine and sandalwood.

Vocabulary.mean: The texture of something is the way its surface looks and feels.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fabric has a very soft texture.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is toxic, it is poisonous. Toxic things are very dangerous.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Toxic water is discharged directly into the river.

Vocabulary.mean: To vary means to be different from another thing in size or amount.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Salary varies between positions in the company.

Vocabulary.mean: An accident is an unexpected undesirable event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was injured in a car accident

Vocabulary.mean: An admiral is someone who controls many military ships.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The admiral visited the ships under his command.

Vocabulary.mean: An arc is a curved shape.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The ball rose in a high arc and landed beyond the fence.

Vocabulary.mean: Your character is your personality.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's a rather odd character.

Vocabulary.mean: Your conscience is your inner sense of what is right and wrong.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Let your conscience be your guide.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is fiery, it is burning strongly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fiery rays of the sun through the leaves.

Vocabulary.mean: Flesh is the skin, muscle and fat on your body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The trap had cut deeply into the rabbit's flesh.

Vocabulary.mean: A grapefruit is a fruit similar to an orange, but bigger and not as sweet.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Would you like to drink grapefruit or guava juice?

Vocabulary.mean: Hay is dry grass used to feed animals or used as a covering.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm looking for some hay to feed the goats.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are horrified, you are very shocked and feel upset.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He looked horrified when I told him.

Vocabulary.mean: Kerosene is a type of oil. It is used in some lamps and stoves.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is cooking with an kerosene stove.

Vocabulary.mean: A loop is a line made into the shape of a circle.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The road went in a huge loop around the lake.

Vocabulary.mean: A paddle is a piece of wood or plastic that moves a boat across water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We need a paddle to help us move across the water.

Vocabulary.mean: A raft is a floating platform made from pieces of wood tied together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are making a raft to escape from the island.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is sour, it has a sharp and unpleasant taste.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These plums are a bit sour.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. Tall plants can be secured by tying them to stakes.

Vocabulary.mean: A steward is a person like a waiter who serves food on planes and ships.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The steward brought us some fast food.

Vocabulary.mean: String is a thin piece of fabric or rope.

Vocabulary.mean: A thorn is a sharp part of a plant.

Vocabulary.mean: To wreck something means to destroy or ruin it.

Vocabulary.mean: To admonish someone is to tell them you disapprove of their behavior.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His mother admonished him for eating too quickly.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is audible, then it is able to be heard.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her voice was barely audible above the noise.

Vocabulary.mean: If something or someone is awesome, they are impressive or frightening.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You look totally awesome in that dress.

Vocabulary.mean: To beware means to be careful of something or someone that is dangerous.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Drivers have been warned to beware of icy roads.

Vocabulary.mean: To brag means to talk of one’s abilities or achievements in a proud way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He bragged to his friends about his new car.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is conscious of something, then they are aware of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's still conscious but he's very badly injured.

Vocabulary.mean: To disagree with someone means to have a different opinion from them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He disagreed with his parents on most things.

Vocabulary.mean: To echo means that a sound repeats itself because it bounced off an object.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He shouted into the mouth of the cave and waited for the echo.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is eventual, it will happen at the end of a series of events.

Vocabulary.mean: A hint is information that suggests something will happen or is true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Did she give you any hints about where she was going?

Vocabulary.mean: An idiot is a person who is not smart or who has done something silly.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. There is still an immense amount of work to be done.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. His carelessness indirectly caused this serious accident.

Vocabulary.mean: A pastime is an activity done for fun that you do often.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is perfect, then it is without any mistakes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The weather's just perfect for swimming.

Vocabulary.mean: To pinpoint something means to locate it exactly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was able to pinpoint on the map the site of the medieval village.

Vocabulary.mean: To switch means to change something to something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She started studying English, but switched to Japanese in her second year.

Vocabulary.mean: If something or someone is thorough, then they are complete in everyway.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The doctor gave him a thorough medical examination.

Vocabulary.mean: To torment someone means to cause them to suffer on purpose.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The cows were tormented by flies.

Vocabulary.mean: A beak is the hard curved part of a bird’s mouth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Birds use their beaks to pick up food.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is damp, it is somewhat wet.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The grass is still damp in the early morning..

Vocabulary.mean: To disapprove of something is to think that it is wrong.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She wants to be an actress, but her parents disapprove.

Vocabulary.mean: You use except to talk about the only thing that a statement does not apply to.

Vocabulary.mean: A flight is an act of flying, often in an airplane.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Passengers are requested to check in two hours before the flight.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is fond of something, they like it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Many people in Britain are fond of gardening .

Vocabulary.mean: Ivy is a plant with long vines that grows upward typically on walls.

Vocabulary.mean: To moan is to make a low sound when feeling pain or sadness.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We could hear the moans of someone trapped under the rubble.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is oblivious of something, they are unaware of it.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. Three hundred people perished in the earthquake.

Vocabulary.mean: A pit is a big hole in the ground.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We dug a deep pit in the yard.

Vocabulary.mean: The rim is the outside edge of a round thing, like a cup or bottle.

Vocabulary.mean: A roost is a place where birds can land and rest or sleep.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is slippery, it is wet or smooth and causes people to slip.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sidewalks were slippery with ice.

Vocabulary.mean: To soar means to fly high in the air.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She watched the gliders soaring effortlessly in the sky.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is trivial, it is not important or meaningful.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is typical, it is normal for a certain type of thing.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. What he did was utter nonsense.

Vocabulary.mean: To weep means to cry.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She wept bitterly at the news.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. I’d like to rest awhile before we continue.

Vocabulary.mean: Cyberspace is the imaginary place of the Internet where activities occur.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You can find the answer to almost any question in cyberspace.

Vocabulary.mean: To edit means to correct a piece of writing so that it is suitable to be published.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He edits the local newspaper.

Vocabulary.mean: An essay is a short piece of writing on a certain subject.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His essay was full of spelling errors.

Vocabulary.mean: To evaluate something means to study it, so a decision can be made.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Doctors evaluate the patient’s condition.

Vocabulary.mean: To faint means to go unconscious and fall down.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I stood up too quickly and very nearly fainted.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is global, it happens all around the world.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The commission is calling for a global ban on whaling.

Vocabulary.mean: A gymnasium is a building with equipment that you can use to get exercise.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is a personal trainer in this gymnasium.

Vocabulary.mean: To highlight something means to mark it with a color so that it is easy to see
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've highlighted the important passages in yellow.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is ignorant about something, they have no knowledge about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My father is ignorant about modern technology.

Vocabulary.mean: An index is a list of words at the end of a book that gives information.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Using the index would have saved you a lot of time.

Vocabulary.mean: A lecture is a long, educational speech.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His lecture was complicated and difficult to follow.

Vocabulary.mean: A moral is a message at the end of a story that teaches you something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The moral of the story is that good people always get lucky.

Vocabulary.mean: To operate means to work or function.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Solar panels can only operate in sunlight.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is private, it is only used by one person or group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Let’s go somewhere private so we can talk freely.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is recent, it happened a short time ago.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There have been many changes in recent years.

Vocabulary.mean: A resolution is a personal decision.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She made a resolution to visit her parents more often.

Vocabulary.mean: A semester is a portion of a school year.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He got good results in the first semester at university.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is typewritten, it is written on a computer or typewriter.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This letter must be typewritten.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is weird, it is very strange.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I heard some weird noises coming from outside.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is absolute, it is total or complete.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The day was an absolute disaster.

Vocabulary.mean: Alas is a word that people say when something bad happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. For many people, alas, hunger is part of everyday life.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are attentive, you are careful and you pay attention.

Vocabulary.mean: A cape is a large cloth that covers one’s back and is tied around the neck.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The superhero wore a long red cape.

Vocabulary.mean: To envision something means to imagine that it may happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company envisions adding at least five stores next year.

Vocabulary.mean: When something happens evenly, it happens at the same rate or level.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Arrange the tomato slices evenly on the top.

Vocabulary.mean: Folk are common or average people.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. When the sun came out, the ice began to melt.

Vocabulary.mean: A patch is a part of a surface that is different in appearance from the rest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His old jeans are covered with patches.

Vocabulary.mean: Pleasure is a feeling of happiness.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His visits gave his grandparents such pleasure.

Vocabulary.mean: A pop is a short, loud sound.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I heard a pop and the lights went out.

Vocabulary.mean: A pudding is a sweet dessert.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I’ll make a pudding for dessert.

Vocabulary.mean: A rail is a horizontal bar made of metal or wood.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. When I make pies, I don’t need to follow a recipe.

Vocabulary.mean: A role is the normal purpose or function of a person or thing.

Vocabulary.mean: To shrink means to get smaller.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Your sweater will shrink if you wash it at too high a temperature.

Vocabulary.mean: To soak something means to make it very wet.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The wind had blown the rain in and soaked the carpet.

Vocabulary.mean: A spark is a small, quick flash of fire.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sparks from old wiring are responsible for the fire.

Vocabulary.mean: A spirit is someone’s feelings and personality, but not a physical body part.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We acted in a spirit of cooperation.

Vocabulary.mean: A suit is a set of clothes. It usually includes a jacket with pants ora skirt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's regulation to wear suits at the office.

Vocabulary.mean: An account with a bank is an arrangement to keep one’s money there.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. To open an account, you need to make a minimum deposit of $500.

Vocabulary.mean: An architect is a person who designs buildings.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The house was designed by architect Louis Kahn.

Vocabulary.mean: To conceal something means to hide it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Tim could barely conceal his disappointment.

Vocabulary.mean: A crime is something bad that a person does that can be punished by law.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government must do something to reduce the level of crime in the area.

Vocabulary.mean: A deed is a certificate that proves that someone owns something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. According to the deed, she owns the land from here to the river.

Vocabulary.mean: Gratitude is a feeling of being thankful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She sent them a present to express her gratitude.

Vocabulary.mean: A habitat is the natural home of animals or plants.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The panda's natural habitat is the bamboo forest.

Vocabulary.mean: To intervene means to help stop a problem between two people or groups.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'd like to help but I don't have the power to intervene in this dispute.

Vocabulary.mean: A landmark is an object that helps people find or remember a location.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Empire State Building is a familiar landmark on the New York skyline.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is legal, it is related to the law or allowed by the law.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It is not legal to sell alcohol to minors.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is memorable, then it is remembered for a special reason.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The city is memorable for its fantastic beaches.

Vocabulary.mean: To oblige someone means to require them to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Parents are obliged to look after their children.

Vocabulary.mean: An offense is an action that breaks the law and requires punishment.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was charged with the offense of driving without a license.

Vocabulary.mean: To proclaim something means to say it in public.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The president has proclaimed a state of emergency.

Vocabulary.mean: A rally is a large public meeting in order to support something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We participate in an anti-nuclear rally.

Vocabulary.mean: To resolve something means to find a solution.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Have you resolved the problem of transport yet?

Vocabulary.mean: Resources are a person or country’s money and materials that they can use.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The long war had drained the resources of both countries.

Vocabulary.mean: A sentence is punishment given to someone who didn’t follow the law.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He served a three-year prison sentence.

Vocabulary.mean: To volunteer means to offer to do something for free.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Schools need volunteers to help children to read.

Vocabulary.mean: A witness is someone who sees or hears a crime or accident happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. According to witnesses, the man in the blue jacket stole the car last night.

Vocabulary.mean: Access is the right to enter or use something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Many of the families do not have access to health care.

Vocabulary.mean: Conduct is the way that someone acts.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her conduct was irreproachable.

Vocabulary.mean: When an event or action is constant, it happens a lot or all the time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's in constant trouble with the police.

Vocabulary.mean: A crack is a narrow space between the parts of something broken.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Cracks had appeared in the dry ground.

Vocabulary.mean: A device is an object or a machine.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You can stream music on your tablet or other mobile device.

Vocabulary.mean: To enclose something is to contain it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The house has a small backyard, enclosed by a high brick wall.

Vocabulary.mean: To grip something is to hold it very tightly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The baby gripped my finger with her tiny hand.

Vocabulary.mean: To halt is to stop moving.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The trial was halted after the first week.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is impending, it is going to happen soon.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The impending crisis over trade made everyone nervous.

Vocabulary.mean: To influence someone or something is to have an effect over them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My grandmother had a strong influence on my early childhood.

Vocabulary.mean: A law is a rule made by the legislative body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Congress passed laws banning driving after drinking alcohol.

Vocabulary.mean: A mode is a setting or condition on a machine.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Switch the camera into the automatic mode.

Vocabulary.mean: To perspire means to sweat.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Exercises make me perspiring profusely.

Vocabulary.mean: To replace something is to put it in the place of something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's bought me a new smart phone to replace my old one.

Vocabulary.mean: To snap something means to break it suddenly, which causes a loud noise.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He snapped the branches in two.

Vocabulary.mean: If a person or animal is sly, they are sneaky or good at tricking people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sly cat stole my fish when I left the room.

Vocabulary.mean: To tend to do something is to be likely to do it or to do it often.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I think you tend to eat more in the winter.
