Vocabulary.mean: When something is valid, it is correct or based on good reasoning.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She had valid reasons for not supporting the proposals.

Vocabulary.mean: A version is an account of something that differs slightly from the original.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are two versions of the game, a offline one and a online one.

Vocabulary.mean: You use whatsoever after a noun to emphasize that there is nothing of that thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The man had no idea whatsoever how to solve his problem.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is alongside another thing, then it is next to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The new pill will be used alongside existing medicines.

Vocabulary.mean: Your appetite is your hunger for food.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The walk gave me a good appetite.

Vocabulary.mean: To assist someone is to help them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We'll do all we can to assist you.

Vocabulary.mean: A breeze is a soft wind.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The flowers were gently swaying in the breeze.

Vocabulary.mean: To defy someone is to work against them or refuse to do what they say.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He still does these works, defying warnings from professionals.

Vocabulary.mean: To display something is to show it, especially by putting it in a certain place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The museum displays many types of dinosaur bones.

Vocabulary.mean: If something or someone is efficient, they do not waste energy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The city's transport system is one of the most efficient in Europe.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is feeble, they are small or weak.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The candle gave only a feeble light.

Vocabulary.mean: To forgive someone is to stop being angry with them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'd never forgive myself if anything happened to the kids.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is lively, they have a lot of energy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We had a lively discussion.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is majestic, it is large and beautiful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We flew over the majestic mountains.

Vocabulary.mean: You use nor to connect two negative ideas.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We can neither change nor improve it.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is outraged, they are very angry.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was outraged at the way he had been treated.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is pessimistic, they believe that the worst will happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The doctors are pessimistic about his chances of recovery.

Vocabulary.mean: A rumor is something people talk about even though it may not be true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Rumors about job cut are circulating in our company.

Vocabulary.mean: To slap someone means to hit them with the palm of the hand.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In the movie, she slaps his face after he kisses her.

Vocabulary.mean: To smash something is to break it into many small pieces.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Several windows had been smashed during storm.

Vocabulary.mean: A subject is the topic that is being discussed or taught.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our subject for discussion is homelessness.

Vocabulary.mean: A wage is the money that a person gets for doing a job.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Is she paid a regular wage or is it by commission only?

Vocabulary.mean: You use whereas to show how two things are different.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You eat a huge plate of food for lunch, whereas I have just a sandwich.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is animate, it has life.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Rocks and machines are not animate things.

Vocabulary.mean: To classify things is to put them into groups based on their type.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The books in the library are classified by subject.

Vocabulary.mean: To concede is to admit that something is true against your wish.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He conceded that he had treated her rudely.

Vocabulary.mean: A concept is an idea about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It is very difficult to define the concept of beauty.

Vocabulary.mean: To construct something means to make or build it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They approved funds to construct a new hospital.

Vocabulary.mean: A decade is a period of ten years.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The economy is growing at its fastest rate this decade.

Vocabulary.mean: A diagram is a simple drawing that explains what something is or how it works.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The teacher drew a diagram showing how blood flows through the heart.

Vocabulary.mean: A ferry is a boat that carries passengers over short distances.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You can take a ferry across the river.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is handy, it is useful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Always keep a handy first-aid kit in your house.

Vocabulary.mean: To isolate is to separate one person or thing from a group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A high wall isolated the house from the rest of the village.

Vocabulary.mean: A longing is a strong feeling of wanting.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Since the war broke out, we only had a longing for peace and freedom.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is numerous, there are many of those things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The essay contains numerous errors.

Vocabulary.mean: A particle is a very small piece of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Dust particles can cause engine blockage.

Vocabulary.mean: A plea is a request that is urgent or emotional.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He made a plea for mercy.

Vocabulary.mean: To refrain from something is to avoid doing it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Please refrain from smoking here.

Vocabulary.mean: A review of something is a formal inspection of it by people in authority.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The terms of the contract are under review.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is sophisticated, they know many things about the world.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Mark is a smart and sophisticated young man.

Vocabulary.mean: To surrender something is to give it up.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police demanded that the thief surrender his weapons.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is upright, it is standing up straight.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Please return your seat to an upright position and fasten your belt.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is worthwhile, it is important or useful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If you want people to do things for you, you've got to make it worthwhile to them.

Vocabulary.mean: An alliance is a group of people who work together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Switzerland does not belong to any military alliance.

Vocabulary.mean: Applause is the noise made when people clap hands to show approval.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The play starts with big applause.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are armed, you are carrying a weapon.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Two armed men were arrested after the robbery.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is authoritative, it uses the best information available.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The book is an authoritative source on the Second World War.

Vocabulary.mean: A ceremony is an event that happens on special occasions.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Olympics ended with a spectacular closing ceremony.

Vocabulary.mean: Culture is the music, art, and writings of a certain place or group of people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Venice is a beautiful city full of culture and history.

Vocabulary.mean: A defense is something that is done to protect another thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The vaccine strengthens the body’s defenses against infection.

Vocabulary.mean: A detail is a small piece of information.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'll send you a fax with the details of the proposal.

Vocabulary.mean: When a group of things is diverse, it is made up of a wide variety of things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Australia is a very culturally diverse country.

Vocabulary.mean: To enchant someone is to make them feel very interested or happy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The audience was clearly enchanted by her performance.

Vocabulary.mean: To equip someone is to give them the things needed to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. All of our classrooms are equipped with computers.

Vocabulary.mean: An exception is someone or something not conforming to a rule.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Nobody had much money at the time and I was no exception.

Vocabulary.mean: A genre is a type of literature, art, or music characterized by its style.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His strength is in the landscape painting genre.

Vocabulary.mean: An impact is the effect someone or something has on another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The environmental impact of this project will be enormous.

Vocabulary.mean: To lure someone is to convince them to do something, by using a trick.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was lured into the job by the offer of a high salary.

Vocabulary.mean: An obstacle is an object or a problem that stops you from doing something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A lack of qualifications can be a major obstacle to finding a job.

Vocabulary.mean: A shelter is a place to go that is safe from danger or bad weather.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Everyone hurried into the shelter when the storm struck.

Vocabulary.mean: To sort means to separate things into different groups or classes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The eggs are sorted into different sizes.

Vocabulary.mean: To supply something means to give people what they need or want.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A healthy diet should supply all necessary vitamins and minerals.

Vocabulary.mean: If people are vain, they are only concerned with how they look.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's too vain to wear glasses.

Vocabulary.mean: An alternative is something that you can choose instead of your first choice.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have no alternative but to ask you to leave.

Vocabulary.mean: An avenue is a road, often a large one with buildings on each side.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We walked down a broad avenue lined with trees.

Vocabulary.mean: The belly is the stomach of a person or animal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. By the sixth month of pregnancy, Gina's belly had begun to grow.

Vocabulary.mean: A bid to do something is an attempt to do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her bid for re-election was unsuccessful.

Vocabulary.mean: To blow means to move air or move something through the air, as in the wind.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The wind was blowing hard outside the window.

Vocabulary.mean: A conflict is a fight between different people or groups.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The conflict destabilized the whole region.

Vocabulary.mean: A continent is one of the seven large areas of land on the Earth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The continents make up about 35% of the earth's crust.

Vocabulary.mean: A current is a steady and constant flow of air or water in a river or ocean.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was swept out to sea by the strong current.

Vocabulary.mean: Disrespect is rudeness or a behavior that shows a lack of respect.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He showed disrespect by interrupting me.

Vocabulary.mean: Enthusiasm is a very strong good feeling about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She never lost her enthusiasm for teaching.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is harsh, it is very unpleasant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They must adapt to the harsh conditions of nature.

Vocabulary.mean: To lean is to bend the body in a particular direction.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I leaned back in my chair to read a book.

Vocabulary.mean: The meantime is the time between two events.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Rick wants to be an actor, but in the meantime he’s working as a waiter.

Vocabulary.mean: Mischief is behavior that is meant to trick or cause trouble for people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some of the neighborhood kids like to get into mischief.

Vocabulary.mean: Muscle is a mass of tissue attached to bone that helps you move.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These exercises build muscle and increase stamina.

Vocabulary.mean: To rescue someone means to remove them from danger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The lifeboat rescued the sailors from the sinking boat.

Vocabulary.mean: A succession is a number of things that follow one after the other.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has won the award for the third year in succession.

Vocabulary.mean: The terrain is the land and all of its physical features or parts.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He used to drive on rough terrain.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is timid, they are afraid, shy, or nervous.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was timid about swimming in deep water.

Vocabulary.mean: Violence is forceful action that is meant to injure or kill people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. More police were sent to help contain the violence.

Vocabulary.mean: To affect someone or something is to have an influence over them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Both buildings were badly affected by the fire.

Vocabulary.mean: An autograph is the written name of a famous person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He signed his autograph for the little girl.

Vocabulary.mean: A bead is a drop of liquid.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Beads of sweat stood out on his forehead.

Vocabulary.mean: To brew coffee or tea means to pour hot water over it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He brewed some coffee for us.

Vocabulary.mean: To charm someone is to please them with your personality.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was charmed by her beauty and wit.

Vocabulary.mean: A destiny is all the things that happen or will happen to a person in their life.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We all want to determine our own destinies.

Vocabulary.mean: A horn is a device that makes a loud noise.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The driver honked his horn when passing us.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is irritable, they become annoyed or angry very easily.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The man has really been irritable today.

Vocabulary.mean: To lag behind is to move slowly behind other moving objects.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. John’s always lagging behind the others in the class.

Vocabulary.mean: To maximize something means to make it the biggest in size or amount.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Most people try to maximize their gains and minimize their losses.

Vocabulary.mean: A nightmare is a bad or scary dream.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I had a terrible nightmare last night.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is nutritious, it helps the body stay healthy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Raw spinach is especially nutritious.

Vocabulary.mean: Protein is a substance that is necessary for the body to grow and be strong.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Meat and fish are a vital source of protein.

Vocabulary.mean: A signature is your name that you have written in your own way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Please print your name clearly below your signature.

Vocabulary.mean: Stuff is a word used to refer to things without mentioning the things by name.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's sticky stuff all over the chair.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is subconscious, it is done without thinking about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. On a subconscious level, he didn't want to hurt her.

Vocabulary.mean: A van is a vehicle that is used for carrying things but is smaller than a truck.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Do you want help bringing your stuff in from the van?

Vocabulary.mean: To warn someone is to make them know of possible danger in the future.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My mother always warned me not to talk to strangers.

Vocabulary.mean: A workout is an exercise routine that helps improve health.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She does a 20-minute workout every morning.

Vocabulary.mean: To zoom is to move quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They got into the car and zoomed off.

Vocabulary.mean: A brick is a block of hard clay that is used for building things, such as walls.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The house has a small backyard, surrounded by a high brick wall.

Vocabulary.mean: To crumble means to break or fall apart into small pieces.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. That old wall is starting to crumble.

Vocabulary.mean: Dough is a mixture of flour and water that becomes bread when baked.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She kneaded the dough and left it to rise.

Vocabulary.mean: To express a feeling or idea means to show others how one thinks or feels.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She sent them a present to express her gratitude.

Vocabulary.mean: A fist is a hand with fingers bent in toward the palm.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He punched me with his fist.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is flexible, then it can bend easily without breaking.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our plans need to be flexible enough to cater for the needs of everyone.

Vocabulary.mean: To flush means the face becomes red due to heat, illness, or emotion.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He flushed with anger.

Vocabulary.mean: To injure someone means to damage a part of their body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I fell down the stairs and injured my back.

Vocabulary.mean: A lump is a small piece of something that is solid.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He ate an enormous lump of cheese.

Vocabulary.mean: A mixture is something that is made by mixing other things together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The mixture of flour, water, and yeast is then left in a warm place for four hours.

Vocabulary.mean: To reconcile means to return to a friendly relationship.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has recently been reconciled with his wife.

Vocabulary.mean: To ruin something means to harm or damage it greatly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bad weather ruined our trip.

Vocabulary.mean: To shatter something means to break it suddenly into many tiny pieces.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The glass shattered into a thousand tiny pieces.

Vocabulary.mean: Shutters are wooden or metal covers in front of a window.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Remember to close the shutter before leaving.

Vocabulary.mean: To sift something means to remove all the large pieces.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sift some powdered sugar on top of the cake.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is slight, then it is small or minor.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I woke up with a slight headache.

Vocabulary.mean: To sparkle means to shine brightly with quick flashes of light.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The lake sparkled in the sunlight.

Vocabulary.mean: To sprinkle means to scatter something all over something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I like to sprinkle some pepper over my pasta.

Vocabulary.mean: If food is stale, then it is not fresh but dry, hard, and not good to eat.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Don't use these breads, they are stale.

Vocabulary.mean: To utter a word or a sound means to say it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She sat through the whole meeting without uttering a word.

Vocabulary.mean: You use although to say that one thing is contrasted by another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Although the sun was shining, it wasn't very warm.

Vocabulary.mean: To apply something means to put it on.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Apply the cream sparingly to your face and neck.

Vocabulary.mean: To await something means to wait for it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's anxiously awaiting his test results.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is beloved, it is very special and you like it very much.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was beloved by all who knew her.

Vocabulary.mean: To bury someone or something means to put them in the ground.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His father is buried in the cemetery on the hill.

Vocabulary.mean: A climate is the usual weather in a place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The climate is cooler in the east of the country.

Vocabulary.mean: When you complain, you say that you are unhappy about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She complained that she had too much work to do.

Vocabulary.mean: To confuse someone means to make them feel like they are unsure.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The instructions on the board confused me.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is due, it is expected to happen or be done at that time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. When is the first payment due?

Vocabulary.mean: When you talk about an entire thing, you are talking about the whole thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He'd spent the entire journey asleep.

Vocabulary.mean: To establish something means to create it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The two brothers established a clothes retailing business.

Vocabulary.mean: A furnace is a place where heat is made.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. People who work with furnaces in a steel factory need to wear protective clothing.

Vocabulary.mean: A leash is a rope or chain that is used to lead an animal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Dogs must be kept on a leash in this park.

Vocabulary.mean: To mature means to grow up to become an adult.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has matured a great deal over the past year.

Vocabulary.mean: To measure something means to find out the quality, value, or effect of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This machine measures your heart rate.

Vocabulary.mean: The midst of something is the middle of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The house is set in the midst of large gardens.

Vocabulary.mean: Misery is extreme suffering.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Ten years of marriage to him have made her life a misery.

Vocabulary.mean: When something happened prior to something else, it happened earlier.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Please give us prior notice if you need an evening meal.

Vocabulary.mean: Research is close and careful study to discover new things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Research on animals has led to some important medical advances.

Vocabulary.mean: A variety of something is a group of many different kinds of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The markets offer a variety of fresh fruits and vegetables.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens altogether, it happens completely.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The train slowed down and then stopped altogether.

Vocabulary.mean: To bind is to bring people together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They are bound together for mutual benefit.

Vocabulary.mean: A bruise is a dark mark caused by being hit by something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. After the accident, his back was full of bruises.

Vocabulary.mean: A custom is a way of doing things that has been the same for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. What customs do you have for New Year in your country?

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is disobedient, they do not follow the rules or instructions.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My children are very disobedient.

Vocabulary.mean: To foresee something is to know about it before it happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It is impossible to foresee how life will work out.

Vocabulary.mean: To glimpse something is to see it for a short time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He caught a glimpse of her face.

Vocabulary.mean: A hoop is a ring that is made of plastic, metal, or wood.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The dogs had been trained to jump through hoops.

Vocabulary.mean: Misfortune is bad luck or an unlucky event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's unfair to take advantage of other people's misfortunes.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is negative, it is unpleasant or sad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We received a negative answer to our request.

Vocabulary.mean: Per is used to mean “each” when giving a price, size, or amount.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The tour will cost $100 per person.

Vocabulary.mean: To plead is to ask for something you want very badly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She pleaded with him not to go.

Vocabulary.mean: To rip something means to pull it apart.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His new trousers ripped when he bent down.

Vocabulary.mean: The sake of something is the reason for doing it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She gave up smoking for the sake of her health.

Vocabulary.mean: To scrape something is to rub it very hard with something sharp.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sheila scraped the snow off the windshield of her car.

Vocabulary.mean: A source of something is the place that it comes from.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Spinach is a good source of vitamins.

Vocabulary.mean: When somebody is stern, they are very serious.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police are planning sterner measures to combat crime.

Vocabulary.mean: To stitch is to use a needle and thread to join pieces of cloth together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her dress was stitched by hand.

Vocabulary.mean: A thump is the sound of a heavy object falling.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She fell to the floor with a thump.

Vocabulary.mean: When somebody is vehement, they are angry and emotional.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Their actions have led to the vehement protests of animal-rights groups.

Vocabulary.mean: A civilization is an organized group of humans that have culture and government
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some people think that nuclear war would mean the end of civilization.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is convenient, it is easy to do and does not take a lot of work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It is very convenient to pay by credit card.

Vocabulary.mean: A den is a living space for some types of animals, such as lions.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Bears live in their den during the winter.

Vocabulary.mean: Dew is the drops of water that form on the ground outside during the night.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The grass was wet with early morning dew.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is drastic, it is extreme or major.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In the desert there’s a drastic change in temperature from day to night.

Vocabulary.mean: To exit means to leave.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In case emergency, please exit by the side doors.

Vocabulary.mean: A flock is a group of animals, such as birds, sheep or goats.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The shepherd is bringing his flock down from the hills.

Vocabulary.mean: To fold is to bend something like paper or cloth so that it takes up less space.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I folded the letter and put it in an envelope.

Vocabulary.mean: A lid is a top for a box or container that can be removed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I can't get the lid off this jar.

Vocabulary.mean: To loom is to seem very large and often scary.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Dark storm clouds loomed on the horizon.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is mighty, it is strong and large.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He lift these boxes by his mighty hands.

Vocabulary.mean: A mushroom is a fungus with a round top. Some are used as food.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Would you like some mushroom soup for breakfast?

Vocabulary.mean: When something is native, it is originating in a certain place or area.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Panda is a native of China.

Vocabulary.mean: Poison is a dangerous substance that causes illness or death.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some mushrooms contain a deadly poison.

Vocabulary.mean: Reeds are tall and skinny plants that grow in groups near water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The edge of the lake is covered with reeds.

Vocabulary.mean: To shield something is to protect it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She held her hand above her eyes to shield them from the sun.

Vocabulary.mean: Stormy describes something affected or characterized by storms.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sky was dark and stormy.

Vocabulary.mean: To sway is to move slowly from side to side.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The trees were swaying in the wind.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is urban, it is related to the city.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The urban subway station is under construction.

Vocabulary.mean: To wade is to walk in or pass through water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We waded across the stream.

Vocabulary.mean: An accent is a certain way of speaking that shows where a person is from.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He spoke a southern accent so I couldn't understand what he was saying.

Vocabulary.mean: A barber is a person whose job is to cut hair.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He used to work as a barber.

Vocabulary.mean: A basement of a house or building is a room that is built underground.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I left the car in the basement.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is blank, it does not have anything on it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Viết tên của bạn vào tờ giấy trắng trên bàn.

Vocabulary.mean: To blink means to shut the eyes and quickly open them again.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He stared at her without blinking.

Vocabulary.mean: A choir is a group of people who sing together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He sings in the church choir.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is comic, it is funny.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The play is both comic and tragic.

Vocabulary.mean: To complicate something means to make it harder than necessary.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The rescue operation was complicated by bad weather.

Vocabulary.mean: To decline an offer or invitation means to say no to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She declined their job offer.

Vocabulary.mean: An errand is a trip taken to do a specific activity.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Mom asked me to do some errands for her.

Vocabulary.mean: A glove is a piece of clothing that covers your fingers and hand.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Remember to wear gloves because it is very cold outside.

Vocabulary.mean: A hermit is one who lives alone and does not spend time with others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The hermit lived a simple life in a small cave in the forest.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is done justly, then it is fair.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Vietnam is justly famous for its beautiful beaches.

Vocabulary.mean: Leather is a material made from animal skin that is used to make clothing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The jacket are made of leather.

Vocabulary.mean: To ponder something is to think about it carefully.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She pondered over his words.

Vocabulary.mean: To reserve something means to keep it for a certain person or time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm awfully sorry, but we've forgotten to reserve you a table.

Vocabulary.mean: A script is the words of a film or play.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's written the script for a number of successful movies.

Vocabulary.mean: To search for something or someone means to look for them carefully.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Rescue teams searched survivors from the wreckage.

Vocabulary.mean: To slam is to close something hard.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He slammed the door after him.

Vocabulary.mean: A staircase is a set of stairs found inside a building.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The staircase leads straight to the attic.

Vocabulary.mean: Afflicted means to suffer physically or mentally.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was afflicted by pain in his leg.

Vocabulary.mean: An aisle is a space between two things that people use to walk.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Coffee and tea are in the next aisle.

Vocabulary.mean: The atmosphere is the air around the Earth where weather conditions form.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These factories are releasing toxic gases into the atmosphere.

Vocabulary.mean: An author is a person who wrote a certain piece of writing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is the author of some best selling books.

Vocabulary.mean: A breakdown is a failure to work correctly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My car had a breakdown in the middle of the road.

Vocabulary.mean: Cargo is the items carried by a ship or airplane.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This is where the planes would land and unload their cargo.

Vocabulary.mean: A chapter is a part of a book that usually has a number or a title.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. After you've finished each chapter, run the spell-checker.

Vocabulary.mean: To connect two things means to join them together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Can I connect my printer to your computer?

Vocabulary.mean: Etc. is short for “etcetera.” It is used to refer to other unspecified objects.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We have seen many animals in the zoo: lions, tigers, elephants, etc.

Vocabulary.mean: To flip means to press a switch quickly to turn it on or off.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I flipped the book to look at the back cover.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are idle, you are not doing anything.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If you have an idle moment, call me.

Vocabulary.mean: To notify someone of something is to tell them about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We notified the police that the bicycle had been stolen.

Vocabulary.mean: Peas are a vegetable that is small, round and green.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Cook the peas by plunging them into boiling water.

Vocabulary.mean: A raisin is a dried grape.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sprinkle some raisins on the cake.

Vocabulary.mean: To retain something is to keep it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These plants need a rich soil which retains moisture.

Vocabulary.mean: To state something means to say it in a definite way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has already stated his intention to run for election.

Vocabulary.mean: A tray is a flat plate used to hold food.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was carrying a tray of drinks.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is unfortunate, it is bad or unlucky.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was unfortunate to lose in the final round.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is vivid, it is bright and colorful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was wearing a vivid shirt.

Vocabulary.mean: To vomit means to have food come up from one’s stomach.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He came home drunk and vomited all over the kitchen floor.

Vocabulary.mean: To betray someone means to treat them in a dishonest way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I trusted him and he betrayed me.

Vocabulary.mean: A blast is a loud noise made by something that explodes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The blast completely destroyed the building.

Vocabulary.mean: A bracelet is a piece of jewelry that you wear around your wrist.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has some bracelets in her jewellery box that she never wears.

Vocabulary.mean: To cease means to stop.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company ceased trading in June.

Vocabulary.mean: To choke means to cough because you have difficulty breathing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Peanuts can choke a small child.

Vocabulary.mean: When an event is civil, it happens inside a country.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The civil war had severe consequences.

Vocabulary.mean: To comment means to say something that shows your personal opinion.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She made helpful comments on my work.

Vocabulary.mean: To cross means to go from one side to the other side.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Cross the bridge and turn right.

Vocabulary.mean: A dent is damage caused by something heavy hitting something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The accident left a dent in my car.

Vocabulary.mean: To distrust someone means to believe that they are not honest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She distrusted his honesty.

Vocabulary.mean: A fort is a small building that is specially built to defend an area from attack.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They gathered troops to protect the fort.

Vocabulary.mean: To found means to bring something into existence.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He used all his savings to found an internet business.

Vocabulary.mean: Lining is a piece of cloth that covers the inside of clothes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The lining of my jacket is made of cotton.

Vocabulary.mean: A mass is a large number of things of one type.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A mass of snow falling down the mountain after the explosion.

Vocabulary.mean: To pray means to talk to God.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are praying for the victims of the earthquake.

Vocabulary.mean: If a place is rife with something bad, it is very common in that place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It is a country where corruption is rife.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is the sole thing, it is the only thing of a particular type.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was the sole survivor of the plane crash.

Vocabulary.mean: If you sweep the floor, you clean it with a tool like a broom or a brush.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She sweeps the street in front of her house.

Vocabulary.mean: Treachery is a behavior in which a person betrays a country or a person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was punished for his treacheries.

Vocabulary.mean: To tuck something means to put it somewhere so that it is neat or safe.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The letter had been tucked under a pile of papers.

Vocabulary.mean: A background is a person’s education, family, and experience.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The job would suit someone with a business background.

Vocabulary.mean: Bait is something used to trick a person or thing to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fishermen bought some worms to use as bait.

Vocabulary.mean: To chronicle something means to record an event or speech.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This book chronicles the life of Mark Twain.

Vocabulary.mean: Copper is a redmetal often used in electric wire and pipes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The wire core is usually made of copper.

Vocabulary.mean: A disease is an illness that causes specific problems.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The disease is spreading rapidly in this region.

Vocabulary.mean: Folklore is the collection of beliefs and stories of a culture.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Books of Grimm brothers are often based on folklore and fairy-tales.

Vocabulary.mean: To infect someone means to give them an illness.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Mosquitoes can infect people with malaria.

Vocabulary.mean: To itch means to rub the skin with your fingernails.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's a mosquito bite on my ankle that is itching like crazy!

Vocabulary.mean: Literature is books, plays, and poetry.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The course in English literature covers Shakespeare’s plays.

Vocabulary.mean: A millennium is one thousand years.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The book is a history of the last two millennia.

Vocabulary.mean: A myth is a traditional story that explains a culture’s history and beliefs.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Kids like the stories about the gods and goddesses of Greek and Roman myths.

Vocabulary.mean: To promote someone means to raise them to a higher position or rank.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was promoted to division manager last year.

Vocabulary.mean: To relate to something means to have a connection with it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. An increase in the unemployment rate is often directly related to government policies.

Vocabulary.mean: A religion is a belief in a god or gods.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This temple is a place of great holiness for the religion's followers.

Vocabulary.mean: A sum is a specific amount of money.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sum involved in the sale was not reported.

Vocabulary.mean: A teller is a person who works with a bank’s customers.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bank teller instructed me to fill out the form.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is trustworthy, they are honest and truthful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. At work, he is always a trustworthy person.

Vocabulary.mean: To update something means to make it more modern.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Software needs to be updated to the new version.

Vocabulary.mean: A vein is a tube in the body that carries blood toward the heart.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I could feel the blood pulsing through my veins.

Vocabulary.mean: Venom is a poisonous substance that comes from animals or plants.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Scientists use snake venom to make an antidote.

Vocabulary.mean: Charity is an act of giving help, usually money, to those who need it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She does a lot of work for charity.

Vocabulary.mean: Commerce is the activity of buying and selling things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They are trying to promote commerce between their countries.

Vocabulary.mean: To condemn someone means to give them a specific punishment.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The movie was condemned for glorifying violence.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is cozy, then it is comfortable, warm, and relaxing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fire made me feel cozy.

Vocabulary.mean: To deplete an amount of something means to use up all of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Food supplies were severely depleted.

Vocabulary.mean: An economy is the money and businesses of a country or region.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Tourism contributes millions of dollars to the region’s economy.

Vocabulary.mean: An empire is a large group of countries ruled by an emperor or empress.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These are the ruins of an ancient empire.

Vocabulary.mean: Goods are anything that can be bought or sold.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There is a 25% discount on all electrical goods until the end of the week.

Vocabulary.mean: To heed something means to obey or follow it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They failed to heed the lessons of history.

Vocabulary.mean: To hitchhike means to travel by asking for rides from passing vehicles.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They hitchhiked around Europe.

Vocabulary.mean: To mock someone means to tease them in a cruel way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He mocked her fat.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is neutral, then they do not help either of the two fighting sides.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Switzerland remained neutral during the war.

Vocabulary.mean: To persecute means to treat someone badly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government is implementing some measures to persecute its opponents.

Vocabulary.mean: Pity is the feeling of sadness and kindness for those who are suffering.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She did not want his pity.

Vocabulary.mean: To reduce something means to make it less in size or number.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The train reduced speed as it approached the station.

Vocabulary.mean: A scribe was a person whose job was to copy written works.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Before paper was common, medieval scribes used parchment or vellum.

Vocabulary.mean: A temper is someone’s mood or a chance that they might get angry.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's got a really bad temper.

Vocabulary.mean: A throne is the special chair in which a ruler sits.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The throne was carved from oak.

Vocabulary.mean: Unity is the state of people working together for a certain purpose.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Party unity is threatened when members will not compromise.

Vocabulary.mean: A victor is a group or person that wins in a contest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. At the end of the game, the red team was the victor.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is accurate, it is completely correct.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her novel is an accurate reflection of life in Spain.

Vocabulary.mean: To analyze something is to study it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This software is used to analyze marketing data.

Vocabulary.mean: An asteroid is a giant rock from outer space.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Scientists are hoping an asteroid will clue them in about early life on earth.

Vocabulary.mean: A controversy is a dispute about something that affects many people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There was a big controversy surrounding his latest movie.

Vocabulary.mean: To evolve is to change over time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Did humans evolve from apes?

Vocabulary.mean: A factor is something that has an effect on the way another thing happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Heavy snow was a contributing factor in the accident.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is genetic, it is related to the genes in one’s body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are about 4 000 inherited human genetic diseases.

Vocabulary.mean: A genome is the collection of all the genes in a living thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Understanding the human genome may help cure many diseases.

Vocabulary.mean: To be identical is to be the same as someone or something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The test is identical to the one you took last year.

Vocabulary.mean: An intellectual is a very smart person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her arguments lacked intellectual rigour.

Vocabulary.mean: A majority of something is almost all of the people or things in that group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The majority of the employees have university degrees.

Vocabulary.mean: A mammal is an animal that usually has hair and is not born from an egg.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Humans, dogs, elephants, and dolphins are all mammals.

Vocabulary.mean: To multiply is to increase in number.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The children are already learning to multiply and divide.

Vocabulary.mean: Offspring are the children of a person or the babies of an animal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Female badgers may give birth to as many as five offspring.

Vocabulary.mean: A pesticide is a substance used to kill insects.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Environmentalists called for cuts in pesticide use.

Vocabulary.mean: To regulate something is to control how it happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her mother strictly regulates how much TV she can watch.

Vocabulary.mean: To reinforce something is to make it stronger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He used information from these books to reinforce what he was saying.

Vocabulary.mean: If one is stricken by a disease or problem, they are badly affected by it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My country has been stricken by war for the past thirty years.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is vast, it is very large.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A vast audience watched the broadcast.

Vocabulary.mean: A vegetarian is someone who does not eat any meat products.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've been feeling much healthier since I became a vegetarian.

Vocabulary.mean: To cherish something means to hold it as very important.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We cherish the many memories we have of our dear mother.

Vocabulary.mean: Compassion is a feeling of understanding for someone who is hurt or suffering.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The doctor shows compassion for the patient of plane crash.

Vocabulary.mean: Consent is permission to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They can't publish your information without your consent.

Vocabulary.mean: The core is the center of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The earth's core is a hot, molten mix of iron and nickel.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is cunning, they are good at tricking people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was as cunning as a fox.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is dizzy, then they feel off balance as if they will fall down.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She felt dizzy and needed to sit down.

Vocabulary.mean: Equilibrium is the balance between different forces.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Government measures have created  an equilibrium in the economy.

Vocabulary.mean: To foster a feeling or a skill means to help it develop.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm trying to foster an interest in classical music in my children.

Vocabulary.mean: To grind something means to break it into very small pieces or powder.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Add a teaspoon of freshly ground black pepper.

Vocabulary.mean: To growl means to make a deep, angry sound.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The dog growled and bit her foot.

Vocabulary.mean: Moderation is a state of being just enough but not too much.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Moderation in eating and drinking is the way to stay healthy.

Vocabulary.mean: A predator is an animal that kills and eats other animals.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Survival is simply the relationship between predator and prey

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is sane, they can think in a normal way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. No sane person would do that.

Vocabulary.mean: A saucer is a small round dish that you set a cup on.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She gave the cat a saucer of milk.

Vocabulary.mean: To snatch something means to take it away with a quick motion.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He snatched the photos out of my hand.

Vocabulary.mean: To stagger means to move in an unsteady way and almost fall over.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He staggered home after drinking too much.

Vocabulary.mean: To stumble means to put your foot down wrong so that you almost fall.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Running along the beach, she stumbled on a log and fell on the sand.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is tense, they are worried something bad might happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was very tense as she waited for the interview.

Vocabulary.mean: To tumble means to fall, often in a rolling way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He slipped and tumbled down the stairs.

Vocabulary.mean: To withhold something is to not give it to someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Payment was withheld until the work was completed.

Vocabulary.mean: An aircraft is a vehicle that flies in the sky, such as an airplane or helicopter.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Attacks by enemy aircraft forced the tanks to retreat from the city.

Vocabulary.mean: A celebrity is someone who is famous.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Hollywood celebrities turned up at Laguna Beach.

Vocabulary.mean: Concrete is a substance made from stones.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The pathway is formed from large pebbles set in concrete.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is decisive, they make decisions quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You need to be more decisive.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is esteemed, many people like or respect them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It is my honor to introduce our esteemed senator.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ethical, it is the right thing to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It may be possible to clone human beings, but is it ethical?

Vocabulary.mean: If plants or animals are extinct, there are none left.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Koala is in danger of becoming extinct in Australia.

Vocabulary.mean: If a person or plant is hardy, it is strong and can live though difficult conditions.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These plants are quite hardy, and can withstand a frost.

Vocabulary.mean: An institute is an organization that is interested in research or teaching.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The institute will invest 1 million in the project.

Vocabulary.mean: Jealousy is a feeling of wanting something that somebody else has.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I felt so jealous when he got a new bike.

Vocabulary.mean: To migrate means to move from one place to another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In winter, these birds migrate south.

Vocabulary.mean: To nurture something means to care for it as it grows or develops.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. As a record company director, his job is to nurture young talent.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is overhead, it is located above you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Planes flew overhead constantly.

Vocabulary.mean: A principle is a belief about the correct way to behave.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He refused to compromise his principles.

Vocabulary.mean: If a place is rural, it is in the countryside instead of the city.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There is a gap between rich and poor between rural and urban areas.

Vocabulary.mean: If a place is secluded, it is far away from any other place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We managed to find a fairly secluded spot for our picnic.

Vocabulary.mean: A species is a type of plant or animal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Mountain gorillas are an endangered species.

Vocabulary.mean: A swamp is a very wet area of land.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Alligators live in these swamps.

Vocabulary.mean: To traverse means to move or travel through an area.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Stanley traversed the continent from west to east.

Vocabulary.mean: Zoology is a subject in which people study animals.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. John wants to study zoology because he has always liked animals.

Vocabulary.mean: An assumption is something that you believe is true but cannot prove.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His actions were based on a false assumption.

Vocabulary.mean: Barley is a grain that is used for animal feed, health food and beer.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Farmers are harvesting barley in the field.

Vocabulary.mean: A beast is a large, dangerous animal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Children love to hear stories about mythical beasts like unicorns and dragons.

Vocabulary.mean: A colonel is a military officer.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. James has been given a promotion in the army. He is now a colonel.

Vocabulary.mean: If a disease is contagious, it is easily carried from one person to another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Be careful, this disease is very contagious.

Vocabulary.mean: A corpse is a dead body of a human.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The corpse was in an stage of decomposition.

Vocabulary.mean: A crisis is a situation that is extremely stressful or dangerous.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The country is in the midst of an economic crisis.

Vocabulary.mean: To cure means to cause an illness or injury to end or disappear.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The medicine won't cure her, it merely stops the pain.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is deformed, it is not shaped normally and may appear ugly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The child was born with a deformed hand.

Vocabulary.mean: To discriminate means to judge people according to their looks.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She felt she had been discriminated against because of her age.

Vocabulary.mean: An embassy is where government officials work in a foreign country.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Soldiers guard the main doors of the embassy.

Vocabulary.mean: To extinguish a fire means to make it stop.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It took the firefighters several hours to extinguish the flames.

Vocabulary.mean: Flint is a hard stone that people used to make weapons for hunting.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are a lot of flint tools in the museum.

Vocabulary.mean: To harass someone means to annoy or trouble them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She felt she was being harassed by the coach’s constant demands.

Vocabulary.mean: To integrate means to join, communicate and socialize.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He seems to find it difficult to integrate socially.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is miniature, it is very small.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I bought some miniature furniture for my niece's doll's house.

Vocabulary.mean: Nutrition is the process by which people use food to stay healthy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Good nutrition is essential if patients are to make a quick recovery.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens promptly, it happens quickly or on time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We try to answer email as promptly as we can.

Vocabulary.mean: A technician is a person who is skilled in electronic or mechanical work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I need to call the technician to help me with my laptop.

Vocabulary.mean: The tropics are the areas of land and sea close to the equator.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. People like to go to the tropics for vacation because it’s warm.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is beneficial, it is good for you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Only some bacteria are harmful, many are beneficial.

Vocabulary.mean: A birthplace is a place where a person is born or where something started.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Hawaii was the birthplace of surfing.

Vocabulary.mean: The capacity of something is the amount of things that can be put in it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The stadium has a seating capacity of 50,000.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is comparative, it is being judged based on something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's carrying out a comparative study of health in inner cities and rural areas.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is comprehensive, it has all the details about something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The book gives a comprehensive view of the English Civil War.

Vocabulary.mean: To conserve something is to protect it from being ruined or used completely.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In order to conserve fuel, they put in extra insulation.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is crucial, it is extremely important to another thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Price will be a crucial factor in the success of this new product.

Vocabulary.mean: Cumulative describes an increase by adding one after another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company estimated the net cumulative loss would be $26 million.

Vocabulary.mean: To deposit something is to put it into a place or another thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The cat deposited a dead mouse at my door.

Vocabulary.mean: To distribute something is to give it to a number of people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The books will be distributed free to local schools.

Vocabulary.mean: The equator is an imaginary line that splits the Earth into north and south.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Brazil lies on the equator.

Vocabulary.mean: Exotic describes something unusual because it is from far away.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She travels to all kinds of exotic locations all over the world.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is federal, it comes from the government of a country.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They were charged with federal law.

Vocabulary.mean: A formation is the way that something is made.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The formation of cloud happens when water evaporates.

Vocabulary.mean: The frequency of something is the number of times that it happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The frequency of accidents has decreased over the past year.

Vocabulary.mean: An objective is a goal or plan that someone has.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our main objective is to improve the company's productivity.

Vocabulary.mean: Oxygen is a gas that all living things need to breathe.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Air is composed mainly of nitrogen and oxygen.

Vocabulary.mean: A rainforest is a forest that is in a place where it rains very often.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Amazon river basin contains the world's largest tropical rainforest.

Vocabulary.mean: A strategy is a plan for how to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Chess is a game that requires strategy.

Vocabulary.mean: If an area is wooded, it is covered with trees.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We camped on a wooded hills.

Vocabulary.mean: Avail is help. It is often used in the achievement of a goal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My attempts to improve the situation were of no avail.

Vocabulary.mean: To expand is to become bigger in size.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are no plans to expand the local airport.

Vocabulary.mean: To define means to clearly state, show, or explain what something is.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It is very difficult to define the concept of beauty.

Vocabulary.mean: To dread is to be afraid of something that could, or is going to, happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's dreading the exam, he's sure he's going to fail.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is fundamental, it is a basic part of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There is a fundamental difference between the two points of view.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is horrifying, it is frightening and very unpleasant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I witnessed a  horrifying car accident yesterday.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is incredulous about something, they do not believe that it is true.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was incredulous that monkeys could escape.

Vocabulary.mean: To linger is to last for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The smell of her perfume still lingers around here.

Vocabulary.mean: An organism is a living thing, especially a very small one.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Amoebae and bacteria are single celled organisms.

Vocabulary.mean: To paraphrase is to make someone else’s writing or speech shorter.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Try to paraphrase the question before you answer it.

Vocabulary.mean: A plague is a serious disease that quickly spreads to many people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Millions of people die from plague every year.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens presently, it is happening right now.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We will be leaving presently.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is random, it happens without any pattern or reason.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The security guards carried out random checks on people entering the building.

Vocabulary.mean: A riot is a crowd that reacts to bad news by violently breaking laws.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police quickly smashed the riots in the city.

Vocabulary.mean: To scribble is to write something quickly without caring about how it looks.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My son scribbled a few words on a postcard.

Vocabulary.mean: A shrine is a religious building built to honor a person, event, or god.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are visiting the ancient shrine in India.

Vocabulary.mean: Solitude is the state of being totally alone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I returned to the solitude of my room.

Vocabulary.mean: If a contrast is stark, then the things being compared are utterly different.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The good weather was in stark contrast to the storms of previous weeks.

Vocabulary.mean: To summon a person is to ask them to come to you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have been summoned to appear in court.

Vocabulary.mean: To worsen is to get worse.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His health has worsened considerably since we last saw him.

Vocabulary.mean: An automobile is a car.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The automobile industry is growing strongly.

Vocabulary.mean: A candidate is a person who is competing to win something such as a job.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We have interviewed some candidates for this position.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is confidential, it must be kept secret.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A person's medical records are confidential.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is corporate, it is related to a large business.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company's guests are entertained in the corporate hospitality area.

Vocabulary.mean: To enhance something is to make it better.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The spices enhances the flavor of the fish.

Vocabulary.mean: An era is a period of time that has something special about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fall of the Berlin wall marked the end of an era.

Vocabulary.mean: A guideline is a rule about how to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The article gives guidelines on how to invest your money safely.

Vocabulary.mean: To incorporate is to add something to another thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The program incorporates a powerful graphics tool.

Vocabulary.mean: To interact is to talk to or do something with another person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Teachers have a limited amount of time to interact with each child.

Vocabulary.mean: An interval is the time between two things happening.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If there is a fire, the alarm will sound at 15-second intervals.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is mobile, it can be moved easily.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The equipment is not really mobile.

Vocabulary.mean: To modify something is to change it a little bit.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We decided to modify some terms of the contract.

Vocabulary.mean: If two things are parallel, they are the same distance away from each other.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The two roads are parallel.

Vocabulary.mean: A phenomenon is something that can be seen as it is happening.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Gravity is a natural phenomenon.

Vocabulary.mean: To pollute means to make air, water, or land dirty, unclean, or foul.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Smoke from factories pollutes the surrounding environment.

Vocabulary.mean: To ridicule is to make fun of something in a mean way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She rarely spoke her mind out of fear of being ridiculed.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is solar, it is related to the sun.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Scientists are searching for intelligent life forms in other solar systems.

Vocabulary.mean: A territory is a piece of land that belongs to a country but isn’t a state.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This area is a disputed territory.

Vocabulary.mean: A tournament is a competition, usually with many people participating.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The tennis tournament is held annually in September.

Vocabulary.mean: Transportation is any type of vehicle that can carry people or things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The city is providing free transportation to the stadium from downtown.

Vocabulary.mean: A bill is a statement of money owed for goods or a service.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She always pays her bills on time.

Vocabulary.mean: A boundary is the line where one area of land stops, and another begins.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You can camp anywhere inside the boundaries of the park.

Vocabulary.mean: Chaos is a situation that is confusing and not ordered.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There was chaos in the theatre when the bomb went off.

Vocabulary.mean: If a person is consistent, they keep the same behavior or attitude.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has been Milan's most consistent player this season.

Vocabulary.mean: A cyclone is a large storm with heavy rain and winds that spin in a circle.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A powerful cyclone has caused serious damage to the city.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is doomed, they are going to fail or be destroyed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This is a doomed city.

Vocabulary.mean: An heir is a person who receives money or property of someone who dies.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The prince was the only heir to the throne.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is martial, it is related to fighting or war.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Kungfu là môn võ bắt đầu tại Trung Quốc.

Vocabulary.mean: If food is organic, it is grown without adding chemicals to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The restaurant only uses organic ingredients.

Vocabulary.mean: Poultry is a bird, such as a chicken, that is used for meat and eggs.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They raise poultry on their farm.

Vocabulary.mean: To scramble is to move somewhere quickly and desperately.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We scrambled up the hill.

Vocabulary.mean: A sergeant is a soldier or police officer of middle rank.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The captain was demoted to sergeant for failing to fulfil his duties.

Vocabulary.mean: If you describe something as sheer, it is complete and very strong.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The concert was sheer delight.

Vocabulary.mean: A stance is an attitude about an issue that someone states clearly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government's stance on the issue of tax cuts is well known.

Vocabulary.mean: A telegraph is a method of sending electric messages on wires.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In the 1900s, the telegraph was the fastest way to send a message.

Vocabulary.mean: Textile is cloth that has been woven or knitted.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Imports of textiles rose last year.

Vocabulary.mean: A tornado is a tube shaped formation of air that spins very quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The tornado will land on the south coast tomorrow.

Vocabulary.mean: A typhoon is a large tropical storm that moves in circles.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We had to cancel the travel because of the typhoon.

Vocabulary.mean: To wail is to show sadness by crying loudly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The little girl was wailing miserably when her favorite toy broken.

Vocabulary.mean: A wardrobe is the collection of all of a person’s clothing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has a different wardrobe for every occasion.

Vocabulary.mean: To allot something means to give it to someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The board allotted $5000 to the recreation center.

Vocabulary.mean: To appall means to horrify, shock, or disgust someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The thought of having to do it all again appals me.

Vocabulary.mean: A cache is a hiding place for valuable things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The robber kept a hidden cache of $2,500 in a box under the bed.

Vocabulary.mean: Convenience is a state of being able to do something with little effort.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Repairs were scheduled at the customer’s convenience.

Vocabulary.mean: A dearth is an amount or supply which is not large enough.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The region is suffering from a dearth of medical specialists.

Vocabulary.mean: If a thing you do is deliberate, you intend to do it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He accused her of writing deliberate untruths.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is dire, it is terrible and very serious.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Cheating will bring dire consequences.

Vocabulary.mean: To elapse means to pass, as in seconds, minutes, or hours.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Four years had elapsed since she last saw him.

Vocabulary.mean: Empathy is sharing or understanding another person’s feelings.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He loves children and has a certain empathy with them.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is fanciful, it is unusual or unrealistic.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The girl had fanciful ideas about having a lot of money without working..

Vocabulary.mean: To gripe means to complain constantly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her main gripe is that she's not being trained properly.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is grueling, it is very hard to do.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've had a gruelling day.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is mundane, it is boring, common, or ordinary.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The show was just another mundane family sitcom.

Vocabulary.mean: To opt is to make a choice, especially when deciding in favor of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Mike opted for early retirement.

Vocabulary.mean: Outrage is a very strong emotion of anger or shock.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. When the truth came out, there was public outrage.

Vocabulary.mean: When an amount of something is paltry, it is very small.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They worked long hours for paltry wages.

Vocabulary.mean: To rectify something means to correct it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We must take steps to rectify the situation.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is resourceful, they are good at dealing with hard situations.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's a very resourceful manager.

Vocabulary.mean: Sustenance is food and water needed to keep a person, animal, or plant alive.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Cattle get a lot of their sustenance from grazing.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is tedious, it is long, frustrating, and boring.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The problem is I find learning so tedious.

Vocabulary.mean: An abbey is a house or group of houses where monks or nuns live.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The abbey was completely rebuilt in 1503 after it had been destroyed by fire.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is abundant, then it is available in large quantities.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It is a region with abundant natural resources.

Vocabulary.mean: To adjoin something means to be next to or attached to something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The toilet adjoins to the bedroom.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ample, then it is enough or more than enough.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There will be ample opportunity for everyone here to speak.

Vocabulary.mean: If a place is arid, then it is hot and dry and gets very little or no rain.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The desert is so arid that nothing can grow there.

Vocabulary.mean: A cathedral is an important and often large and beautifully built church.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I was woken up by the chimes of the cathedral bells.

Vocabulary.mean: To deprive someone of something means to not let them have it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. If you deprive a child of affection, they can become very withdrawn.

Vocabulary.mean: A drought is a long period of time in which little or no rain falls.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This year severe drought has ruined the crops.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is eligible, then they are permitted to do or have something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Only people over 18 are eligible to vote.

Vocabulary.mean: To fast means to go without food or drink for a period of time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. One day a week he fasts for health reasons.

Vocabulary.mean: To grumble means to complain.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She spent the evening grumbling to me about her job.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone goes inland, they travel into the center of a country or land.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We left the coast and headed inland.

Vocabulary.mean: Moisture is small drops of water in the air or on a surface.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It was a clear day with little moisture in the air.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens nonetheless, then it occurs despite some other thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The book is too long but, nonetheless, informative and entertaining.

Vocabulary.mean: An oath is a formal, often public, promise.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You are bound by oath to tell the truth.

Vocabulary.mean: A prairie is a large flat area of grassland.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Herds of cattle are grazed in the prairie.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ragged, then it is old, torn, and falling apart.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The children were wearing dirty, ragged clothes.

Vocabulary.mean: If an area of land is rugged, then it is rocky and difficult to travel through.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They admired the rugged beauty of the coastline.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is scarce, then it is in a very small amount.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This is a huge waste of scarce resources.

Vocabulary.mean: To speculate means to guess about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's useless to speculate without more information.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is analytic, it is related to logic and reasoning.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some students have a more analytical approach to learning.

Vocabulary.mean: To assert a fact or belief means to state it with confidence.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The companies have asserted that everything they did was appropriate.

Vocabulary.mean: A bachelor is an unmarried man.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was 38, and a confirmed bachelor.

Vocabulary.mean: Calculus is an advanced type of mathematics.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. By using calculus, scientists determined small changes in the stars’ brightness.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is celestial, it is related to the sky or to outer space.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The moon is a celestial body.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is cognitive, it is related to learning and knowing things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This is both a cognitive and an emotional process.

Vocabulary.mean: A collision is the act of two things hitting into each another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The collision involved a truck and a car.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is competent, they are able to think or act successfully.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's very competent in his work.

Vocabulary.mean: A diploma is a certificate proving that someone has completed their studies.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She is taking a diploma in management studies.

Vocabulary.mean: To excel at a subject or activity means to be very good at it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Rebecca always excelled in languages at school.

Vocabulary.mean: Geology is the study of the Earth’s natural structures and how they change.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He studied geology at university.

Vocabulary.mean: To harness something means to control and use it, usually to make energy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There is a great deal of interest in harnessing wind and waves as new sources of power.

Vocabulary.mean: An intellect is a person’s ability to understand things easily.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His intellect is an invaluable asset.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is keen, they are intelligent.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is the keenest student in my class.

Vocabulary.mean: Mythology is a group of stories from a particular country or region.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We enjoyed learning about Egyptian mythology.

Vocabulary.mean: Physiology is the study of the various parts of living things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He works at the department of anatomy and physiology.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is radioactive, then it lets out, or is related to, radiation.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Uranium is a radioactive material.

Vocabulary.mean: Relativity is a set of ideas about time and space developed by Albert Einstein.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are learning Einstein’s theory of relativity.

Vocabulary.mean: Sociology is the study of human society, its organizations, and problems.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has a degree in sociology and politics.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is theoretical, it is based on theory rather than experience.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The first year provides students with a sound theoretical basis for later study.

Vocabulary.mean: An administrator is a person who controls a business, company, or organization.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She works as a school administrator.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is affluent, they are wealthy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We live in an affluent neighborhood.

Vocabulary.mean: To audit means to inspect financial records from a person or business.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The accounts are audited annually.

Vocabulary.mean: To automate a company means to install machines or computers to do the work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The entire manufacturing process has been automated.

Vocabulary.mean: To bribe someone means to illegally persuade them for a favor with money.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They bribe the company leadership to gain a competitive advantage.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is corrupt, they break the law for money or fame.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Corrupt officials accepting bribes is serious problem.

Vocabulary.mean: To dispose of something means to get rid of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She disposed of the bottle by throwing it into the recycle bin.

Vocabulary.mean: A headquarters is a building where the bosses of a company work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company's headquarter is in New York.

Vocabulary.mean: An incentive is what makes a person want to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Bonus payments provide an incentive to work harder.

Vocabulary.mean: An infrastructure is a collection of services needed to run a society or business.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The war has badly damaged the country's infrastructure.

Vocabulary.mean: To legislate means to make laws.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government will legislate against discrimination in the workplace.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is legitimate, then it is acceptable according to the law.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her complaints were quite legitimate.

Vocabulary.mean: To manipulate something means to skillfully or unfairly control or affect it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She uses her charm to manipulate people.

Vocabulary.mean: Merchandise is goods ready to be purchased or sold.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This store has a wide selection of merchandise for sale.

Vocabulary.mean: Retail is the activity of selling goods to the public, often for personal use.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The recommended retail price is £9.99.

Vocabulary.mean: Revenue is the income made by a company.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company's annual revenues rose by 30%.

Vocabulary.mean: Rubbish is trash or waste.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I forgot to put the rubbish out this morning.

Vocabulary.mean: A subsidy is money given by the government to companies to assist them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company received a substantial government subsidy.

Vocabulary.mean: A transaction is an act of buying or selling something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There was no financial transaction between us last year.

Vocabulary.mean: To violate a law, rule, or agreement means to break it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The policeman said I violated the speed limit.

Vocabulary.mean: To assess something means to judge the structure, purpose, or quality of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They couldn't agree the way to assess their students.

Vocabulary.mean: To astonish someone means to greatly surprise them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The news astonished everyone.
