Vocabulary.mean: To commence something means to begin it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The meeting is scheduled to commence at noon.

Vocabulary.mean: The essence of something is its important qualities or basic characteristics.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The essence of your situation isn't so different from mine.

Vocabulary.mean: To extract something means to remove it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They extract the oil from the seeds for use in cooking and manufacturing.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is fabulous, it is extremely good.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She looked absolutely fabulous in her dress.

Vocabulary.mean: Haste is speed in movement or action.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In spite of all their haste, they didn’t have time to finish.

Vocabulary.mean: An impulse is a sudden thoughtless urge to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He had a sudden impulse to  sing in front of the crowd.

Vocabulary.mean: Latter describes something last in a series or the second choice of two things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The latter point is the most important.

Vocabulary.mean: A molecule is the smallest basic unit that makes up a physical substance.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A molecule of water consists of two atoms of hydrogen and one atom of oxygen.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ongoing, then it is still happening or still growing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police investigation is ongoing.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is pharmaceutical, then it is related to the development of drugs.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The pharmaceutical industry has brought a great revenue to the country.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is precise, then they are exact and careful about their work.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We don't know the precise details of the story yet.

Vocabulary.mean: Proximity is closeness in time, space, or relationships.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The area has a number of schools in close proximity to each other.

Vocabulary.mean: Publicity is public attention given to someone or something by the media.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His speech attracted a lot of publicity.

Vocabulary.mean: A remedy is a cure for a disease, argument, or problem.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are taking a number of remedies for this problem.

Vocabulary.mean: The significance of something is the quality that makes it important.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The new drug has great significance for the treatment of the disease.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is subsequent, then it comes after something else in time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bugs have been fixed in subsequent versions of the software.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is synthetic, then it is made to be like something natural.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Products of the company are made of synthetic fabrics.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is terminal, then it causes or results in death.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She had a terminal lung disease.

Vocabulary.mean: The altitude of a place is its height above sea level.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are flying at an altitude of 6 000 metres.

Vocabulary.mean: A coastline is the outline of a country’s coast.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They are taking emergency measures to protect the coastline from oil spillage

Vocabulary.mean: To deter means to prevent or discourage someone from doing something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. High prices are deterring a lot of young couples from buying houses.

Vocabulary.mean: To devise something means to have an idea or plan about it in the mind.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A new system has been devised to control traffic in the city.

Vocabulary.mean: Expertise is the knowledge and skills to do something well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is a logical choice given his expertise in consumer marketing.

Vocabulary.mean: A fracture is a crack or break in something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A fractured pipe at a steelworks has leaked 20 tons of oil into the Severn estuary.

Vocabulary.mean: To impair something means to damage it or make it worse.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Lack of sleep impaired her ability to think clearly.

Vocabulary.mean: To implement something means to ensure that what has been planned is done.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A new programme will be implemented.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is indigenous, it is originally from, or native to, a place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The kangaroo is indigenous to Australia.

Vocabulary.mean: Insight is a deep and accurate understanding of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The research affords a new insight into the origins of the human.

Vocabulary.mean: A limb is a large branch on a tree.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He fell down from the tree limb and broken his leg.

Vocabulary.mean: A migraine is a painful headache that makes one feel sick.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I forgot to take my migraine medication.

Vocabulary.mean: Optimism is the feeling of being hopeful about the future or success of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her optimism seemed to infect all those around her.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is peculiar, it is strange, sometimes in a bad way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has the most peculiar ideas.

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is proficient at something, they can do it well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's proficient in two languages.

Vocabulary.mean: A quest is a long and difficult search for something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In his quest for physical perfection, he spends hours in the gym.

Vocabulary.mean: A ridge is a long, narrow piece of raised land.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We walked along the narrow mountain ridge.

Vocabulary.mean: A spouse is the person to whom someone is married.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. With this type of visa, you can bring your spouse upon entry.

Vocabulary.mean: To thrust means to push or move something quickly with a lot of force.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She thrust the baby into my arms and ran off.

Vocabulary.mean: To tolerate something means to be able to accept it even when it is unpleasant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Your behaviour will not be tolerated.

Vocabulary.mean: If a plant or animal is aquatic, it lives or grows in water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. White shark is a aquatic dangerous creature.

Vocabulary.mean: The biosphere is the earth’s surface and atmosphere where there are living things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are millions of species living in the biosphere.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is bizarre, it is very strange.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. That party was too bizarre for me!

Vocabulary.mean: Celsius is a scale for measuring temperature.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Water boils at one hundred degrees Celsius.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is coarse, that means it has a rough texture.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have just bought a coarse linen shirts.

Vocabulary.mean: A companion is a person that someone spends a lot of time with.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She went travelling with a female companion.

Vocabulary.mean: To digest means to swallow food and pass it through the body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Eating too fast will make it harder to digest food.

Vocabulary.mean: The duration of an event is the time during which it happens.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He plans to work at this company of two years' duration.

Vocabulary.mean: Ecology is the study of the environment and living things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The oil spill caused terrible damage to the fragile ecology of the coast.

Vocabulary.mean: A feat is an impressive or difficult achievement or action.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Getting the house painted was quite a feat.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is infinite, it has no limit or end.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Human potential is infinite.

Vocabulary.mean: The nucleus is the central part of an atom or cell.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. DNA is stored in the nucleus of a cell.

Vocabulary.mean: A parasite is a tiny animal or plant that attaches to another animal to get food.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He became infected with the parasite after traveling to the rainforest.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is prominent, it is important and well known.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She plays a prominent role in the organization.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is repetitive, it is repeated many times and becomes boring.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I was too bored with a repetitive job.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is reproductive, it has to do with a living thing producing young.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The reproductive system of human is complex.

Vocabulary.mean: When a place is temperate, it never gets too hot or cold.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The climate here is pretty temperate.

Vocabulary.mean: Tolerance is the ability to accept something painful or unpleasant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I don’t have much tolerance for hot, humid weather.

Vocabulary.mean: To undergo an action means to have it happen to you.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The patient undergoes treatments twice a week.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is vulnerable, they are weak and without protection.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She looked very vulnerable standing there on her own.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is adept at something, they are very good at doing it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He’s adept at making people feel at ease.

Vocabulary.mean: If land is barren, it has no plants growing on it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are trying to renovate this barren area.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ceramic, it is made of baked clay.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Flowers are grown in ceramic pots.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is culinary, it is related to cooking.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My cooking skills will improved after this course.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is dense, it has a lot of things close together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We drove through the dense fog.

Vocabulary.mean: Dignity is the ability to be calm and worthy of respect.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Laws of privacy are designed to protect the dignity of individuals.

Vocabulary.mean: To dominate someone or something is to control them.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is edible, you can eat it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some mushrooms are edible.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is hostile, they are angry and unfriendly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her parents were openly hostile to me.

Vocabulary.mean: Your intake of food is the amount of food you take into your body.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Reduce your daily intake of salt will make you healthier.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone does something likewise, they do the same thing as someone else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He exercises after work and I want to do the likewise.

Vocabulary.mean: Malnutrition is the condition of not getting enough nutrients.

Vocabulary.mean: Medication is medicine or drugs given to people who are sick.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Are you taking any medications now?

Vocabulary.mean: A misconception is a wrong idea about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It’s a misconception that he thinks only about money.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is obscure, it is not well-known.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Official policy has changed for reasons that remain obscure.

Vocabulary.mean: To oppress someone means to rule over them in a cruel and unfair way.

Vocabulary.mean: To peel fruits and vegetables is to remove their skin.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Can you help me peel carrots?

Vocabulary.mean: A prescription is permission from a doctor to get medicine.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The doctor gave me a prescription for antibiotics.

Vocabulary.mean: A respirator is a machine that helps weak or sick people breathe.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The firefighters wore respirators to help them breathe in the smoke-filled house.

Vocabulary.mean: To strive is to struggle to achieve something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We strive to ensure that all children are treated equally.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is archaic, it is very old or outdated.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is benevolent, they are kind and generous.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was a benevolent old man and wouldn't hurt a fly.

Vocabulary.mean: Brass is a metal that is used to make musical instruments and ornaments.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The door handles were made of brass.

Vocabulary.mean: Capitalism is an economic system where private companies make goods for profit.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The professor is distinguishing between capitalism and socialism.

Vocabulary.mean: A component is a part of a larger machine.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The factory supplies electrical components for cars.

Vocabulary.mean: Dependence is a situation in which somebody relies on something else.

Vocabulary.mean: To diminish means to reduce or get smaller.

Vocabulary.mean: A drawback is a disadvantage.

Vocabulary.mean: A fad is something that is popular for a short time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He thought Bitcoin would be just a fad.

Vocabulary.mean: To impose means to interrupt or force your ideas on other people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Very high taxes have recently been imposed on cigarettes.

Vocabulary.mean: Managerial describes something related to a manager or management.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This position requires managerial skills.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is medieval, it comes from the period between 650 and 1500 CE.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This church is a perfect example of medieval architecture.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is obsolete, it is not used anymore because something better exists.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Gas lamps became obsolete when electric lighting was invented.

Vocabulary.mean: A peninsula is a large piece of land that is surrounded by the sea on three sides.

Vocabulary.mean: If a person has prestige, people admire or respect them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company has gained international prestige.

Vocabulary.mean: A proportion is an amount that shows the link between the parts and the whole.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Water covers a large proportion of the earth's surface.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is radical, it is very new or different.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was known as a radical politician.

Vocabulary.mean: To refute something means to prove that it is false or incorrect.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has refuted the claims that he behaved unprofessionally.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is spectacular, it looks or sounds very impressive.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The scenery is spectacular.

Vocabulary.mean: To weave means to make cloth using horizontal and vertical threads.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. How long does it take to weave three yards of cloth?

Vocabulary.mean: An accountant is a person whose job is to keep financial accounts.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I applied for a position as an accountant in the company.

Vocabulary.mean: A capitalist is a business person who invests in trade and industry for profit.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are calling on capitalists to invest in the project.

Vocabulary.mean: Contempt is the feeling of having no respect for something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She looked at him with contempt.

Vocabulary.mean: To dedicate oneself to something means to put a lot of time and effort into it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has dedicated his life to scientific research.

Vocabulary.mean: A ditch is a narrow hole cut into the ground by a road or a field.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The car fell into the ditch after trying to avoid a cow.

Vocabulary.mean: An enterprise is a company or business.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They run a private enterprise in their local town.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is exquisite, it is very beautiful or pleasant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Look at this exquisite painting.

Vocabulary.mean: To finance someone or something means to provide money for them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Investors has agreed to finance our project.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is indifferent toward something, they have a lack of interest in it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government cannot afford to be indifferent to public opinion.

Vocabulary.mean: To irrigate means to supply water to land so that crops can grow.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They use airplanes to irrigate the fields.

Vocabulary.mean: To maximize something is to make it as great in amount, size, or importance.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company's top goal is to maximize profits.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is monetary, it relates to money.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government uses tight monetary policy to curb inflation.

Vocabulary.mean: A precaution is an action that is meant to stop something bad from happening.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Many people have been stockpiling food as a precaution against shortages.

Vocabulary.mean: Preliminary describes something that happens before a more important event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The preliminary results are very positive.

Vocabulary.mean: To saturate something means to completely soak it with a liquid.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The heavy rains saturate the ground.

Vocabulary.mean: The simplicity of something is the fact that it is easy to do or understand.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The advantage of the plan is its simplicity.

Vocabulary.mean: To sow seeds means to plant them in the ground.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sow the seeds in a pot and water them daily.

Vocabulary.mean: Soy is a food made from soybeans, such as flour or butter.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This year, we will plant soy on the field near our home.

Vocabulary.mean: A spade is a tool used for digging.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My son used his spade to make a hole in the garden.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is upcoming, that means it will happen in the near future.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Tickets for the group's upcoming tour are about to go on sale.

Vocabulary.mean: When a bad thing is acute, it is very severe and intense.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was suffering from acute heart pains.

Vocabulary.mean: Aggression is behavior that is mean or violent to others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You have to learn to control your aggression in order to avoid serious conflict.

Vocabulary.mean: A banquet is a grand formal meal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Medieval banquets are held in the castle once a month.

Vocabulary.mean: A biography is an account of someone’s life that is written by someone else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He wrote a biography of Winston Churchill.

Vocabulary.mean: To boost something means to increase or improve it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. More money is needed to boost the industry.

Vocabulary.mean: To clap means to hit one’s hands together to express pleasure or get attention.

Vocabulary.mean: To compel someone to do something means to force them to do it.

Vocabulary.mean: The dominance of a person is their state of being more powerful than others.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is gorgeous, it is very pleasing and attractive.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is inevitable, it is certain to happen or cannot be avoided.

Vocabulary.mean: A legacy is an effect that exists because of a person or thing in the past.

Vocabulary.mean: A masterpiece is a very good painting, novel, movie, or other work of art.

Vocabulary.mean: If there are multiple things, there are many of them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He suffered multiple injuries in a motorcycle accident.

Vocabulary.mean: To narrate a story means to write about it or read it aloud.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She is narrating her adventures in Africa.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is notorious, it is well because of something bad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company is notorious for paying its bills late.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is outdated, it is old and no longer useful in modern time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These figures are now outdated.

Vocabulary.mean: When a thing is talked about overall, the whole thing is considered.

Vocabulary.mean: To applaud means to clap in order to show approval.

Vocabulary.mean: When things are compatible, they work well or exist together successfully.

Vocabulary.mean: When things are consecutive, they happen one after another without interruption.

Vocabulary.mean: To disprove something means to show that it is not true.

Vocabulary.example: e.g. Magnets are used to attach paper to the board.

Vocabulary.mean: A person’s metabolism is the way chemical processes in their body use energy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Exercise is supposed to speed up your metabolism.

Vocabulary.mean: A microchip is a small device inside a computer that holds information.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A more powerful chip will help the computer process data faster.

Vocabulary.mean: A phase is a stage in a process or the gradual development of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We're now entering the final phase of the project.

Vocabulary.mean: To pinch means to take a piece of skin between one’s fingers and squeeze.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I had to pinch myself so I’d know I wasn’t dreaming.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is prevalent, it is common.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These diseases are more prevalent among young children.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is quantum, it relates to the behavior of atomic particles.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The students are studying quantum mechanics.

Vocabulary.mean: A ratio is a relationship between two things expressed in numbers or amounts.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The ratio of exports to imports also improved from 70.4% to 83.2%.

Vocabulary.mean: A spiral is a shape which winds round and round in a larger and larger circle.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A corkscrew is made in a spiral.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is viral, it is a disease or infection that is caused by a virus.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Young man has a viral infection.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are astounded, you are very surprised.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I was astounded to hear that Tina had left.

Vocabulary.mean: An attribute is a characteristic of a person or thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Patience is one of the most important attributes in a teacher.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is bilingual, then they can speak two languages.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is bilingual in Japanese and English.

Vocabulary.mean: A clone is an identical copy of a living creature.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Scientists recently made a clone of a dog.

Vocabulary.mean: Colloquial describes informal words that are more suitable for speech than writing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He always uses colloquial language.

Vocabulary.mean: Cosmetics are substances that make the face and skin more beautiful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She found a job selling cosmetics.

Vocabulary.mean: To dash means to run or move quickly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The dog ran off, and she dashed after him.

Vocabulary.mean: Disgust is a feeling of distaste and anger caused by something rude or unpleasant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I can only feel disgust for these criminals.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is fluorescent, it is such a bright color that it seems to give off light.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The map was marked with a fluorescent green line.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are furious, you are extremely angry.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He's furious about the way he's been treated.

Vocabulary.mean: A gulf is a gap between people who do not understand each other.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The gulf between rich and poor is enormous.

Vocabulary.mean: Humanities are subjects which analyze human ideas, such as history and literature.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Jennifer has always been more interested in humanities than science.

Vocabulary.mean: A knot is made when you tie the ends of rope or cord together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She tied the ribbon tightly in a knot.

Vocabulary.mean: A linguist is someone who studies languages.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's an excellent linguist.

Vocabulary.mean: A participant is someone who joins in a social event or competition.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The game is a major sporting event with more than three thousand participants.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is plausible, it is reasonable or possible.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her story sounded perfectly plausible.

Vocabulary.mean: A ritual is a formal custom that people do regularly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She objects to the ritual of organized religion.

Vocabulary.mean: A sibling is a brother or sister.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The younger children were badly treated by older siblings.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is skinny, they are extremely thin.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You should eat more, you're too skinny.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is vague, it is not clear, and it gives very few details.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I have only a vague memory of the house where I lived as a child.

Vocabulary.mean: An acid is a chemical that can burn or dissolve other substances.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Below pH 6.5 is acid, above pH 7.5 is alkaline.

Vocabulary.mean: An administration is the group of people who manage a company or organization.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He’s studying business administration.

Vocabulary.mean: Administrative describes anything related to managing a company or organization.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Your responsibilities will be mainly administrative.

Vocabulary.mean: Biotechnology is the use of living parts, such as cells, in industry and technology.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They are active in the field of biotechnology.

Vocabulary.mean: Cholesterol is a substance in fat, tissues, and blood of all animals.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. An oil that is high in polyunsaturated and low in cholesterol is good for health.

Vocabulary.mean: A coalition is a group of people or organizations working for a common purpose.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The coalition immediately decided to cut capital spending.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is deceptive, it encourages one to believe something that is false.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The firm was found guilty of publishing a misleading and deceptive advertisement.

Vocabulary.mean: Diabetes is a medical condition where a person has too much sugar in their blood.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Diabetes can cause many serious complications.

Vocabulary.mean: To eliminate something that is unwanted means to completely remove it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The virus can never be entirely eliminated from the body.

Vocabulary.mean: Erosion is the destruction of rock or soil due to flowing water or weather.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The erosion of the coastline is getting more and more severe.

Vocabulary.mean: Ethics are moral beliefs or rules about right or wrong.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They have a very strong work ethic.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is explicit, it is very clear, open, and truthful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I gave her very explicit directions how to get here.

Vocabulary.mean: A framework is a set of rules or ideas that people use to solve problems.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The report provides a framework for further research.

Vocabulary.mean: To manufacture something means to make it in a factory.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He works for a company that manufactures car parts.

Vocabulary.mean: A mechanism is a part of a machine that performs a certain function.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Automatic cameras have a special focusing mechanism.

Vocabulary.mean: To minimize means to reduce something to the lowest possible level.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We need to minimize costs by improving labor productivity.

Vocabulary.mean: Nectar is a sweet liquid produced by flowers that bees and other insects collect.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bee turns nectar into honey.

Vocabulary.mean: A notion is an idea or belief about something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I don't think he has any notion of the seriousness of the situation.

Vocabulary.mean: When things are prone to some bad thing, they are likely affected by it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I've always been prone to headaches.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is straightforward, it is good because it is easy to understand.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's quite straightforward to get here.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is astronomical, then it is extremely large.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The costs were astronomical.

Vocabulary.mean: An atom is the smallest unit of a substance.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Scientists are working to harness the power of the atom.

Vocabulary.mean: Breadth is the distance from one side to the other side of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The length of this box is twice its breadth.

Vocabulary.mean: A circumference is the distance completely around a circular object.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The earth is almost 25 000 miles in circumference.

Vocabulary.mean: A comet is an object in space made of ice and rock with a tail of glowing dust.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. For some cultures, comets often bring bad luck.

Vocabulary.mean: A crater is a large hole in a planet’s or moon’s surface.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. With a good telescope, you can see craters on the moon.

Vocabulary.mean: A crescent is the curved shape lit on the moon’s face during its early and late stages.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The moon is a bright crescent in the night sky.

Vocabulary.mean: Debris is the small pieces scattered from something wrecked or destroyed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Debris from the aircraft was scattered over a large area.

Vocabulary.mean: Despair is the complete loss of hope.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Drought has left farmers desperate.

Vocabulary.mean: To embed something means to place it firmly within a surrounding thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bullet embedded itself in the wall.

Vocabulary.mean: A fragment is a small part of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The road was covered with fragments of glass from the shattered window.

Vocabulary.mean: A galaxy is any extremely large collection of star systems.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The scientists are observing phenomena in nearby galaxies.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is gigantic, then it is extremely large.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bomb caused a gigantic explosion.

Vocabulary.mean: Gloom is a state of being almost completely dark.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Caroline peered into the gloom of the hallway.

Vocabulary.mean: To radiate means to send out energy or heat.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The little stove radiated a surprising amount of heat.

Vocabulary.mean: To roam means to move around without a plan or purpose.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sheep are allowed to roam freely on this land.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is solitary, then it is lonely or the only one.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He enjoys solitary walks in the wilderness.

Vocabulary.mean: The spectrum is the full range of color ranging from red to violet.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A spectrum is formed by a ray of light passing through a prism.

Vocabulary.mean: A sphere is a threeround shape, like a ball.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The room is decorated with colorful spheres.

Vocabulary.mean: Status is the position of something or someone in relation to others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The success of her book has given her unexpected celebrity status.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is bankrupt, then they are unable to pay their debts.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He went bankrupt after only a year in business.

Vocabulary.mean: To conform to rules or laws is to obey them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The building does not conform with safety regulations.

Vocabulary.mean: To employ someone means to give work to them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. How many people does the company employ?

Vocabulary.mean: To expel someone means to force them to leave a place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Foreign journalists are being expelled.

Vocabulary.mean: An extension is a part added to something to give it more time or space.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We’re building an extension on our house to enlarge the kitchen.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is forthcoming, then it is about to happen in the future.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her forthcoming novel is expected to become an instant bestseller.

Vocabulary.mean: To furnish means to put furniture in a house or room.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They've furnished the room very simply.

Vocabulary.mean: Hygiene is the conditions or methods needed for health and cleanliness.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Poor standards of hygiene mean that the disease spreads fast.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is hygienic, then it is clean and unlikely to cause disease.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Food must be prepared and stored in hygienic conditions.

Vocabulary.mean: A landlord is a man who rents property to a person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Heather's landlord actually lowered her rent when she said she might move out.

Vocabulary.mean: To lease means to rent property, usually an apartment or land.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I leased my new car instead of buying it.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is mandatory, then it is required by law.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In 1991, the British government made it mandatory to wear rear seat belts in cars.

Vocabulary.mean: To mend something means to fix it when it is broken or damaged.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Could you mend this hole in my shirt?

Vocabulary.mean: A mortgage is a loan for property, especially homes and businesses.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They took out a $400,000 mortgage to buy the house.

Vocabulary.mean: Personnel are employees in a business.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The new director is likely to make major changes in personnel.

Vocabulary.mean: Plumbing is the system of pipes used in a home to supply water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They're going to have to put in new plumbing.

Vocabulary.mean: A tenant is a person who rents property from a landlord.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. For years, they were tenants on my father’s property.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is trendy, then it is very popular and new.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. New York City is full of trendy shops and restaurants.

Vocabulary.mean: A utility is a business that supplies services such as water or electricity.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Rescue teams are trying to restore utilities in the area after the storm.

Vocabulary.mean: Whereby means by which or through which.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They’ve set up a plan whereby you can spread the cost over several months.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is aesthetic, then it is concerned with a love of beauty.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The works of art are judged on purely aesthetic grounds.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is arrogant, they think that they are more important than others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I never met a more conceited and arrogant young man.

Vocabulary.mean: A bias is a person’s likelihood to like one thing more than another thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The teacher seems to have a bias towards the girls in her class.

Vocabulary.mean: A canyon is a narrow valley with steep walls through which a river often flows.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sight of the deep canyon ahead is majestic.

Vocabulary.mean: A creek is a stream or small river.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The creek near the house has a lot of fish.

Vocabulary.mean: A drill is a tool with a point that spins in order to make a hole.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I used the drill to make several holes in the wall.

Vocabulary.mean: An executive is the top manager of a business.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She is now a senior executive.

Vocabulary.mean: Fatigue is a feeling of extreme tiredness.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Driver fatigue was to blame for the accident.

Vocabulary.mean: An incline is a sharp rise in something, especially a hill or mountain.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The ground inclined steeply towards the ridge in the distance.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is nasty, then it is not nice or pleasant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There's a nasty smell in here.

Vocabulary.mean: To perceive something means to be aware of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I perceived a change in his behaviour.

Vocabulary.mean: A primate is a type of mammal that includes monkeys, apes, and humans.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Primate species have superior intelligence than other species.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is primitive, then it is simple, basic, and not very developed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Twelve thousand years ago, our ancestors were primitive savages living in caves.

Vocabulary.mean: A stereotype is a general but often incorrect idea about a person or thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her plots are predictable and her characters little more than stereotypes.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is sticky, then it is covered with a substance that things stick to.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The children's faces were sticky with chocolate.

Vocabulary.mean: A termite is an insect that lives in groups and feeds on wood.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Termites have eaten nearly all the wooden doors.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens thereby an action, then it is the result of that action.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Regular exercise strengthens the heart, thereby reducing the risk of heart attack.

Vocabulary.mean: A trail is a path through a wild area.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This trail leads straight to the top of the mountain.

Vocabulary.mean: A twig is a short and thin branch from a tree or bush.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We collected dry twigs to start the fire.

Vocabulary.mean: Welfare is the health and happiness of a person or group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are concerned about the child's welfare.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is done on one’s behalf, it is done for that person by another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He gave what amounted to an apology on behalf of his company.

Vocabulary.mean: To flap means to move quickly up and down or from side to side.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bird flapped its wings and flew away.

Vocabulary.mean: A glacier is a large piece of ice that moves very slowly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The North Pole is covered by a huge glacier.

Vocabulary.mean: The globe refers to the Earth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Water covers most of the globe.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is horizontal, it is flat and level with the ground.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Keep the patient in a horizontal position with her feet slightly raised.

Vocabulary.mean: To hum means to make a low, continuous noise.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. What's that strange humming sound?

Vocabulary.mean: An inventory is a supply of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our inventory of used cars is the best in town.

Vocabulary.mean: If a thought or feeling is inward, it is not expressed or shown to others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her calm expression hid her inward panic.

Vocabulary.mean: A loaf of bread is bread shaped and baked in one piece.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I bought two loaves of bread for breakfast.

Vocabulary.mean: An oracle is person who speaks with gods and gives advice about the future.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The oracle made some predictions for the future.

Vocabulary.mean: To orbit something means to move around it in a continuous, curving path.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The satellite will go into orbit around Earth.

Vocabulary.mean: An overview is a general description of a situation.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I’ll give you a brief overview of what the job involves.

Vocabulary.mean: A preview is an opportunity to see something before it is available to the public.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There was a preview screening of the movie on Monday night.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is previous, then it happened earlier in time or order.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The previous owner of the house left all the furniture when they left.

Vocabulary.mean: To provide something means to supply it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A healthy diet should provide all your essential nutrients.

Vocabulary.mean: To recur means to happen more than once.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The same ideas recur throughout her books.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is relevant, it is important to a certain person or situation.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Do you have the relevant experience?

Vocabulary.mean: A rite is a traditional ceremony carried out by a particular group or society.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You have to go through an initiation rite before you become a full member.

Vocabulary.mean: To stall means to stop a process and continue it at a later time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My car stalled at the traffic light.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is supernatural, it is not real or explainable by natural law.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Ghosts and evil spirits are supernatural.

Vocabulary.mean: To adapt means to change in order to deal with a new situation or addition.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These products can be adapted to suit individual tastes.

Vocabulary.mean: Biological describes the process of life and living things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Eating is a biological necessity!

Vocabulary.mean: When something is cellular, it relates to the cells of animals or plants.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She used a microscope to see the activity at a cellular level.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are dynamic, they are lively and have creative ideas.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's young and dynamic and will be a great addition to the team.

Vocabulary.mean: A fantasy is a pleasant situation that people think about but is unlikely to happen.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Writing songs was just a fantasy of mine.

Vocabulary.mean: Heredity is the process of passing on features from parents to children.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The girl’s face is similar to her father’s because of heredity.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is internal, it exists or happens inside a person, object, or place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The bank will conduct an internal investigation.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is minimal, it is very small.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Fortunately, damage to the building was minimal.

Vocabulary.mean: A pioneer is a person who is the first to discover or be involved in something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was a pioneer in the field of microsurgery.

Vocabulary.mean: To prescribe medicine means to tell someone to take it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Many doctors prescribe aspirin to forestall second heart attacks.

Vocabulary.mean: When things are respective, they relate separately to each person just mentioned.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They are each recognized specialists in their respective fields.

Vocabulary.mean: To revive someone or something means to restore health or life to them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My plants revived as soon as I gave them some water.

Vocabulary.mean: When rules or systems are rigid, they are severe because they cannot be changed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The curriculum was too narrow and too rigid.

Vocabulary.mean: A sequence is a number of events or things that come one after another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Candidates are called into the examination room in alphabetical sequence.

Vocabulary.mean: To substitute something or someone means to have them take the place of another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You can substitute oil for butter in this recipe.

Vocabulary.mean: A surgeon is a doctor who is trained to do surgery.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The surgeon did everything in her power to save him.

Vocabulary.mean: Therapy is treatment for a particular physical or mental illness or condition.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. With physical therapy, you should eventually be able to walk again.

Vocabulary.mean: To transfer something means to move it from one place to another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The patient was transferred to another hospital.

Vocabulary.mean: A transition is a process where there is a change from one form to another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The health care system is in transition at the moment.

Vocabulary.mean: A transplant is an operation in which a damaged part of one’s body is replaced.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Surgeons have successfully transplant a liver into a young man.

Vocabulary.mean: An aquarium is a building where fish and underwater animals are kept.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are many interesting creatures in the aquarium.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is arbitrary, it is not based on any plan or system, so it seems random.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The choice of players for the team seemed completely arbitrary.

Vocabulary.mean: An autobiography is a true story of a person’s life written by that person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In his autobiography, he grew up in poverty.

Vocabulary.mean: A convention is behavior that is considered to be common or polite.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. By convention, the team leader will perform the test first.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is gracious, then they are kind and helpful to those who need it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is a gracious host.

Vocabulary.mean: To improve something means to make it better.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her grades have improved greatly this semester.

Vocabulary.mean: To insulate something means to protect it from heat, cold, or noise.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We’ve saved a lot on our heating bills by insulating the attic.

Vocabulary.mean: To intrigue means to cause an interest in something or someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There was something about him that intrigued her.

Vocabulary.mean: Longevity is the ability to live for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We wish you both health and longevity.

Vocabulary.mean: To misplace something means to lose it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I am always misplacing my keys.

Vocabulary.mean: When children are naughty, they behave badly or do not do what they are told.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You've been a very naughty boy!

Vocabulary.mean: A norm is a way of behaving that is considered normal in a particular society.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Older parents seem to be the norm rather than the exception nowadays.

Vocabulary.mean: An orangutan is a large ape with red and brown hair and long arms.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Orangutans are one of the smartest primates.

Vocabulary.mean: To overload something means to put more things into it than it is meant to hold.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Don't overload the washing machine, or it won't get the clothes clean.

Vocabulary.mean: Philanthropy is the act of helping others, without wanting anything in return.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Hospitals were built as a result of private philanthropy and government intervention.

Vocabulary.mean: To probe into something means to ask questions to discover facts about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He didn't like the media probing into his past.

Vocabulary.mean: A recipient of something is the person who receives it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was the first recipient of an artificial heart.

Vocabulary.mean: A reptile is a cold animal that lays eggs and has skin covered with scales.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Snakes, turtles, and crocodiles are all reptiles.

Vocabulary.mean: To thrive means to do well and be successful, healthy, or strong.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This year his business is thriving.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is ultimate, it is the final result or aim of a long series of events.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My ultimate goal is to make a lot of money.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is antique, it is very old and rare, and therefore valuable.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This museum has the largest collection of antiques in the world.

Vocabulary.mean: An applicant is someone who writes a request to be considered for a job or prize.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. How many applicants did you have for the job?

Vocabulary.mean: An artifact is an old object made by humans that is historically interesting.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is authentic, it is not false or a copy of the original.

Vocabulary.mean: The chronology of a series of past events is when they happened.

Vocabulary.mean: A diplomat is a representative of a country who works with another country.

Vocabulary.mean: An epic is a long book, poem, or movie about a period of time or a great event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Professor is teaching about one of the great Hindu epics.

Vocabulary.mean: An excerpt is a short piece of writing or music taken from a larger piece.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The orchestra is playing an excerpt from the symphony.

Vocabulary.mean: A fossil is the hard remains of a prehistoric animal or plant.

Vocabulary.mean: To humiliate someone means to make them feel ashamed and embarrassed.

Vocabulary.mean: When a poem is considered lyric, it is written in a simple and direct style.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Paul Simon writes the lyrics for most of his songs.

Vocabulary.mean: Majesty is supreme greatness or authority.

Vocabulary.mean: The monarch of a country is the king, queen, emperor, or empress.

Vocabulary.mean: To precede something means to come before it.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is punctual, they do something or arrive at the right time.

Vocabulary.mean: To recruit people means to select them to join or work for an organization.

Vocabulary.mean: A refund is money given back to a person when an item is returned to a store.

Vocabulary.mean: A register is an official list or record of people or things.

Vocabulary.mean: Renown is the quality of being well known due to having done good things.

Vocabulary.mean: A tusk is a long, curved, pointed tooth of an elephant, boar, or walrus.

Vocabulary.mean: A burden is a serious or difficult responsibility.

Vocabulary.mean: To compromise is to agree to something that is not exactly what you want.

Vocabulary.mean: To craft something is to make it using skill.

Vocabulary.mean: A crook is someone who is not honest or who commits crimes.

Vocabulary.mean: Currency is the form of money used in a certain place.

Vocabulary.mean: An enigma is someone or something that is mysterious or hard to understand.

Vocabulary.mean: When people or things are fragile, they are not strong and can be damaged easily.

Vocabulary.mean: A hybrid is a mixture of different things or styles.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Hinny is a hybrid offspring of a male horse and a female donkey.

Vocabulary.mean: Innocence is a lack of experience of difficult or complex things in life.

Vocabulary.mean: To merge two things is to combine them into one whole thing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They decided to merge the two companies into one.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is moderate, it is not too big or too small in size or amount.

Vocabulary.mean: To overwhelm is to exist in such a large amount that someone cannot deal with it.

Vocabulary.mean: A perception of a situation is a way of thinking about it or understanding it.

Vocabulary.mean: A reunion is the meeting of people or things that have been separated.

Vocabulary.mean: To rig something means to dishonestly arrange it.

Vocabulary.mean: A shiver is a shaking movement the body makes when someone is cold or scared.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is sociable, they are friendly.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is talkative, they talk a lot.

Vocabulary.mean: To tow something is to pull it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Our car was towed away by the police.

Vocabulary.mean: To tramp is to put your feet down in a loud, heavy way as you walk.

Vocabulary.mean: To alleviate pain or suffering means to make it less intense or severe.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The drugs did nothing to alleviate her pain.

Vocabulary.mean: Astrology is the study of the stars in the belief that they influence people’s lives.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Unlike astronomy, astrology cannot be described as an exact science.

Vocabulary.mean: To differentiate things or people is to show the difference between them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's difficult to differentiate between the two varieties.

Vocabulary.mean: To disrupt something or someone is to prevent them from working.

Vocabulary.mean: An equation is a math operation to determine the value of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We often have difficulty solving equations.

Vocabulary.mean: To err means to make a mistake.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He erred in agreeing to her appointment to the position.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is erroneous, it is incorrect or only partly correct.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Their conclusions are quite erroneous.

Vocabulary.mean: If people or things are frantic, they behave in a wild way because they are frightened
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The crowd became frantic when the bomb exploded.

Vocabulary.mean: The hull of a boat or tank is the main body of it.

Vocabulary.mean: When an action is inadvertent, it is done without realizing what you are doing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She made an inadvertent error when she omitted some information.

Vocabulary.mean: To improvise something is to do it with whatever is available or without planning.

Vocabulary.mean: The latitude of a place is its distance from the equator.

Vocabulary.mean: A mariner is a sailor.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He spent his whole life as a mariner.

Vocabulary.mean: A multitude of things or people is a very large number of them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The library offers a whole multitude of books for young readers.

Vocabulary.mean: A nuisance is a person or thing that is annoying or causes a lot of problems.

Vocabulary.mean: The permanence of something is its ability to last forever.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We no longer talk of the permanence of marriage.

Vocabulary.mean: To revolve around something is to keep it as the main feature or focus.

Vocabulary.mean: To soothe means to calm someone who is angry or upset.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is stranded, they are prevented from leaving a place.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is volatile, it is likely to change suddenly and unexpectedly.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is arduous, it demands great effort or labor.

Vocabulary.mean: To attain something means to gain or achieve it, often after a lot of effort.

Vocabulary.mean: To coexist with something means to exist with it in the same time and place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Two civilizations coexist in peace.

Vocabulary.mean: To conceive something means to be able to imagine or believe it.

Vocabulary.mean: When something or someone is dubious, they are not considered honest.

Vocabulary.mean: An ego is a person’s sense of their own worth.

Vocabulary.mean: Elastic is a rubber that stretches when it is pulled.

Vocabulary.mean: An endeavor is an attempt to do something, especially something new or original.

Vocabulary.mean: To engrave means to cut a design or words into the surface of something.

Vocabulary.mean: A mold is a hollow container that is used to make certain shapes.

Vocabulary.mean: Plaster is a smooth paste that gets hard when it dries.

Vocabulary.mean: A shovel is a tool with a long handle that is used for digging.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is terrestrial, it relates to Earth.

Vocabulary.mean: When something or someone is vicious, they are violent and cruel.

Vocabulary.mean: If something or someone is absurd, they are ridiculous.

Vocabulary.mean: Anemia is a blood condition that causes a person to be pale and tired.

Vocabulary.mean: The aristocracy is the highest class of people in certain societies.

Vocabulary.mean: Attire is nice or special clothing.

Vocabulary.mean: To enlarge something means to make it bigger.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is predominant, then it is the most important, common or strongest.

Vocabulary.mean: Rouge is a red powder or cream used as makeup on the cheeks or lips.

Vocabulary.mean: Vanity is excessive pride or love of one’s own appearance or things one has done.

Vocabulary.mean: If something or someone is vulgar, then they are rude or lacking in style.

Vocabulary.mean: An ordeal is a bad experience.

Vocabulary.mean: When something or someone is devoid of a thing, they are missing it.

she said, looking at the flies buzzing above the piles of dirty plates.
