Vocabulary.example: e.g. The two cars collided at the crossroads.

Vocabulary.mean: A culprit is someone who did a crime or other bad deed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Two eyewitnesses identified him as the culprit.

Vocabulary.mean: To evacuate means to leave a place of danger to a place of safety.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police evacuated the village shortly before the explosion.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is flammable, then it is able to catch on fire.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These materials are highly flammable.

Vocabulary.mean: A mob is a large crowd of people that often wants to cause violence.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The angry mob outside the jail was ready to riot.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is premature, then it is done too early or before the proper time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. A spokesman said it was premature to comment on the negotiations.

Vocabulary.mean: To resent something means to have bad feelings about it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. People still resent the closure of the local school.

Vocabulary.mean: A satire is a work of art that uses humor and irony to make fun of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The play is a satire on corporate culture.

Vocabulary.mean: Scrutiny is the careful examination of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The documents should be available for public scrutiny.

Vocabulary.mean: To segregate something means to place it in a group apart from other things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We will be creating a special fund segregated from our other operations.

Vocabulary.mean: To subject someone to something means to force them to do or experience it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The officers subjected everyone to a careful search before they left the plane.

Vocabulary.mean: To testify means to give evidence as a witness.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. One witness testified that she saw the thief running away.

Vocabulary.mean: A tumult is a loud and confused noise made by a large crowd of people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You couldn't hear her speak over the tumult from the screaming fans.

Vocabulary.mean: To underestimate something or someone means to think they are not important.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She had a tendency to underestimate her son's potential.

Vocabulary.mean: Uproar is loud noise caused by people who are very angry or upset.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The whole hall was in uproar after the announcement.

Vocabulary.mean: To accelerate means to increase in speed.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The car accelerated to overtake me.

Vocabulary.mean: If you do something anew, you do it again and in a different way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They started life anew in Australia.

Vocabulary.mean: A defect is a part of something that is wrong or missing.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The cars have a defect in the electrical system that may cause them to stall.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is dreary, then it is dull, dark, and lifeless.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She had spent another dreary day in the office.

Vocabulary.mean: To duplicate something means to copy it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The documents had been duplicated.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is electromagnetic, it is related to electricity and magnetic fields.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Scientists are studying the application of electromagnetic waves in practice.

Vocabulary.mean: An electron is a particle in all atoms that has a negative electric charge.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The number of electrons in an atom determines the substance the atoms make.

Vocabulary.mean: To glide means to fly on extended wings with little or no effort.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We saw an eagle gliding high above the mountains.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is ingenious, then they are very smart.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She devised an ingenious solution to the problem.

Vocabulary.mean: An innovation is a product or an idea that is new or very original.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company is very interested in product design and innovation.

Vocabulary.mean: If something or someone is innovative, they can think in creative ways.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Gwen introduced a number of innovative solutions.

Vocabulary.mean: To launch something means to make it go into motion.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The lifeboat was launched immediately.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is meteorological, it is concerned with the science of weather.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It was the most terrible blizzard in meteorological history.

Vocabulary.mean: Meteorology is the science that studies the weather.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My son majored in meteorology at the university.

Vocabulary.mean: To penetrate something means to enter into it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The drill isn't sharp enough to penetrate into the rock.

Vocabulary.mean: Propulsion is the force that moves something forward.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fish uses its tail fins for propulsion through the water.

Vocabulary.mean: To simulate something means to copy its actions or characteristics.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Computer software can be used to simulate conditions on the seabed.

Vocabulary.mean: To spur someone means to urge them into action.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The huge new factory spurred economic growth in the entire region.

Vocabulary.mean: To stimulate something means to cause or to increase activity in it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Read books to stimulate your child’s imagination.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is tenacious, then they do not easily give up.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's a tenacious woman. She never gives up.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is done beforehand, then it is done in advance.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She had phoned beforehand to let me know she was coming.

Vocabulary.mean: If a temperature is centigrade, it is scaled, so water freezes at 0° and boils at 100°.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The average temperature in the spring is 18-20 degrees centigrade.

Vocabulary.mean: To chatter means to talk quickly about unimportant things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She spent the morning chattering away to her friends.

Vocabulary.mean: A concerto is music for a solo instrument and played with an orchestra.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Mozart's concerto for flute and harp

Vocabulary.mean: To condense a gas means to make it a liquid.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Steam condenses into water when it cools.

Vocabulary.mean: A cove is a part of land where it curves inward around the sea.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are exploring a small cove on the south side of the island.

Vocabulary.mean: To deteriorate means to become steadily worse.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We could see his health deteriorating week by week.

Vocabulary.mean: An exterior is the outside surface of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The exterior of the house needs repainting.

Vocabulary.mean: A freeway is a road with no stops where cars travel at high speeds.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Minimum speed on freeway is 75 mph.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone or something is hearty, then they are loud and happy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her laugh was far too hearty to be genuine.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is hospitable, they are friendly to strangers.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The villagers were very hospitable towards anyone who passed through.

Vocabulary.mean: A manor is a large house with many rooms.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My grandfather owned a large manor in the suburbs.

Vocabulary.mean: A monastery is a building in which monks live.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are visiting an old monastery in France.

Vocabulary.mean: A nursery is a room where babies and children sleep, play, or are cared for.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The store has a nursery where you can leave your children while you shop.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is outstretched, then it is extended to its full length.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The baby ran towards her mother with arms outstretched.

Vocabulary.mean: A parcel is a package of things to be carried or mailed somewhere.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I received a parcel from a stranger this morning.

Vocabulary.mean: A profile is an outline of a face, usually as seen from the side.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Drawing profiles is somehow easier than drawing the full face.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is vivacious, they are talkative and cheerful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He had three pretty, vivacious daughters.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is winding, then it follows a twisting course.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They struggled up the narrow winding stairs.

Vocabulary.mean: To zip something means to close it with a zipper.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I zipped and buttoned my jacket.

Vocabulary.mean: An airway is the passage by which air reaches a person’s lungs.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Small objects can obstruct the airways of young children.

Vocabulary.mean: The Almighty is a name for a god in a religion.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We must pray to the Almighty for forgiveness.

Vocabulary.mean: An advent is the arrival or beginning of an important person, thing, or event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Transportation was transformed by the advent of the internal combustion engine.

Vocabulary.mean: A constellation is a group of stars with a recognizable shape.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Little Bear constellation is still used by navigators at sea.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is definitive, then it is the most official.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There is no definitive scientific evidence that coffee is harmful.

Vocabulary.mean: To equate one thing with another is to compare them and consider them very similar.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. People sometimes equate money with happiness.

Vocabulary.mean: To inhale means to take air or a smell into the lungs.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She flung open the window and inhaled deeply.

Vocabulary.mean: To invoke something is to mention it to support an argument or ask for help.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Their sacred dance is performed to invoke ancient gods.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is lunar, then it is related to the moon.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are observing the lunar eclipse through a telescope.

Vocabulary.mean: A novelty is something that is new, original, or strange.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Electric cars are still something of a novelty.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is outmoded, then it is no longer in fashion or use.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The typewriter is outmoded.

Vocabulary.mean: To personalize something means to design it to meet a person’s unique needs.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This program enables faxes to be personalized automatically.

Vocabulary.mean: To pertain to something means to be related or connected to it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Regulations pertaining to high-tech industries was passed by government.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is primal, then it is very basic or related to the origin of something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The appeal of music is primal.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is psychiatric, then it is related to mental illness or its treatment.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has been transferred to a psychiatric hospital.

Vocabulary.mean: Psychiatry is the study and treatment of mental illness.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I studied psychiatry at the university.

Vocabulary.mean: A reflex is an unconscious action in which a body part responds to an event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The doctor tested her reflexes.

Vocabulary.mean: A seizure is sudden illness in which the body loses control and shakes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He had seizures after performing the exercises too hard.

Vocabulary.mean: A session is a meeting at a regular time in order to discuss and solve an issue.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The parliamentary session is due to end on 27 May.

Vocabulary.mean: A utensil is a common tool or container.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Wash your hands and all cooking utensils after preparing raw meat.

Vocabulary.mean: An adhesive is a substance used for sticking things together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You'll need some strong adhesive to mend that chair.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is adverse, then it is harmful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her policies may have adverse effects on the economy.

Vocabulary.mean: A dependency is a strong need for someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The economy still has a large dependency on agriculture.

Vocabulary.mean: To dump something means to throw it away or get rid of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Toxic chemicals continue to be dumped into the river.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is eternal, then it lasts forever.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They swore eternal loyalty to the king.

Vocabulary.mean: To fluctuate means to rise and fall in number or amount.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Fruit prices fluctuate according to the season.

Vocabulary.mean: If something moves to and fro, it moves backward and forward or side to side.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her long hair went to and fro as she swung on the swing.

Vocabulary.mean: Inclusion is the act of including someone or something in a group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Twelve new stories were selected for inclusion in the book.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is intermediate, then it is in the middle of two levels, places, ortimes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This test is too difficult for intermediate students of English.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is intermittent, then it happens in a way that is not constant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We had to postpone travel because of the intermittent rain.

Vocabulary.mean: A mentor is a person with experience or knowledge who advises someone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His former coach had remained his mentor throughout his career.

Vocabulary.mean: A phoenix is an imaginary bird that burned to ashes and was reborn.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Phoenix is a symbol for rebirth and a new beginning.

Vocabulary.mean: Photosynthesis is the process in which plants change sunlight and air.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The leaves are where photosynthesis takes place in plants.

Vocabulary.mean: Pollen is the tiny yellow powder made in the flowers of plants.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Pollen makes me allergic.

Vocabulary.mean: To regain something means to get it back.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. After a bad year, she has regained her form.

Vocabulary.mean: To reverse means to change to the opposite direction.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government has failed to reverse the economic decline.

Vocabulary.mean: A swarm is a group of flying insects.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The dead sheep was covered with swarms of flies.

Vocabulary.mean: Texture is the quality of something that can be known by its touch.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The fabric has a very soft texture.

Vocabulary.mean: To tickle someone is to touch them in a way that causes laughter.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I tickled her feet and she laughed.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is vibrant, then it is bright and full of color.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He always uses vibrant colours in his paintings.

Vocabulary.mean: To abolish something means to put an end to it, such as a system or law.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This tax should be abolished.

Vocabulary.mean: To amend something means to change it to improve or make it accurate.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The terms of the contract were amended in later years.

Vocabulary.mean: To aspire means to have a strong desire to achieve or do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He aspired to be the leader.

Vocabulary.mean: To censor information means to remove it if it is rude or rebellious.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The book was heavily censored when first published.

Vocabulary.mean: A charter is a document that describes the rights of an organization or group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The United Nations charter sets forth goals we all admire.

Vocabulary.mean: A constitution is a document of principles for a government.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Under the union constitution, a new committee is elected each year.

Vocabulary.mean: When a place is cosmopolitan, it is full of people from many different places.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. New York is a highly cosmopolitan city.

Vocabulary.mean: To disseminate information or knowledge means to distribute it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Their findings have been widely disseminated.

Vocabulary.mean: To flatter people means to praise them in an effort to please them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I knew he was only flattering me because he wanted to borrow some money.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is infamous, they are well known for something bad.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The man is a general who was infamous for his brutality.

Vocabulary.mean: If one is lame, they cannot walk properly due to an injury to the leg or foot.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My horse had gone lame.

Vocabulary.mean: To limp means to walk with difficulty because someone’s leg or foot is hurt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Jackson limped off the field after injuring his ankle.

Vocabulary.mean: An outburst is a sudden, strong expression of an emotion.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was alarmed by his violent outburst.

Vocabulary.mean: When a behavior is pathological, it is extreme, unacceptable, and uncontrollable.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Anthony's a pathological liar.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is phenomenal, it is unusually great.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Angela can do a phenomenal amount of work in one day.

Vocabulary.mean: A poll is a survey in which people give their opinions about important things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In a recent opinion poll, a majority of respondents were against nuclear weapons.

Vocabulary.mean: Remorse is a strong feeling of sadness and regret.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was filled with remorse for not believing her.

Vocabulary.mean: Secrecy is the behavior of keeping things secret.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The content of her report is shrouded in secrecy.

Vocabulary.mean: To tackle something means to deal with it in a determined and efficient way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are many ways of tackling this problem.

Vocabulary.mean: A trance is a state where people seem asleep and have no control of themselves.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sound of the waves lulled me into a trance.

Vocabulary.mean: A coward is a person who lacks courage to do risky or dangerous things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She considered him a coward for failing to join up in the war.

Vocabulary.mean: To delete something means to remove or erase written material.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The editor deleted the last three paragraphs.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is firsthand, then it is from an original source.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Most of us have firsthand experience of teaching.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is earnest, then they are honest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was in earnest conversation with his father.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is ethnic, then it is related to a group with a similar culture.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She loves ethnic foods, especially Chinese.

Vocabulary.mean: To exclude someone means to not accept them into a group.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Tom has been excluded from team for bad behaviour.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is fluent in a language, then they are able to speak it very well.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's fluent in French.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is imperial, then it is of, or related to an empire.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The play is set in imperial Rome.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is inclusive, then it is open to all groups and people in society.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The party must adopt more inclusive strategies and a broader vision.

Vocabulary.mean: A legislature is the section of a government that makes laws.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's up to the state legislature to enact the budget.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is linguistic, then it is concerned with language.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm particularly interested in the linguistic development of young children.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is monolingual, then they speak only one language.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Monolingual children are able to learn a second language quickly if given the chance.

Vocabulary.mean: Nationality is an identity based on the nation from which you come.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We teach students of all nationalities.

Vocabulary.mean: A patriot is someone who loves, supports, and defends their country.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I wouldn't say I’m a great patriot, but I would never betray my country.

Vocabulary.mean: To prosecute someone means to take legal action against them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The banker was prosecuted for fraud.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is racial, then it is related to a race or races.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They are members of a racial minority.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is solemn, then it is serious and honest.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The memorial was a very solemn occasion.

Vocabulary.mean: Solidarity is a union formed from common responsibilities or interests.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The purpose of the speech was to show solidarity with the country's leaders.

Vocabulary.mean: Tact is the ability to avoid offending people when dealing with problems.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She is not exactly known for her tact.

Vocabulary.mean: To undermine someone means to betray or weaken their efforts or authority.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Criticism just undermines their confidence.

Vocabulary.mean: To allocate something means to put it aside for a certain purpose or person.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The government is allocating £10 million for health education.

Vocabulary.mean: When food is appetizing, it looks and smells very good.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The meals he cooked were always appetizing.

Vocabulary.mean: A blizzard is a severe snow storm with strong winds.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The blizzard struck the north-east yesterday, causing serious damage.

Vocabulary.mean: A cavity is a hole or space in something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The gold was hidden in a secret cavity.

Vocabulary.mean: If something moves clockwise, it moves in a circle in the same direction as a clock.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Turn the key clockwise to open the door.

Vocabulary.mean: When circles or rings are concentric, they have the same center.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The target was a series of concentric circles.

Vocabulary.mean: Courtesy is the excellence of manners or social conduct.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He could at least have had the courtesy to say sorry.

Vocabulary.mean: When food is crisp, it is hard or has a hard surface in a way that is pleasant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Bake until the pastry is golden and crisp.

Vocabulary.mean: Discord is disagreement or fighting between people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The plan to build the highway created discord in our community.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is frigid, it is extremely cold.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Few plants can grow in such a frigid environment.

Vocabulary.mean: To generate something means to cause it to develop or begin.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The new development will generate 1,500 new jobs.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is glacial, it relates to large masses of ice that move slowly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Polar bears live in the glacial regions of Arctic.

Vocabulary.mean: An interchange of ideas between people is a discussion of each person’s idea.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They hope to encourage the free interchange of ideas.

Vocabulary.mean: A locker is a small cabinet with a lock where people store their possessions.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I left my things in my locker.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is multicultural, it relates to many different cultures.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We live in a multicultural society.

Vocabulary.mean: An omission is something that has been left out or not done.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are some serious errors and omissions in the book.

Vocabulary.mean: To oversee something means to make sure that it is being done properly.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We've just appointed a coordinator who will oversee the whole project.

Vocabulary.mean: To pierce something means to make a hole in it using a sharp object.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The needle pierces the fabric four times a second.

Vocabulary.mean: To replicate something is to do it in the exact same way as someone before.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Researchers tried to replicate the original experiment.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is wavy, it is not straight but has a series of curves.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sarah has wavy blond hair.

Vocabulary.mean: To abide by something, like a rule, means to obey it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. You'll have to abide by the rules of the club.

Vocabulary.mean: Conversion is the act of changing something into a different state or form.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Solar power is the conversion of the sun's energy into heat and electricity.

Vocabulary.mean: To cram things means to put them into a place that can barely contain them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I bought a large basket and crammed it full of presents.

Vocabulary.mean: To defer means to arrange for an action to happen at a later time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My bank has agreed to defer the repayments on my loan.

Vocabulary.mean: To export products means to sell them to other countries.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Japan exports a huge quantity of cars around the world.

Vocabulary.mean: Fumes are unhealthy smoke and gases that are made by fires or chemicals.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Clouds of toxic fumes escaped in a huge chemical factory blaze.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is habitual, it is a behavior that a person usually does or has.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She sat smoking her habitual cigarette.

Vocabulary.mean: To justify something means to show or prove that it is necessary.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I can't really justify taking another day off work.

Vocabulary.mean: Output is the amount of something that a person or thing produces.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Last year manufacturing output fell by 14 percent.

Vocabulary.mean: Overpopulation is the state of having too many people in an area.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Overpopulation is one of the country's most pressing social problems.

Vocabulary.mean: A patent is a right to be the only person allowed to make or sell a new product.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The device was protected by patent.

Vocabulary.mean: To penalize someone means to punish him or her.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was penalized for time wasting.

Vocabulary.mean: Petroleum is a liquid natural resource from which many fuels are made.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Petroleum is used to produce fuel for vehicles.

Vocabulary.mean: A prototype is a new machine that is not ready to be made in large quantities.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The press conference to introduce a new phone prototype.

Vocabulary.mean: A scrap of something is a small amount of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Do you have a scrap of paper I could write on?

Vocabulary.mean: A sector is a part of a country’s economy in a specific type of industry.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In the financial sector, banks and insurance companies have both grown well over the past year.

Vocabulary.mean: To subscribe to something is to agree or to concur with it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Frank subscribed to the belief that human kindness would overcome evil.

Vocabulary.mean: To subsist means to have the food, water, and money needed to stay alive.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Old people often subsist on very small incomes.

Vocabulary.mean: To suspend something means to delay or stop it from happening for a while.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Flights to Paris were suspended.

Vocabulary.mean: A synthesis is a combination of different ideas or styles.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This design is a synthesis of traditional and modern values.

Vocabulary.mean: An acrobat is a person who entertains people by doing amazing physical things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We were impressed by the performance of acrobats in the circus last night.

Vocabulary.mean: Advocacy is the act of supporting or recommending something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The charity provides advice, help, and advocacy for older people.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is communal, it involves a group of people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We are walking in the communal park.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is fluid, it is smooth and moves gracefully.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She is performing the dance with fluid movements.

Vocabulary.mean: To harmonize means to make different things go well together.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The garden has been designed to harmonize with the natural landscape.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is industrious, they work hard.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's extremely competent and industrious.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is inventive, they are good at creating new things.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is very inventive, always dreaming up new gadgets for the home.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is judicial, it is related to judges or courts of law.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Supreme Court ordered a judicial inquiry into the deaths.

Vocabulary.mean: Mandarin is one of the two main Chinese languages.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We do not understand what he said because he uses Mandarin.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is metropolitan, it relates to a large city.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was drawn to the metropolitan glamour and excitement of Paris.

Vocabulary.mean: To mimic something means to copy the way it sounds or moves.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's always mimicking the teachers.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is misguided, it is based on bad judgment or wrong beliefs.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company blamed its disappointing performance on a misguided business plan.

Vocabulary.mean: To rehearse means to practice and prepare for a performance in front of people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The musicians are rehearsing for the concert.

Vocabulary.mean: To scorn someone means to behave without respect toward them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was unable to hide the scorn in her voice.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is sensory, it is related to the senses.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I really like the sensory thrill of watching action movies.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is staple, it is standard or basic.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The staple diet here is meat, fish and mashed potatoes.

Vocabulary.mean: A statute is a law that is official and has been written down.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The new statute  makes it illegal to sell alcohol to people under 16.

Vocabulary.mean: A veteran is someone who has a lot of experience doing something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She is one of our veterans and has been teaching here for over 20 years.

Vocabulary.mean: A villain is an evil person who breaks the law or hurts others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The familiar motif in his books is the villain who is always destroyed.

Vocabulary.mean: A vine is a plant that has long, twisting stems and climbs upward.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We have a grape vine in our garden.

Vocabulary.mean: To constrain something means to limit its development.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The company said that it was constrained to raise prices.

Vocabulary.mean: A depot is a bus or train station.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I met her at the bus depot yesterday.

Vocabulary.mean: To emulate people means to imitate them because they are greatly admired.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He just wants to emulate his dad.

Vocabulary.mean: The forefinger is the finger between one’s thumb and middle finger.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He held a tiny seed between his thumb and forefinger.

Vocabulary.mean: The guts are all the organs inside a person or animal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'll only cook fish if the guts have been removed.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is inherent, it is a natural part of something else.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. There are dangers inherent in almost every sport.

Vocabulary.mean: To intimidate means to frighten others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They were intimidated into accepting a pay cut by the threat of losing their jobs.

Vocabulary.mean: A janitor is a person who makes repairs and takes care of a building.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The school janitor cleaned up the messy cafeteria.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is moist, it is slightly wet.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Keep the soil in the pot moist, but not too wet.

Vocabulary.mean: Nope is an informal way of saying “ no.”
Vocabulary.example: e.g.

Vocabulary.mean: To prod means to push someone or something with a finger or pointed object.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I prodded her in the back to get her attention.

Vocabulary.mean: A ransom is a sum of money paid to a kidnapper to set the person free.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The kidnappers demanded a huge ransom.

Vocabulary.mean: To restrain someone or something means to use physical strength to stop them.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I could hardly restrain my laughter.

Vocabulary.mean: Saliva is the watery liquid in people’s mouths that helps in digestion.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Babies drool because they can't keep saliva in their mouths.

Vocabulary.mean: To spit means to force liquid from one’s mouth.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's disgusting to spit in the street.

Vocabulary.mean: To sprint means to run very fast over a short distance.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We had to sprint to catch the bus.

Vocabulary.mean: A stunt is something that is done in order to get attention or publicity.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Their marriage was just a cheap publicity stunt.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are tolerant, they are approved of because they accept others.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has a very tolerant attitude towards his children.

Vocabulary.mean: A vampire is a fictional monster that sleeps in a coffin and sucks people’s blood.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The most famous vampire is Count Dracula of Transylvania.

Vocabulary.mean: To yawn means to open one’s mouth wide and breathe in air.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He yawned loudly in the middle of her speech.

Vocabulary.mean: An analogy is a connection made between things to show that they are similar.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He drew an analogy between the brain and a computer.

Vocabulary.mean: A person’s ancestry is the series of people from whom a person descended.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. His wife was of royal ancestry.

Vocabulary.mean: An archer is a person who uses a bow and arrows.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Archers started shooting arrows at the enemy.

Vocabulary.mean: A conspiracy is a secret plan made by a group of people to do something illegal.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The police discovered the conspiracy to bomb the stadium.

Vocabulary.mean: A deputy is the secondperson in a business or government.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She has been promoted from deputy manager to senior manager.

Vocabulary.mean: An earl is a nobleman from Britain.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Earl of Northumberland lived in a huge mansion.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is fragrant, it has a pleasant smell.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The air was fragrant with scents from the sea and the hills.

Vocabulary.mean: A funnel is an object with a wide top and a narrow bottom for pouring liquids.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Use a funnel to pour wine into the jar.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is hereditary, it is a trait passed onto children from their parents.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It’s a hereditary disorder that can cause abnormal growth.

Vocabulary.mean: A hymn is a religious song that often praises a god.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The ceremony began with a traditional hymn.

Vocabulary.mean: To invert something means to turn it upside down.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He inverted the bicycle to make repairs on the wheels.

Vocabulary.mean: Prey is the animals that are hunted and eaten by another creature.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The lion will often stalk its prey for hours.

Vocabulary.mean: A procession is a group of people who walk or drive in a line during a public event.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The dancers leading the procession were in colourful and elaborate costumes.

Vocabulary.mean: A prophet is a person chosen by a god to give the god’s message to people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Some believe that he was not a true prophet.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is sarcastic, it is the opposite of what is actually meant.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. ‘There's no need to be sarcastic,’ she said.

Vocabulary.mean: Seasoning is a mix of salt, herbs, and spices that improves the taste of food.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Boil soup for 15 minutes then adjust the seasoning to taste.

Vocabulary.mean: Sodium is an element that can be used to make substances such as salt.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Sodium and chloride combine to make table salt.

Vocabulary.mean: A tyranny is a cruel and unfair government in which one person has power.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The children had no protection against the tyranny of their father.

Vocabulary.mean: A tyrant is someone who treats people in a cruel, harsh, and unfair way.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The country was ruled by a tyrant.

Vocabulary.mean: Vinegar is a strong liquid made from sour wine that is used in cooking.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Would you like oil and vinegar on your salad?

Vocabulary.mean: If something is adjoining, it is next to or joined with a building, or room.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We asked for adjoining rooms.

Vocabulary.mean: To allege something is to say that it is true without offering proof.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The prosecution alleges that she was driving carelessly.

Vocabulary.mean: An arch is a curved opening formed under a structure such as a bridge or doorway.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Passing through the arch, you enter an open courtyard.

Vocabulary.mean: To assemble means to get together in one place.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. All the students were asked to assemble in the main hall.

Vocabulary.mean: A casualty is a person killed or injured in a war or an accident.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The number of casualties in both wars was appallingly high.

Vocabulary.mean: To erect something means to build it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They decided to erect a bridge across the Niagara Gorge.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is foul, then it is not pleasant or enjoyable.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Those toilets smell foul!

Vocabulary.mean: A hectare is a unit of measure equal to 10, ooo square meters.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The castle has an area of ​​40 hectares.

Vocabulary.mean: To heighten an emotion means to increase the intensity of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Tension has heightened after the recent bomb attack.

Vocabulary.mean: Hospitality is friendly behavior and entertainment given to guests or strangers.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The local people showed me great hospitality.

Vocabulary.mean: A mansion is a large and expensive home.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Their family lives in a vast mansion.

Vocabulary.mean: To outnumber a group means to have a greater number than it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. In our office the women outnumber the men three to one.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is overjoyed, then they are extremely happy.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. I'm overjoyed that you're coming to visit me.

Vocabulary.mean: A pasture is an area of land covered with grass for animals to use as food.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The sheep were grazing on the lush green pastures.

Vocabulary.mean: A petition is a written request asking an authority to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. More than 2000 people signed a petition to protect a wildlife area from development.

Vocabulary.mean: To renovate a building means to repair it or build new structures on it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He renovates old houses and sells them.

Vocabulary.mean: To revise something means to change or update it to make it better.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He was asked to revise his proposal before submitting it again.

Vocabulary.mean: A slab is a large, thick, flat piece of stone, concrete, metal, or wood.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The road was paved with smooth stone slabs.

Vocabulary.mean: A terrace is an open area that is connected to a house or an apartment.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her hobby is sitting on the terrace watching the sunset.

Vocabulary.mean: Turf is a section of grass and the dirt in which it grows.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The turf needs to be looked after carefully before the game starts.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is analogous to another thing, then it is like it in certain ways.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The two situations are roughly analogous.

Vocabulary.mean: Binoculars are a device used for seeing things that are far away.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We looked at the birds through binoculars.

Vocabulary.mean: The bulk of something is its great size.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He gave the bulk of his paintings to the museum.

Vocabulary.mean: If something comprises something else, it consists of or is made up of it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The apartment comprises six bedrooms and three living rooms.

Vocabulary.mean: To depict something means to show or portray it, often using art.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The movie depicts American society in the 1930s.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is dual, then it is made up of two parts.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He is a complicated person, everything he says has a dual meaning.

Vocabulary.mean: Fahrenheit temperature is a scale where water freezes at 32° and boils at 212°.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Fahrenheit scale is still used throughout the US.

Vocabulary.mean: To fulfill something means to achieve or finish it.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. At the age of 45, she finally fulfilled her ambition to run a marathon.

Vocabulary.mean: A grove is a small group of trees.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. All the trees in this grove are orange trees.

Vocabulary.mean: Ore is the raw form of rock or material from which a valuable metal is taken.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They are exploiting iron ore in the mountains.

Vocabulary.mean: The outback is the wild inland region of Australia where very few people live.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They often graze cattle in the outback.

Vocabulary.mean: To outweigh something means to exceed it in value, amount, or importance.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The risks are vastly outweighed by the potential benefits.

Vocabulary.mean: A paradox is a true statement or real event that seems illogical.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. It's a paradox that drinking a lot of water can make you feel thirsty.

Vocabulary.mean: A pier is a structure that extends into a body of water.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. After lunch, the family went for a walk along the pier.

Vocabulary.mean: A shortcut is a route that is shorter than the main route.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The kids take a shortcut through the parking lot to get to school.

Vocabulary.mean: A tariff is a tax or fee paid on certain imports or exports.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The US has imposed new tariffs on steel from China.

Vocabulary.mean: A thermometer is a device that measures temperature.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The thermometer indicates that today is a very cold day.

Vocabulary.mean: To tilt something means to tip it into a sloping position.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He tilted his chair back and put his feet up on the desk.

Vocabulary.mean: If a statement is vice versa, then its two main ideas are switched with one another.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He doesn't trust her, and vice versa.

Vocabulary.mean: The whereabouts of someone or something is the place where they are.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The thief's whereabouts have not been found.

Vocabulary.mean: Amber is a hard, yellowish material that comes from trees.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has a collection of prehistoric insects preserved in amber.

Vocabulary.mean: Charcoal is a black material that is used as fuel for fire.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They melted iron ore with charcoal.

Vocabulary.mean: A columnist is a writer who creates articles about a particular subject.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She's a columnist for The New York Times.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is courteous, they are polite and respectful.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The hotel staff are friendly and courteous.

Vocabulary.mean: Credentials are the proof of someone’s experience or ability to do something.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. He has all the credentials for the job.

Vocabulary.mean: A cricket is an insect that makes loud noises, usually at night.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The chirping of crickets make me uncomfortable.

Vocabulary.mean: A delta is flat area where a river splits into smaller rivers that flow into the sea.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The Amazon Delta has a very diverse flora.

Vocabulary.mean: Detergent is soap that is used to clean clothes or dishes.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. These clothes cannot be washed with detergent.

Vocabulary.mean: A euphemism is a term that is used in place of a mean or unpleasant word.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. ‘Pass away’ is a euphemism for ‘die’.

Vocabulary.mean: To expire is to no longer be effective because its use has come to an end.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. My passport expires next month.

Vocabulary.mean: Granite is a very hard type of rock that is often black or pink.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The kitchen counter was made of granite.

Vocabulary.mean: Gravel is a combination of small stones mixed with sand.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We walked along the coast to pick up colorful gravels.

Vocabulary.mean: To haunt is to cause problems or negative thoughts over a long period of time.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. She was haunted by memories of her unhappy childhood.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is liberal, they accept different ideas and people.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Her parents were far more liberal than mine.

Vocabulary.mean: A maze is a system of paths that is complicated and easy to get lost in.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. We got lost in the maze.

Vocabulary.mean: Moss is a small green or yellow plant that grows on wet dirt, rocks, or tree trunks.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. The rocks near the river were covered with moss.

Vocabulary.mean: A pebble is a small, round stone.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. This part of the coast has pebble beaches.

Vocabulary.mean: When a bird pecks, it bites or hits something with its beak.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Chickens pecked at the seeds which covered the ground.

Vocabulary.mean: A reservoir is a place for storing water for a town to use.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. They are building a system of water pipes from the reservoir to the field.

Vocabulary.mean: A streak is a long, thin mark that is easy to see.
Vocabulary.example: e.g. Meteors produce streaks of light as they burn up in the earth's atmosphere.
